headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Bronson, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Universal Health Services Fourth Quarter 2014 and Full Year Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I'
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Bronson, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Universal Health Services Fourth Quarter 2014 and Full Year Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. Steve Filton, CFO. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, thank you. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the full year and fourth quarter ended December 31, 2014. During the conference call, Alan then I will be usi
componenttext:
Good morning, thank you. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the full year and fourth quarter ended December 31, 2014. 
During the conference call, Alan then I will be using words such as believes, expects, anticipates, estimates and similar words that represent forecasts, projections and forward-looking statements. For anyone not familiar with the risks and uncertainties inherent in these forward-looking statements, I recommend the careful reading of the section on risk factors and forward-looking statements and risk factors in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014. 
We'd like to highlight just a couple of developments and business trends before opening the call up to questions.
As discussed in our press release last night, the company recorded net income attributable to UHS per diluted share of $5.42 for the year and $1.71 for the quarter. After adjusting for a reduction in malpractice reserves relating to prior years and the incentive income and expenses associated with the implementation of electronic health record applications at our acute care hospitals, our adjusted net income attributable to UHS per diluted share for the quarter ended December 31, 2014, was $1.51.
On a same facility basis, revenues from our Behavioral Health division increased 3.6% during the fourth quarter of 2014. Adjusted admissions and adjusted patient days to our behavioral health facilities owned for more than a year increased 6.8% and 2.8%, respectively, during the fourth quarter. Revenue per adjusted patient day rose 3.2% during the fourth quarter of 2014 over the comparable prior year quarter.
We define operating margins as operating income or net revenues less salaries and wages and benefits and other operating expenses and supply expense divided by net revenues. Operating margins for behavioral health hospitals owned for more than a year increased slightly to 28.0% during the quarter ended December 31, 2014, as compared to 27.7% during the comparable prior year period.
On a same facility basis in our acute care division, revenues increased 14.9% during the fourth quarter of 2014. Adjusted admissions increased 5.5% while revenue per adjusted admission increased 8.8%. 
On a same facility basis operating margins for our acute care hospitals increased to 18.1% during the fourth quarter of 2014 as compared to 14.1% during the fourth quarter of 2013.
Our cash generated from operating activities increased to approximately $346 million during the fourth quarter of 2014 as compared to $308 million during the fourth quarter of 2013.
Our cash generated from operating activities increased to approximately $1.04 billion during the full year of 2014 as compared to $884 million during 2013.
Our accounts receivable days outstanding decreased to 56 days during the fourth quarter of 2014 as compared to 57 days during the fourth quarter of 2013. At December 31, 2014, our ratio of debt to total capitalization was 47%.
During 2014, we opened a total of 602 new behavioral health beds, including 162 beds opened at 2 de novo hospitals and 440 beds opened at some of our busiest facilities. In addition, we already have approved projects to add approximately 550 new behavioral health beds and convert approximately 50 beds from residential treatment center to acute during 2015 and that number could grow as we continue to pursue opportunities to add and convert additional beds.
We spent $82 million on capital expenditures during the fourth quarter of 2014 and $391 million during the full year of 2014.
During 2015, we expect to spend approximately $375 million to $400 million in capital expenditures, which includes expenditures for capital equipment, renovations, new projects at existing hospitals and construction of new facilities.
In conjunction with our share repurchase program that commenced during the third quarter of 2014, during the fourth quarter, we repurchased 321,500 shares of our stock at an average price of slightly less than $102 per share.
Our estimated range of adjusted net income attributable to UHS for the year ended December 31, 2015, is $6.15 to $6.55 per diluted share. The guidance range excludes the unfavorable $0.12 per diluted share of EHR, expected EHR impact expected during 2015 as described in our press release last night. This guidance range represents, an increase of approximately 6% to 13% over the adjusted net income attributable to UHS of $5.78 [ph] per diluted share for the year ended December 31, 2014, as calculated on the Supplemental Schedule included in last night's press release.
During 2015, our net revenues are estimated to be approximately $8.7 billion to $8.8 billion, representing an increase of approximately 8% to 9% over our 2014 net revenues . Included in our estimated 2015 net revenues are revenues associated with the previously announced acquisition of Cygnet Health Care in the U.K. and a health insurance company in Nevada.
In addition, during the fourth quarter we acquired 46-bed behavioral health hospital located near Taunton in the United Kingdom. Alan and I are pleased to answer your questions at this time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Josh Raskin with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Josh Raskin with Barclays.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I just wanted to dig into the 14.8% growth on the acute care same-store and maybe get a little bit better sense on the revenue per adjusted admission of 8.8% maybe any specific markets or any other commentary that can point to that strength?
componenttext: Steve, I just wanted to dig into the 14.8% growth on the acute care same-store and maybe get a little bit better sense on the revenue per adjusted admission of 8.8% maybe any specific markets or any other commentary that can point to that strength?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So, first line, I mean, I think there are a couple of sort of extraordinary things in the quarter. We called out the $11 million of Texas [indiscernible] in the press release, we also have spoken before about $4 million of California UPL that I know
componenttext: Sure. So, first line, I mean, I think there are a couple of sort of extraordinary things in the quarter. We called out the $11 million of Texas [indiscernible] in the press release, we also have spoken before about $4 million of California UPL that I know some of our peers have recognized as well in the fourth quarter. So if you adjust those things out, it probably brings the revenue growth down by a couple of hundred basis points, still by any measure, a very strong and robust revenue growth quarter. Our admission growth seems to be fairly consistent with our peers who have reported similar strong volumes. What seems to distinguish the UHS performance in the quarter was that really robust revenue intensity and revenue per unit per admission per day. I think a lot of that, Josh, was driven by strong surgical volumes we had both in- and outpatient surgical volume growth of approximately 5%. And for the first time I can remember in a long time, the inpatient growth actually was outpacing the outpatients. So I think that's what really drove some of that revenue intensity.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And no specific markets that jumped out?
componenttext: And no specific markets that jumped out?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, honestly, Josh, when you get an outperformance that strong, it's got to be pretty sort of, pervasive throughout the portfolio and I think ours was.
componenttext: I think, honestly, Josh, when you get an outperformance that strong, it's got to be pretty sort of, pervasive throughout the portfolio and I think ours was.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that makes sense. Just last one on '15. Any sense of the impact of reform that you baked into that guidance on -- I know there's no new sort of Medicaid expansion space, but just curious, there's got to be some anniversary-ing et cetera. Is there a w
componenttext: Yes, that makes sense. Just last one on '15. Any sense of the impact of reform that you baked into that guidance on -- I know there's no new sort of Medicaid expansion space, but just curious, there's got to be some anniversary-ing et cetera. Is there a way to quantify the positive benefit in '15?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm going to preface my answer with first thing, but I think as time lapses and each quarter goes by, we find it a little more challenging to be able to discreetly identify the reform impact from others sort of payer mix improvements and kind of espe
componenttext: Yes. I'm going to preface my answer with first thing, but I think as time lapses and each quarter goes by, we find it a little more challenging to be able to discreetly identify the reform impact from others sort of payer mix improvements and kind of especially from sort of the general economic improvement that we've been enjoying in our markets. I will say, however, that I think our best guesstimate is that we've got, and I think again this is fairly consistent with what we understand that some of our peers have done but I've said, but I think in the acute care division, we assume that the ACA impact in 2015 will be about 6% to 7% of our overall earnings. And that's I think a little bit of an increase over 2014.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And behavioral is still sticking with the same impact as you saw this year?
componenttext: Okay. And behavioral is still sticking with the same impact as you saw this year?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think, in behavioral, we've mentioned before that we find it difficult to discreetly identify the ACA and I'll also include in that the mental health parity impact in the behavioral division. So that we have not really discreetly budgeted o
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think, in behavioral, we've mentioned before that we find it difficult to discreetly identify the ACA and I'll also include in that the mental health parity impact in the behavioral division. So that we have not really discreetly budgeted or guided for that to the degree that we enjoyed a little bit of that in '14, which I think, is possible we certainly sort of included that in the base and the growth of our base, but have not really included as we have in the acute care division a specific impact for either ACA or parity.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Rigg good Susquehanna.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Rigg good Susquehanna.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just -- the leverage at this point was down to about 2x. You've got some internal stuff going on with regard to development, but I guess just more generally, how are you thinking about capital deployment at this point, share repurchases, more M&A, e
componenttext: I was just -- the leverage at this point was down to about 2x. You've got some internal stuff going on with regard to development, but I guess just more generally, how are you thinking about capital deployment at this point, share repurchases, more M&A, et cetera, just trying to get a sense for -- and we're you comfortable at 2x or you want that actually -- you want to see that go a little higher at this point?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, I'm going largely I think, reiterate the comments that we've made at the end of the second quarter when we talk about the fact that our leverage had declined to a level that we were very comfortable with and that's when the announced our $400 milli
componenttext: Chris, I'm going largely I think, reiterate the comments that we've made at the end of the second quarter when we talk about the fact that our leverage had declined to a level that we were very comfortable with and that's when the announced our $400 million share repurchase authorization. And I think we're in largely the same place as we're in now. Since then, we announced the Cygnet acquisition and dedicated about $335 million to that. But we continue to look for growth opportunities, both externally and internally in both of our business segments. We announced just in the call, a small acquisition in the U.K. We continue to look for other opportunities in the U.K. as well as other M&A opportunities in both behavioral and acute here in the U.S. and also continue to expand organically. I mentioned that the new behavioral beds that we've got online for next year. We've talked about our new acute-care hospital that we're building in Las Vegas so we've got a number of things going on. But I think we have also said that if we don't find sufficient sort of opportunities for external growth, we're also more than happy to continue to repurchase shares under the previously announced authorization. So I think from our perspective we're likely to pursue sort of all those avenues in 2015.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one follow up. I know we've talked about the IMD exclusion and legislation around that in the past. Can you give us an update for where that stands and sort of just some general parameters in terms of likelihood for this happening sometime
componenttext: Okay. And just one follow up. I know we've talked about the IMD exclusion and legislation around that in the past. Can you give us an update for where that stands and sort of just some general parameters in terms of likelihood for this happening sometime in the future?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think that we certainly have done nothing to presume that the IMD exclusion will be lifted in the near term. It certainly at least in the context of this conversation the near term being 2015, but I think the industry in general is becoming more and
componenttext: So I think that we certainly have done nothing to presume that the IMD exclusion will be lifted in the near term. It certainly at least in the context of this conversation the near term being 2015, but I think the industry in general is becoming more and more positive about the idea that from a public policy perspective, that either legislatively or administratively there will be progress on this issue. As you know, there is a demonstration project that's part of the Affordable Care Act that lift the IMD exclusion in about a dozen states, and we were participating in some of the states in that project. We believe that the outcome and the data from that demo project will support the idea that a broader lifting of the exclusion makes sense from a public policy perspective in terms of access and cost. And again, as an industry we continue to lobby hard for that and that remains one of our main priorities again from a legislative/regulatory perspective. So we'll continue to work for it. We continue to feel that there's positive movement there, but I think it's difficult to predict with any sort of level of precision when there might be a substantive change.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gurda with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gurda with KeyBanc.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, just taking a look at the guidance expecting growth of about 6% to 13% and I think you did high 20s this year and you're putting up almost double-digit revenue growth or, particularly double-digit in the acute care side. Is the guidance conservativ
componenttext: Steve, just taking a look at the guidance expecting growth of about 6% to 13% and I think you did high 20s this year and you're putting up almost double-digit revenue growth or, particularly double-digit in the acute care side. Is the guidance conservative at this point?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Obviously, I'm going to tell you that I think the guidance is realistic. I will say this, I mean, our performance in 2014 was really extraordinary and we certainly view it that way and we couldn't be anymore pleased with it. But certainly feel that it wou
componenttext: Obviously, I'm going to tell you that I think the guidance is realistic. I will say this, I mean, our performance in 2014 was really extraordinary and we certainly view it that way and we couldn't be anymore pleased with it. But certainly feel that it would be difficult to replicate as you sort of suggest the sort of growth we saw in 2014. I think a good portion or a good reason for that is, while we were all meeting the company as well as our peers, we're focused on the potential ACA impact in '14. And I think we largely anticipated that correctly. We didn't really anticipate that benefit we were going to get from improving economies in the number of our markets, particularly in Texas, but also in Florida and California, et cetera. And I think as we look towards next year, we are cautious about, again, our ability to replicate that same level of growth. I think we feel like we'll continue to see improving economies in those markets for the most part. Now I will also add that I think in the last month or 2 we've gotten a little bit more cautious about the Texas economy specifically given the pressures from oil and gas prices. So -- and I think we've stepped back our projections in those markets, particularly. But other than that, again, I just think we are forecasting strong performance in '15 just not quite as robust as we saw in '14.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, and then I may have this [indiscernible], but it looks to me that the range of your guidance is a little bit wider that it has been in the past. If that's the case, is there a reason for that?
componenttext: That's helpful, and then I may have this [indiscernible], but it looks to me that the range of your guidance is a little bit wider that it has been in the past. If that's the case, is there a reason for that?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Honestly, I thought we felt like the range was fairly consistent. I mean, maybe a little bit wider than what we had last year but fairly consistent with sort of the ranges that our peers were putting up. And there was nothing necessarily be read into
componenttext: No. Honestly, I thought we felt like the range was fairly consistent. I mean, maybe a little bit wider than what we had last year but fairly consistent with sort of the ranges that our peers were putting up. And there was nothing necessarily be read into it. I think we actually think it's a reasonable range.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Kevin Fischbeck from Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Kevin Fischbeck from Bank of America.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Steve Baxter on for Kevin. Many of your peers have talked about how their exchange contract in strategy has evolved for 2015 relative to 2014. I guess, can you give us a sense of the flavor of what you learned for 2014 approach and what you've don
componenttext: This is Steve Baxter on for Kevin. Many of your peers have talked about how their exchange contract in strategy has evolved for 2015 relative to 2014. I guess, can you give us a sense of the flavor of what you learned for 2014 approach and what you've done differently for 2015?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think in our case, Steve, we have said and largely reflective of our experience that we were participants in almost all of the exchange products in our markets in 2014, with a couple of maybe minor exceptions. And, honestly, I think for the most pa
componenttext: Yes. I think in our case, Steve, we have said and largely reflective of our experience that we were participants in almost all of the exchange products in our markets in 2014, with a couple of maybe minor exceptions. And, honestly, I think for the most part, that's our experience in '15 again. I think that we're pleased with that. We continue to work with some payers in our markets in the context of potentially more narrow networks in which we would be a preferred provider. And again, I think we have a couple of minor examples of that in '15, but not as much as maybe we anticipated we would have last year. But so I think again, the broad description of it is that we are in virtually every product and every network, every exchange product and every exchange network, in all of our markets, which is a couple of very minor exceptions.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just switching to the behavioral side. I'd length of stay was down less than it has been for a long time. You think you're getting closer to stabilization or a turning point here? And I guess how you're thinking about that for 2015?
componenttext: Okay. And then just switching to the behavioral side. I'd length of stay was down less than it has been for a long time. You think you're getting closer to stabilization or a turning point here? And I guess how you're thinking about that for 2015?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll answer the first part, first -- or the last part first, and that is in thinking about it for 2015, I think we've assumed another decline in length of stay at about the same way that it has been going down, and I think the reason for that is it's been
componenttext: I'll answer the first part, first -- or the last part first, and that is in thinking about it for 2015, I think we've assumed another decline in length of stay at about the same way that it has been going down, and I think the reason for that is it's been difficult to sort of, project this quarter-to-quarter, some quarters looks like the decline is slowing a little bit. Other quarters not so much. So we continue to project the length of stay pressures will continue into '15, that's what our guidance reflects. I would say that I certainly noticed in the fourth quarter that some of the decline in length of stay that we experienced was self-imposed or self-executed, if you will, in the sense that I mentioned, to some degree, the conversion of residential beds to acute and we've been doing that for a while. And to the degree that we continue to do that, we will drive the length of stay down ourselves because the length of stay in our acute facilities is clearly lower than it is in our residential facilities. But I do think that's reflected in that stronger revenue per day that you saw in the fourth quarter. Because, obviously, as we shift beds and therefore, days and admission from residential to acute, we'll see a drop in length of stay but we ought to see a rise in revenue per day.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: and I think you can see some of that in Q4.
componenttext: and I think you can see some of that in Q4.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I was wondering if you could give us a little bit of color on your expectations for 2015 on maybe the same facility revenue in volume expectations by segment? Can you help us or parse that out for us?
componenttext: Steve, I was wondering if you could give us a little bit of color on your expectations for 2015 on maybe the same facility revenue in volume expectations by segment? Can you help us or parse that out for us?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paula. So I think on the acute side, our expectation of revenue growth is probably in that 6% to 7% range, which I think in turn, yields EBITDA growth in probably the 8% to 10% range. On the behavioral side, I think that's a little bit lower, probab
componenttext: Sure, Paula. So I think on the acute side, our expectation of revenue growth is probably in that 6% to 7% range, which I think in turn, yields EBITDA growth in probably the 8% to 10% range. On the behavioral side, I think that's a little bit lower, probably more in the range of kind of 5.5% -- 5%, 5.5% on the revenue side, which translates to like to sort of 7.5%, 8% on the EBITDA site.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just going back to the acute metrics. How sustainable do you think these trends are in the first quarter in '15 given the guidance that you just gave us? And is there anything about the surgical volumes that were so good in the fourt
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just going back to the acute metrics. How sustainable do you think these trends are in the first quarter in '15 given the guidance that you just gave us? And is there anything about the surgical volumes that were so good in the fourth quarter that would indicate those would continue to be strong?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the way that we went about budgeting for 2015 was really not to assume that any one quarter of the year was particularly representative and particularly I think not necessarily taking the approach that the fourth quarter exit rate was the rate to
componenttext: I think the way that we went about budgeting for 2015 was really not to assume that any one quarter of the year was particularly representative and particularly I think not necessarily taking the approach that the fourth quarter exit rate was the rate to use for the full year of '15. We have a couple of very strong surgical volume quarters in '14, the second quarter was really strong, the fourth quarter was really strong. I think even in retrospect, it's a little bit difficult for us to identify exactly why that was. So I will say that I think that 2015 guidance presumes a more modest sort of surgical experience then what we experienced certainly in Q4 and something that's more reflective of our full year experience. And to be fair, I think the year has started of at least in January, with kind of a more muted surgical volume. There was a lot of, at least, speculation in the back half of '14 that -- hospitals to some degree, would experience in surgeon volume at the end of the year given the increasing prevalence of high deductible plans and that really might influence patient behavior as people exhausted their co-patient deductibles late in the year and we'll take advantage of that. And I don't know if that's what really drove the dynamic we experienced, but we certainly have a real strong surgical quarter in Q4 and a little bit weaker as 2015 started. So we've at least been not inconsistent with that theory. So again, I think we've just been more kind of rational or muted about what our 2015 volumes should look like and I think, that's what's reflected in the guidance.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Steve, I have just 1 quick one on Medicaid expansion I'm just wondering, if you could share some of your thoughts with us on the potential for more states to expand, in particular Florida, just given Tennessee and Utah sort of reaching dead e
componenttext: Okay, great. Steve, I have just 1 quick one on Medicaid expansion I'm just wondering, if you could share some of your thoughts with us on the potential for more states to expand, in particular Florida, just given Tennessee and Utah sort of reaching dead ends or so it seems for now. What does that mean for Florida, if anything? And maybe some of your thoughts are there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, again now -- sort of give the short answer is, we certainly have not assumed that any new states, new for us, would expand Medicaid in 2015, which again for UHS I think really means as we said that we've assume that neither Texas nor Florida would e
componenttext: Well, again now -- sort of give the short answer is, we certainly have not assumed that any new states, new for us, would expand Medicaid in 2015, which again for UHS I think really means as we said that we've assume that neither Texas nor Florida would expand in 2015. I think we have had a view really from the beginning of ACA implementation that in the long run, all states would ultimately participate in Medicaid expansion because it just made economic sense for them to do so. Obviously, I think in a lot of cases, economic census being overwhelmed or pressured by political considerations and I think we find those very hard to sort of measure and calculate. So we continue again in our state hospital associations and in other forums to work for expansion in those states and which we operate that have not expanded yet. Again, don't expect anything necessarily to happen in '15 as you suggest there's a struggle in a couple of the states that have tried it. So we just continue to present the issue. Again as an industry, especially with both our for-profit and especially our not-for-profit peers.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ralph Giacobbe with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ralph Giacobbe with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: The quarterly progression was pretty lumpy in 2014. I know you don't give quarterly guidance, but any general direction on how you'd expect or see it kind of playing out in 2015?
componenttext: The quarterly progression was pretty lumpy in 2014. I know you don't give quarterly guidance, but any general direction on how you'd expect or see it kind of playing out in 2015?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ralph, frankly, part of the -- one of the reasons why we don't give quarterly guidance is we think it's difficult to do. And I appreciate the fact that folks in your position are forced to do so. Look, I suggested before and you've alluded to the fact tha
componenttext: Ralph, frankly, part of the -- one of the reasons why we don't give quarterly guidance is we think it's difficult to do. And I appreciate the fact that folks in your position are forced to do so. Look, I suggested before and you've alluded to the fact that we had, as you described some lumpiness in 2014, honestly, we're unable to predict that. I guess the best advice that I would give to people is to budget 2015 or think about 2015 a bit more ratably and not necessarily try and mimic the sort of seasonal or quarterly trends that we experienced in 2014 because I think in our own minds, it's not obvious that those trends would be repeated in that same fashion in '15.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right, that's fair. And then, you've obviously talked about acute and surgical mix. Can you talk a little bit about payer mix and what you saw there between the various buckets?
componenttext: Okay, all right, that's fair. And then, you've obviously talked about acute and surgical mix. Can you talk a little bit about payer mix and what you saw there between the various buckets?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we basically felt like our payer mix strength, which, of course, I think at the end of the day, was really what drove the outsized performance of the, particularly the acute division in 2014. It really was relatively stable throughout the yea
componenttext: Yes. I think we basically felt like our payer mix strength, which, of course, I think at the end of the day, was really what drove the outsized performance of the, particularly the acute division in 2014. It really was relatively stable throughout the year. Now the character have changed some, in the sense that in the beginning of the year, the payer mix improvement was clearly more weighted to Medicaid -- more Medicaid patients and that is Medicaid patients, and I think was a function of Medicaid expansion in some of our large states like Nevada, like California and the District of Colombia. And then, in the back half of the year, we saw a bit more of a shift from the Medicaid impact to the commercial exchange impact, but just generally, I think the payer mix was -- the payer mix improvement was really a constant for us in 2014. And as I said, generally, a -- the biggest and primary driver of the really strong performance, and again, I think as we answered your question before about the guidance, I think we expect that, that payer mix improvement continues into 2015 and our guidance reflects that, but that it does not necessarily continue at the same rate. And certainly, one of the sort of muting dynamics that we have is that we don't have any new states as we just talked about at to participate in Medicaid expansion next year. So to some degree, the Medicaid improvement certainly levels off pretty considerably in '15.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and there's one more if I could. I think charity and discounts were up in the fourth quarter. I'm just trying to understand a little bit of the dynamics around the, what would that maybe be the case and what if anything are doing as patients present
componenttext: Okay, and there's one more if I could. I think charity and discounts were up in the fourth quarter. I'm just trying to understand a little bit of the dynamics around the, what would that maybe be the case and what if anything are doing as patients present to get them signed up?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think of that -- let me answer the question in a couple of different ways I think, that in terms of signing patients up, like many, or I would probably speculate, like most of our peers, we've developed a pretty rigorous process to make sure that w
componenttext: Yes. I think of that -- let me answer the question in a couple of different ways I think, that in terms of signing patients up, like many, or I would probably speculate, like most of our peers, we've developed a pretty rigorous process to make sure that we have certified counselors in all of our facilities and that we're both proactively and reactively responding to patients who come to our facilities uninsured and trying to find the most effective and efficient way to get them insured, whether that's enrollment in Medicaid or through commercial exchange opportunity, would we are doing all those things. Now at the end of the day, I think as I said most hospitals are probably doing something similar. As far as the swings in charity and bad debt, I know I'm going to sound like a broken record when I say this, but we find it difficult even internally to explain some of the specific movements between those buckets. And I always make the point that as company, we analyze uncompensated care as sort of a single unified bucket, and we include bad debt, and charity care and uninsured discount. And again, I think if you look at those numbers on a combined basis, it reinforces the comment that I made before which is there's a significant decline in those numbers in 2014 throughout the year. And it's reflective of the ACA and improved economic benefits that we've already talked about.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's fair, Steve. I guess from my perspective, just trying to understand -- when you offer sort of the charity care, there's no pressure on the individual to have to pay for it, right? So I guess my thought process was, why would not there be more of pu
componenttext: That's fair, Steve. I guess from my perspective, just trying to understand -- when you offer sort of the charity care, there's no pressure on the individual to have to pay for it, right? So I guess my thought process was, why would not there be more of push to bad debt even if you have to write it off, the pressure on the individual would, ultimately, then perhaps, force them to consider getting enrolls either via exchanges or Medicaid versus just writing if off right upfront? Am I not thinking about that, right? Or would there be an initiative buy sort of high -- because I think in the past you talk about letting each of the individual hospitals kind of determine that. Would that makes sense in terms of trying to even push that number lower?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. I think the balance that we and all hospitals walk is trying to be reasonable about what is a reasonable level of income and assets for patients to qualify for charity care. So somebody comes in the hospital level with no insurance and a very low-i
componenttext: Right. I think the balance that we and all hospitals walk is trying to be reasonable about what is a reasonable level of income and assets for patients to qualify for charity care. So somebody comes in the hospital level with no insurance and a very low-income level and no assets and the general physician this made, based on the script is that there really is no point in making an effort to collect from this patients. I think your question is, why didn't you try and collect from as many patients as you possibly can? And I would answer in 2 ways. I mean, I think that one, from sort of the sort of a public policy perspective, we recognize that for people at a very low-income level with little assets, it really is just too much of a burden for them to pay some of these bills. And then secondly, I think from a business perspective, it's an effort that we have found can consume a fair amount of time and money and really yield very little. So again, we try and have a charity policy that I think is fairly consistent with industry that tries to walk that line and collects from people who really can't afford to pay but really doesn't try and collect from that portion of the population that can't.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ana Gupte with Leerink Swann Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ana Gupte with Leerink Swann Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, just wanted to follow up on some of the comments I thought I've heard from you recently on the state Medicaid budgets and pressures in 2015. Just kind of giving us a color on why you might be concerned? And are you baking in anything in guidance th
componenttext: Steve, just wanted to follow up on some of the comments I thought I've heard from you recently on the state Medicaid budgets and pressures in 2015. Just kind of giving us a color on why you might be concerned? And are you baking in anything in guidance that might not have happened? Or are these already events under way?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Ana, I think that the comments that you are alluding to are comments that I made consistent with what I said earlier in the call, that over the last couple of months, we have backed off our projections and guidance for our Texas markets. And to be fair
componenttext: So Ana, I think that the comments that you are alluding to are comments that I made consistent with what I said earlier in the call, that over the last couple of months, we have backed off our projections and guidance for our Texas markets. And to be fair, I don't think we've seen currently a lot of softness in those markets but are just anticipating the possibility of such, given the fact that the Texas economy seems to be slowing. And again, I think we could see that softness in a number of ways through a slightly deteriorating payer mix or slightly lower volumes, or through some pressure from the state, either in traditional Medicaid rates or some of the special reimbursement programs that we benefit from. And so I think those are the comments that you're thinking about. So in general I mean, we didn't make any specific cuts or assume specific cuts in Texas reimbursement, but just sort of step back our Texas earnings projections for next year a little bit and on a broad basis in expectation that we might feel some pressures in that economy in 2015 that we clearly did not feel in 2014.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so it sounds like more sort of second order that could happen at the state level rather than just currently insured consumer?
componenttext: Okay. And so it sounds like more sort of second order that could happen at the state level rather than just currently insured consumer?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that's right. And also I think it's correct because I mean, the fact of the matter is that how our Texas markets are really tend not to be markets that are directly tied to the oil and gas industry, markets like Dallas or West Texas. We tend to be
componenttext: I think that's right. And also I think it's correct because I mean, the fact of the matter is that how our Texas markets are really tend not to be markets that are directly tied to the oil and gas industry, markets like Dallas or West Texas. We tend to be in markets that are sort of more indirectly impacted by the overall status economy.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just switching gears to the March court hearing status as per your recent discussions with the lobby groups and with Congress and the state officials. What are you expecting or hearing in terms of if these things gets -- if subsidies get cut off,
componenttext: And then just switching gears to the March court hearing status as per your recent discussions with the lobby groups and with Congress and the state officials. What are you expecting or hearing in terms of if these things gets -- if subsidies get cut off, what might happen and who might take the lead in addressing this?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all, obviously, I mean, while we followed this closely as do all of you, we certainly do feel like we don't have any particularly valuable insight into how this might turn out. And so we'll just continue to follow it very closely. If the
componenttext: Yes. So first of all, obviously, I mean, while we followed this closely as do all of you, we certainly do feel like we don't have any particularly valuable insight into how this might turn out. And so we'll just continue to follow it very closely. If the Supreme Court were to rule against the subsidies, we would certainly work very hard in the various states that we operate and that don't have state exchanges at the moment to get them established. But again I think that at least in the short run, we acknowledge that would be sort of a difficult hurdle to overcome. So, obviously, we've done nothing in our guidance as I don't think any of our peers have to reflect the Supreme Court decision. [indiscernible] could be unfavorable, but we -- our guidance presumes status quo. But if a decision is a negative one from our perspective, we'll just work very aggressively with our state associations to try and accomplish the sorts of workarounds that people have identified and written about, and I'll make the obvious comment here that I think as a company, we are less exposed to this issue than our peers since 2/3 of our earnings come from the behavioral business where I think we don't feel like we've gotten much of an ACA benefit and therefore, really not exposed if this were to be a bit of a headwind in 2015 or maybe beyond.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And this 1%, you think an appropriate estimate for exposure, 1%-ish or less?
componenttext: And this 1%, you think an appropriate estimate for exposure, 1%-ish or less?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think a number of the sell-side estimates have been the amount of our overall earnings that are subject to states that have federal exchanges or maybe 1% to 2%, and I think that number tends to be lower for us than our peers again it's really just
componenttext: Yes, I think a number of the sell-side estimates have been the amount of our overall earnings that are subject to states that have federal exchanges or maybe 1% to 2%, and I think that number tends to be lower for us than our peers again it's really just specific to the acute care business. But I think that's a pretty accurate guesstimate of what that impact would be.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Darren Lehrich with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is actually Josh calling in for Dan. Can you just first talk about your U.K. pipeline and if you're seeing much over there come to market?
componenttext: This is actually Josh calling in for Dan. Can you just first talk about your U.K. pipeline and if you're seeing much over there come to market?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that the U.K. acquisition landscape is, in some respect, similar to what it's like here in the U.S., it's fairly fragmented. We obviously have, as I said, just in my prepared remarks announced a small deal of kind of a one-off acquisition. We are
componenttext: I think that the U.K. acquisition landscape is, in some respect, similar to what it's like here in the U.S., it's fairly fragmented. We obviously have, as I said, just in my prepared remarks announced a small deal of kind of a one-off acquisition. We are pursuing a de novo development project right now in the U.K. and I think pursuing a kind of a whole array of other potential possibilities. It think we described, when we announced the Cygnet deal that we thought that was a landscape that was right for continued expansion in the sort of one of the motivations for getting into that market. So our view of that has not really changed. I mean, we've been enthusiastic about the early results of existing facilities that we bought in the U.K. and remain enthusiastic about the growth opportunities as well, which I think will be both a sort of again, organic and inorganic some small, over time, maybe some large.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right, great, that's helpful. And then just in terms of your guidance. Can you maybe talk about some of the bigger swing factors that you get you to the high end, low end of that? And maybe the level of capital deployment you guys are assuming?
componenttext: All right, great, that's helpful. And then just in terms of your guidance. Can you maybe talk about some of the bigger swing factors that you get you to the high end, low end of that? And maybe the level of capital deployment you guys are assuming?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So from a capital employment perspective, we've assumed, as we said, in our press ways and I said in my remarks, somewhere between $375 million and $400 million of CapEx, and that's fairly similar to this year's experience. We have historically never incl
componenttext: So from a capital employment perspective, we've assumed, as we said, in our press ways and I said in my remarks, somewhere between $375 million and $400 million of CapEx, and that's fairly similar to this year's experience. We have historically never included share repurchases assumptions in our guidance, and we have not done so this year as well. As far as other sort of pushes and pulls, if you will, I think we've already talked about a couple. From a special reimbursements perspective and we include in that sort of broad category disproportionate share, this disparate funding in taxes, provided [indiscernible], we feel arrangements I think the overall that reimbursement decline is a little bit in 2015 maybe $5 million or $10 million, I think that we have some dilution, -- the dilution probably not word, but probably begin pulling in our Temecula market in '14. That facility open in late in '13 we had a fair amount of start-up cost and start-up losses and now this year, we've been profitable, and so as a consequence that was a big swing. We'll continue to improve in that Temecula market, but the improvement in '15 just is not going to be as great as it was in '14. So depending on how you think about it, that's a little bit of a headwind. I think those are the only couple of things that I think we had not mentioned yet, that I would call out. Otherwise I think it's largely kind of steady as she goes other than what we already talked where I think, we've just been a little bit muted in how much payer mix improvement we can expect in '15 versus what we were able to achieve in '14.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right, great. And then, just lastly, just looks like from the 10-K there were some additional developments in terms of your ongoing investigations and maybe please provide us with an update on what's going on. And if there's anything new?
componenttext: All right, great. And then, just lastly, just looks like from the 10-K there were some additional developments in terms of your ongoing investigations and maybe please provide us with an update on what's going on. And if there's anything new?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that the only real change in our disclosure in the 10-K was the added disclosure that we had received -- a request from the government for information for a one incremental facility in Salt Lake City. Other than that, I would just sort of broadly
componenttext: I think that the only real change in our disclosure in the 10-K was the added disclosure that we had received -- a request from the government for information for a one incremental facility in Salt Lake City. Other than that, I would just sort of broadly say that the investigation continues. We have had some preliminary conversations with the government, but I think it's fair to say for anyone who's hospital and I think most hospitals have encountered some version of this process that takes it a long time and it think we would say we're in the early stages and it would be difficult for us to either project with any precision the ultimate resolution and outcome or even the timing of such.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Lieberman with Wells Fargo.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015

componenttext: One of your peers noted some uncertainty regarding Texas on Medicare payments. Can you maybe discuss if you got any uncertainty or range of variability around those payments?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think, Gary, I hope that what you're referencing is ACA has some of these waiver programs and they had originally reserved for some of those payments when CMS had sort of targeted them earlier in the year and then when CMS sort of lifted their d
componenttext: Yes. So I think, Gary, I hope that what you're referencing is ACA has some of these waiver programs and they had originally reserved for some of those payments when CMS had sort of targeted them earlier in the year and then when CMS sort of lifted their deferral of payments, ACA recognized those payments, et cetera, we really had none of that back and forth because you were not we do not have program and have that same County that ACA did that have been sort of targeted by CMS. So I would just say that for the most part, we have assumed that our again, Texas special reimbursement, which includes those programs and [indiscernible] will continue next year, pretty consistently again with the 1 caveat that in total and that includes all the states we operate, in that special reimbursement declined by $5 million or $10 million next year.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, maybe [indiscernible] Alan's thoughts on the potential for a congressional fix may be ahead of the Supreme Court decision or if the government loses the [indiscernible] case?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, maybe [indiscernible] Alan's thoughts on the potential for a congressional fix may be ahead of the Supreme Court decision or if the government loses the [indiscernible] case?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that it would be very simple to have it fixed legislatively, but I don't think it's going to happen. If you're following what's happening with the Republican Party at the moment, in all the meetings, that's not going to happen. But that would be v
componenttext: I think that it would be very simple to have it fixed legislatively, but I don't think it's going to happen. If you're following what's happening with the Republican Party at the moment, in all the meetings, that's not going to happen. But that would be very simple. But the government said that they have not developed a plan B, which I can't believe. So there will be a number of workarounds. I think, the thing to focus on is that 5 million people will lose insurance immediately. and I think, public policy on both Democrats, Republicans and, et cetera, and that those people should be covered. So I think it will be at some point a fix for this, should it come out negatively from the Supreme Court.

componenttext: So Frank,, I'm not exactly sure. About the flu impact on ED volume I think flu tends to impact ED volumes sort of disproportionately more than admission. I will say that I think our general sense of the flu and admissions was probably no more than sort of 30 or 40 basis points.

componenttext: Okay, what about just ED volumes in general? Do you have a number there?

componenttext: ED volumes were very strong. We definitely saw heightened ED activity as a result of the flu, but I think also we saw heightened ED activity just in general. And again, as I think our admission numbers reflect, I mean, it was a very strong volume quarter and generally, admission growth tends to move in proportion to ED volumes, and I think that was what we experienced in Q4.

componenttext: No, I think it was really kind of boss the various service lines, so that was, not necessarily isolated to cardiology or orthopedics or even general surgery. I do think it's hard to get these kinds of numbers because until we have real broad-based strength.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions, if I could. I know you talked about you've talked about health reform on a couple of answer already, but do have a  Q4 run rate of ACA benefit concert of I know it's maybe not precise, but just in general? And can you break tha
componenttext: Just a couple of questions, if I could. I know you talked about you've talked about health reform on a couple of answer already, but do have a  Q4 run rate of ACA benefit concert of I know it's maybe not precise, but just in general? And can you break that out between what you think is the Medicaid benefits versus the exchange benefit?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So A.J., I mean, I think that we tried, and again, I can't get this by saying that I think even more so than our peers, I think we've always described the process of the discretely identifying the ACA benefit as less or more precise than maybe some people
componenttext: So A.J., I mean, I think that we tried, and again, I can't get this by saying that I think even more so than our peers, I think we've always described the process of the discretely identifying the ACA benefit as less or more precise than maybe some people think it might be. But I would generally say that I think our best efforts sort of quantify the ACA impact, for 2014 at about $40 million or so, something like that. and I think, that the quarterly progression of that, there's been a somewhat of, an increase as this year has gone on. And as more and more enrollment has taken place in both Medicaid and commercial exchanges. But it hasn't been terribly dramatic. So I would say, if you think about that $40 million distributed in the year, maybe we had $8 million in the first quarter and $12 million in the fourth quarter, something like that just in terms of order of magnitude.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the split between exchange versus Medicaid?
componenttext: Okay. And then the split between exchange versus Medicaid?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. As I think as we mentioned earlier, I think for the year, I think we think it's probably about 2/3 Medicaid related, and 1/3 commercial, and I think that's shifted. I mean, that was even more pronounced early in the year and then it got a little bit
componenttext: Yes. As I think as we mentioned earlier, I think for the year, I think we think it's probably about 2/3 Medicaid related, and 1/3 commercial, and I think that's shifted. I mean, that was even more pronounced early in the year and then it got a little bit weighted on commercial as the year went on, but I think, ultimately, was about a 2/3, 1/3 split for the year.

componenttext: Okay, and you mentioned California provider and Texas. Specifically on California provider, I know there's 2 pieces to it, the managed care and fee-for-service. headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. So prior to this, I think we identified our potential benefit from California UPL to be in sort of the $8 million or $9 million range for 2014. We recorded and recognized $4 million benefit in Q4 and that's because, as you described it, A.J., that'
componenttext: Right. So prior to this, I think we identified our potential benefit from California UPL to be in sort of the $8 million or $9 million range for 2014. We recorded and recognized $4 million benefit in Q4 and that's because, as you described it, A.J., that's the piece of the program that was approved and so we only recorded the income associated with the piece that the government has approved. We have guided only or included in our guidance for '15 a comparable number. And so if there is an approval of the second piece of that program, that would be an upside when it gets approved.

componenttext: Yes. So I don't have that in front of me, A.J., but we actually disclosed those number pretty specifically in the 10-K. So you can find them there. But I would generally say that in both cases, we actually are in pretty decent shape in both those states, still have outstanding receivables, but not anywhere near the sort of -- not anywhere near the balances when they were at their highest levels.

componenttext: You gave us some same-store stuff to get pretty close. Is there a case mix number to kind of support all of this surgical growth? Or is it more on the commercial side and not really reflecting the case mix?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015

componenttext: I think it's actually both. componenttext: Good morning. My name is Bronson, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Universal Health Services Fourth Quarter 2014 and Full Year Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. Steve Filton, CFO. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the full year and fourth quarter ended December 31, 2014. During the conference call, Alan and I will be usin
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the full year and fourth quarter ended December 31, 2014. 
During the conference call, Alan and I will be using words such as believes, expects, anticipates, estimates and similar words that represent forecasts, projections and forward-looking statements. For anyone not familiar with the risks and uncertainties inherent in these forward-looking statements, I recommend the careful reading of the section on risk factors and forward-looking statements and risk factors in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014. 
We'd like to highlight just a couple of developments and business trends before opening the call up to questions.
As discussed in our press release last night, the company recorded net income attributable to UHS per diluted share of $5.42 for the year and $1.71 for the quarter. After adjusting for a reduction in malpractice reserves relating to prior years and the incentive income and expenses associated with the implementation of electronic health record applications at our acute care hospitals, our adjusted net income attributable to UHS per diluted share for the quarter ended December 31, 2014 was $1.51.
On a same-facility basis, revenues in our behavioral health division increased 6.3% during the fourth quarter of 2014. Adjusted admissions and adjusted patient days to our behavioral health facilities owned for more than a year increased 6.8% and 2.8%, respectively, during the fourth quarter. Revenue per adjusted patient day rose 3.2% during the fourth quarter of 2014 over the comparable prior year quarter.
We define operating margins as operating income or net revenues less salaries, wages and benefits, other operating expenses and supplies expense divided by net revenues. Operating margins for our behavioral health hospitals owned for more than a year increased slightly to 28.0% during the quarter ended December 31, 2014 as compared to 27.7% during the comparable prior year period.
On a same-facility basis, in our acute care division, revenues increased 14.9% during the fourth quarter of 2014. Adjusted admissions increased 5.5%, while revenue per adjusted admission increased 8.8%. On a same-facility basis, operating margins for our acute care hospitals increased to 18.1% during the fourth quarter of 2014 as compared to 14.1% during the fourth quarter of 2013.
Our cash generated from operating activities increased to approximately $346 million during the fourth quarter of 2014 as compared to $308 million during the fourth quarter of 2013. Our cash generated from operating activities increased to approximately $1.04 billion during the full year of 2014 as compared to $884 million during 2013.
Our accounts receivable days outstanding decreased to 56 days during the fourth quarter of 2014 as compared to 57 days during the fourth quarter of 2013. At December 31, 2014, our ratio of debt to total capitalization was 47%.
During 2014, we opened a total of 602 new behavioral health beds, including 162 beds opened at 2 de novo hospitals and 440 beds opened at some of our busiest facilities. In addition, we already have approved projects to add approximately 550 new behavioral health beds and convert approximately 50 beds from residential treatment center to acute during 2015, and that number could grow as we continue to pursue opportunities to add and convert additional beds.
We spent $82 million on capital expenditures during the fourth quarter of 2014 and $391 million during the full year of 2014. During 2015, we expect to spend approximately $375 million to $400 million in capital expenditures, which includes expenditures for capital equipment, renovations, new projects at existing hospitals and construction of new facilities.
In conjunction with our share repurchase program that commenced during the third quarter of 2014, during the fourth quarter, we repurchased 321,500 shares of our stock at an average price of slightly less than $102 per share.
Our estimated range of adjusted net income attributable to UHS for the year ended December 31, 2015 is $6.15 to $6.55 per diluted share. The guidance range excludes the unfavorable $0.12 per diluted share of EHR expected -- EHR impact expected during 2015, as described in our press release last night. This guidance range represents an increase of approximately 6% to 13% over the adjusted net income attributable to UHS of $5.78 per diluted share for the year ended December 31, 2014, as calculated on the supplemental schedule included in last night's press release.
During 2015, our net revenues are estimated to be approximately $8.7 billion to $8.8 billion, representing an increase of approximately 8% to 9% over our 2014 net revenues . Included in our estimated 2015 net revenues are revenues associated with the previously announced acquisition of Cygnet Health Care in the U.K. and a health insurance company in Nevada.
In addition, during the fourth quarter, we acquired a 46-bed behavioral health hospital located near Taunton in the United Kingdom. 
Alan and I are pleased to answer your questions at this time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I just wanted to dig in on the 14.8% growth of the acute care same-store and maybe get a little bit better sense on the revenue per adjusted admission of 8.8%, maybe any specific markets or any other commentary that can point to that strength.
componenttext: Steve, I just wanted to dig in on the 14.8% growth of the acute care same-store and maybe get a little bit better sense on the revenue per adjusted admission of 8.8%, maybe any specific markets or any other commentary that can point to that strength.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So first of all, I mean, I think there are a couple of sort of extraordinary things in the quarter. We called out the $11 million of Texas DSRIP in the press release. We also have spoken before about $4 million of California UPL that I know some of
componenttext: Sure. So first of all, I mean, I think there are a couple of sort of extraordinary things in the quarter. We called out the $11 million of Texas DSRIP in the press release. We also have spoken before about $4 million of California UPL that I know some of our peers have recognized as well in the fourth quarter. So if you adjust those things out, it probably brings the revenue growth down by a couple of hundred basis points, still, by any measure, a very strong and robust revenue growth quarter. Our admission growth seemed to be fairly consistent with our peers who have reported similar strong volumes. What seems to distinguish the UHS performance in the quarter was that really robust revenue intensity and revenue per unit, per admission or per day. I think a lot of that, Josh, was driven by strong surgical volumes we had both in- and outpatient surgical volume growth of approximately 5%. And for the first time I can remember in a long time, the inpatient growth actually was outpacing the outpatient, so I think that's what really drove some of that revenue intensity.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And no specific markets, Steve, that jumped out?
componenttext: And no specific markets, Steve, that jumped out?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, I think honestly, Josh, when you get a performance that strong, it's got to be pretty sort of pervasive throughout the portfolio, and I think ours was.
componenttext: No, I mean, I think honestly, Josh, when you get a performance that strong, it's got to be pretty sort of pervasive throughout the portfolio, and I think ours was.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that makes sense. And then just last one on '15. Any sense of the impact of reform that you've baked into the guidance? I mean, I know there's no new sort of Medicaid expansion states, but just curious, there's got to be some anniversary-ing, et cete
componenttext: Yes, that makes sense. And then just last one on '15. Any sense of the impact of reform that you've baked into the guidance? I mean, I know there's no new sort of Medicaid expansion states, but just curious, there's got to be some anniversary-ing, et cetera. Is there a way to quantify the positive benefit in '15?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm going to preface my answer with first saying that I think as time elapses and each quarter goes by, we find it a little more challenging to be able to discreetly identify the reform impact from other sort of payer mix improvements and kind of esp
componenttext: Yes. I'm going to preface my answer with first saying that I think as time elapses and each quarter goes by, we find it a little more challenging to be able to discreetly identify the reform impact from other sort of payer mix improvements and kind of especially from sort of the general economic improvement that we've been enjoying in our markets. I will say, however, that I think our best guesstimate is that we've got -- and I think, again, this is fairly consistent with what I understand some of our peers have said, but I think in the acute care division, we assume that the ACA impact in 2015 will be about 6% to 7% of our overall earnings. And that's, I think, a little bit of an increase over 2014.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And behavioral is still sticking with same impact as you saw this year?
componenttext: Okay. And behavioral is still sticking with same impact as you saw this year?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think in behavioral, we've mentioned before that we find it difficult to discretely identify the ACA. And I'll also include in that the mental health parity impact in the behavioral division so that we have not really discretely budgeted or
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think in behavioral, we've mentioned before that we find it difficult to discretely identify the ACA. And I'll also include in that the mental health parity impact in the behavioral division so that we have not really discretely budgeted or guided for that to the degree that we enjoyed a little bit of that in '14, which, I think, is possible. We certainly sort of included that in the base and the growth of our base but have not really included, as we have in the acute care division, a specific impact for either ACA or parity.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 27, 2015
