componenttextpreview: My guess is, directionally, our experience was much like the street expectations and models in that. Clearly the biggest excess over budget expectations was in the acute division, the 12 plus-percent revenue growth, same-store revenue growth in acute divi
componenttext: My guess is, directionally, our experience was much like the street expectations and models in that. Clearly the biggest excess over budget expectations was in the acute division, the 12 plus-percent revenue growth, same-store revenue growth in acute division. It was well in excess of the 7% to 8% that we talked about having guided to in our 2015 guidance. So that was clearly the biggest element of the beat.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I know you guys don't update numbers for Q1, but any thoughts about how is coming in versus your expectations? And I'll jump off.
componenttext: Okay. And then I know you guys don't update numbers for Q1, but any thoughts about how is coming in versus your expectations? And I'll jump off.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think we may have made the point that throughout 2014 that I think the science, if you will, of identifying the discrete impact of reform was difficult in 2014. I think as we move into the second year of reform implementation, it becomes even sort
componenttext: Sure. I think we may have made the point that throughout 2014 that I think the science, if you will, of identifying the discrete impact of reform was difficult in 2014. I think as we move into the second year of reform implementation, it becomes even sort of blurry from our perspective. And I think that we estimated that about 6% to 7% of our acute care EBITDA would come from reform patients, either Medicaid expansion patients or commercial exchange patients. And I think we still believe that, that's a best guess number. And I think we ran at that rate in Q1. But again, I will sort of caveat that I think we believe it is becoming more and more difficult to precisely identify that impact. And I think it will become even more difficult as time passes.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to know if you could update us on the percentage of the business that may be related to the economic environment improving? And maybe how we should think about those trends for the rest of the year in 2015. Also if you could give us more col
componenttext: I just wanted to know if you could update us on the percentage of the business that may be related to the economic environment improving? And maybe how we should think about those trends for the rest of the year in 2015. Also if you could give us more color on maybe your larger markets and what's happening in Texas, Florida and Vegas?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paula. I think what we did, what we had said in 2014 was we attributed something like 35% to 40% of our acute care improvement to ACA related impact comparable to 35% to 40% to just economic improvement in our markets, and the remaining 15% to 20% t
componenttext: Sure, Paula. I think what we did, what we had said in 2014 was we attributed something like 35% to 40% of our acute care improvement to ACA related impact comparable to 35% to 40% to just economic improvement in our markets, and the remaining 15% to 20% to kind of discrete market share improvements, et cetera, in our individual markets. Again, it strikes me that those percentages are probably still reasonably accurate in 2015 in terms of sort of geographically how the quarter looked. We had a very, very strong quarter in our Las Vegas market. Volumes are very strong in the Las Vegas market. We continue to see a full quarter's worth of benefit of the Medicaid expansion in Nevada, which is a Medicaid expansion state obviously. And so just real strong results in the Las Vegas market in Q1. Additionally, a very nice swing between years in our Temecula facility. I'll remind people that our Temecula was a start up in the first quarter of 2014. So it is ramping up quite nicely. And while I think a lot of that ramp is reflected in our guidance, it does provide a real nice tailwind year-to-year. So those are the 2 markets I would highlight. Obviously, I think when you posed a solid and as robust quarter as we did, you're going to have strong results pretty much through the portfolio that we did but at least I'd highlight those 2 markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And do you think some of those strength is sustainable throughout the year? I mean you talked about the 7% to 8% increase. We had a 12% sort of with that, given the difficult comparison that we might see some softness as you go through? Or is it too soon
componenttext: And do you think some of those strength is sustainable throughout the year? I mean you talked about the 7% to 8% increase. We had a 12% sort of with that, given the difficult comparison that we might see some softness as you go through? Or is it too soon to tell?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think part of the reason why we made no change to guidance is that I think after one quarter, we think that it's generally premature to make changes to the outlook. We certainly feel like the core strength that both business segments demonstrated
componenttext: Well, I think part of the reason why we made no change to guidance is that I think after one quarter, we think that it's generally premature to make changes to the outlook. We certainly feel like the core strength that both business segments demonstrated in Q1 is largely sustainable. I mean, that 12 plus-percent same store revenue growth in the acute division, particularly as the year progresses and the comparisons become more difficult and the volume comparisons particularly become more difficult, I think it will be difficult to sustain. But I think the core directional trends that are very strong in the 2 businesses, we certainly believe, should be sustainable.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for that color. And I just wanted to know, what do you actually view the strength in the revenue or the pricing for adjusted name is there anything particular you can call out for us in the quarter in terms of pricing or pair mix shift?
componenttext: Thank you for that color. And I just wanted to know, what do you actually view the strength in the revenue or the pricing for adjusted name is there anything particular you can call out for us in the quarter in terms of pricing or pair mix shift?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that's a continuation of some of that trend we called out in the fourth quarter. We talked about it in Q4, very strong surgical volume strength. We saw those same trends in Q1. I highlighted in Q4 the fact that I think for the first time, at least
componenttext: I think that's a continuation of some of that trend we called out in the fourth quarter. We talked about it in Q4, very strong surgical volume strength. We saw those same trends in Q1. I highlighted in Q4 the fact that I think for the first time, at least in recent memory, our inpatient surgical growth rate was higher than our outpatient. We saw that same dynamic continue into Q1. So that's certainly driving a lot of the sort of acuity element of the revenue improvement. And then secondly, we just have that continued the payer mix improvement. We anticipated that 2015 would benefit from a full year of that enrollment that we saw occur, sort of incrementally throughout 2014. And I think Q1 was a reflection of that, and again particularly in places like Las Vegas, which had huge Medicaid expansion growth in '14. And you're seeing that play out in a full quarter in the first quarter of 2015.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of a A.J. Rice from UBS.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of a A.J. Rice from UBS.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, obviously, you had good cash flow quarter as well, as operating quarter. But you didn't do too much in the buyback mode. Is that indicative of you seeing an uptick in dealer activity? Or any thoughts about the buyback going forward?
componenttext: First, obviously, you had good cash flow quarter as well, as operating quarter. But you didn't do too much in the buyback mode. Is that indicative of you seeing an uptick in dealer activity? Or any thoughts about the buyback going forward?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the first quarter is a little different for us in the sense that we spent most of the first quarter in a quiet period. So most of the buyback during the first quarter is done, in our case, under a 10b5 preplanned repurchase that we established some pri
componenttext: So the first quarter is a little different for us in the sense that we spent most of the first quarter in a quiet period. So most of the buyback during the first quarter is done, in our case, under a 10b5 preplanned repurchase that we established some price parameters around. And sometimes we miss those estimates, some. So I think I wouldn't read the relatively modest repurchases in Q1 to be terribly meaningful in any regard. I'll repeat what we've said over the last few [ph] quarters since the buyback authorization in Q2 of 2014 was approved by the board, and that is we anticipate we're going to generate a significant amount of free cash. We're not really anxious to see our leverage levels go any lower than we were, when we established the share buyback. And while we continue to explore opportunities in the M&A space in both of the business segments, I think we feel comfortable we have the room to do most sized deals as well as share repurchases as well as continuing CapEx at the current levels. So we're very comfortable that we can accomplish all those things and still maintain what in our minds is a comfortable leverage level.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I might also just ask you because we get asked a lot about it. A couple of weeks ago, you filed another 8-K indicating some additional request for information in the behavioral business. Broadly, I'll just throw out on the table. Is there anythi
componenttext: Okay. And I might also just ask you because we get asked a lot about it. A couple of weeks ago, you filed another 8-K indicating some additional request for information in the behavioral business. Broadly, I'll just throw out on the table. Is there anything that can be said about what's happening behind the scenes there? And then I would also throw it out in terms of the operating performance, looking at the behavioral business from a high level, it doesn't look like those inquiries are having any impact, at least in aggregate, on the business. Is that your assessment of it, or anything we should be aware of?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the investigation has been ongoing now for a little over 2 years, AJ. We take it very seriously. We have cooperated fully with the government and have responded to all their requests and continue to respond to any new and incremental request that they
componenttext: So the investigation has been ongoing now for a little over 2 years, AJ. We take it very seriously. We have cooperated fully with the government and have responded to all their requests and continue to respond to any new and incremental request that they make. But I think your observation is a fair one, in a sense that we continue to operate our business, consistent with what we believe are our highest standards and continue to do so. I think unfortunately, those who follow the industry know that these investigations can be a long process. It certainly has been long already, but I also don't believe it's necessarily in its end stages. It may go on for a while. And while it does, we'll continue to take it seriously and comply with the government and cooperate with the government. But at the same time, we are going to continue to run the business, which we feel delivers high-quality care throughout the portfolio.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just maybe I'll slip in a last technical question. The California provider fee, I think you were not accruing in previously managed care proportion. Did you accrue anything this quarter? And what might that be if it ever comes to fruition f
componenttext: Okay. And then just maybe I'll slip in a last technical question. The California provider fee, I think you were not accruing in previously managed care proportion. Did you accrue anything this quarter? And what might that be if it ever comes to fruition for you?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we did not recognize any incremental California UPL revenue in the quarter. And I think if it were to be approved, it's probably another, in my recollection, AJ, is another set of $5 million, $6 million. It's not a huge number.
componenttext: So we did not recognize any incremental California UPL revenue in the quarter. And I think if it were to be approved, it's probably another, in my recollection, AJ, is another set of $5 million, $6 million. It's not a huge number.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Ralph Giacobbe with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Ralph Giacobbe with Credit Suisse.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to jump on the behavioral side. Do you think there's any help for mental health parity in the quarter? Anyway to discern that? I know we talked about the quarter, any more visibility or optimism around the length-of-stay challenges?
componenttext: Just wanted to jump on the behavioral side. Do you think there's any help for mental health parity in the quarter? Anyway to discern that? I know we talked about the quarter, any more visibility or optimism around the length-of-stay challenges?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ralph. I think on the length of stay issue, we continue to see length of stay decline. Although, I'll repeat a comment that I made in the fourth quarter, and I think it continued into Q1, and that is that at least some of that length of stay decline
componenttext: Sure, Ralph. I think on the length of stay issue, we continue to see length of stay decline. Although, I'll repeat a comment that I made in the fourth quarter, and I think it continued into Q1, and that is that at least some of that length of stay decline, at least in the last few [ph] quarters, is self-imposed or self-manufactured in the sense that we continue to convert residential beds and residential services to acute beds and acute services. And when we do that, we are by definition lowering our length of stay because acute services length of stay is markedly lower than the residential length of stay is. So at least some element of the length of stay decline is intentional. And quite frankly, I think in our minds a positive development, in that we're replacing higher revenue beds with lower revenue beds. And I think that's partly what you see in the strong revenue growth, that seems a revenue growth of 6 plus-percent, which is clearly at the high end of our own expectations. As far as being able to identify the effect from parity, I think we always believe that it will be difficult to do. And I think we still believe that almost well not impossible to do. And that's because when we see a patient who has valid and legitimate insurance, we really don't sort of know the history of that insurance, to what degree benefit plan design has changed et cetera. I think the insurance company, the government might have better insight into that. What we are very focused on as a company and I think as an industry, is in making sure that, that parity rules and regulations, including some of the newer ones and some of the clarifications are being properly enforced, because I think we believe that there still are plans and that there's still executions of the plans that are not compliant and therefore, that there is sort of upside to us if we can ensure that, that compliance is met throughout the country.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. Where are you, I guess, in the process of converting beds? Is there a timeline to where you are at this point? Or is it just ongoing?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. Where are you, I guess, in the process of converting beds? Is there a timeline to where you are at this point? Or is it just ongoing?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know if there's a finite sort of process, Rob, where we have X number of beds that we want to convert. I think it's an issue of we're always looking at the best and highest use of all of our beds. And to the degree that beds become sort of underpe
componenttext: I don't know if there's a finite sort of process, Rob, where we have X number of beds that we want to convert. I think it's an issue of we're always looking at the best and highest use of all of our beds. And to the degree that beds become sort of underperforming because rates go down or length of stay is under great pressure, whatever it may be. And if the demand is there for another bed or performing service, we're willing to convert those beds. So I don't know that you would sort of put it in the context, but we're done with 50% of our conversions. I think for us it's just sort of an ongoing process and will remain so.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. One more if I can. SWV came in a lot better. Is there anything more than just leveraging the top line? Or are there specific initiatives there that help? And I guess more on a go-forward basis, can you help us in terms of what a fair range, I
componenttext: Fair enough. One more if I can. SWV came in a lot better. Is there anything more than just leveraging the top line? Or are there specific initiatives there that help? And I guess more on a go-forward basis, can you help us in terms of what a fair range, I'm thinking about that line item as a percentage of revenue, particularly consider your commentary around the topline growth growth that we've seen in the quarter?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think salaries and wages are obviously the single biggest expense item in both of our divisions and get a lot of attention from the operators. But the nature of the business such when you have really strong revenue growth that we had in Q1, you are like
componenttext: I think salaries and wages are obviously the single biggest expense item in both of our divisions and get a lot of attention from the operators. But the nature of the business such when you have really strong revenue growth that we had in Q1, you are likely to see a significant amount of operating leverage. We did see that particularly in the acute division in Q1. If that revenue run rate does start to sort of modestly progress as I suggest before that it might from the 12 plus-percent that we ran in Q1, it might be a little bit challenging to generate quite as much leverage as we did. But our operators are very focused on controlling those salary numbers and delivering the efficient and high-quality products, so I think they will continue to remain focused that way.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Frank Morgan with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Frank Morgan with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess hopping back on the discussion on parity. I know CMS recently put out a proposal to manage Medicaid and shield. I'm curious how much of an impact that may have? Is it in that direction at the stored striking value in the exclusion?
componenttext: I guess hopping back on the discussion on parity. I know CMS recently put out a proposal to manage Medicaid and shield. I'm curious how much of an impact that may have? Is it in that direction at the stored striking value in the exclusion?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so, Frank, I think you get to the point I think as most of the people listening know that the IND exclusion precludes freestanding behavioral facilities from treating or from being paid at least for adult Medicaid patients. And that's a big hurdle fr
componenttext: Yes, so, Frank, I think you get to the point I think as most of the people listening know that the IND exclusion precludes freestanding behavioral facilities from treating or from being paid at least for adult Medicaid patients. And that's a big hurdle from our perspective. The recent parity clarifications that you mentioned I think are helpful for the nonadult population, the Medicaid population that's under age 21. And I think what it says is that managed care or Medicaid managed care organizations and other like organizations have to comply with parity as to our case, that under 21 population. So I think it's helpful not in a sort of a game changing way, but it's definitely helpful around the edges if you will. We are hopeful and continue to work as an industry for a more rational sort of approach to the IND exclusion. And that means I think we continue to lobby CMS and cooperate with their data-gathering activities to try and demonstrate that lifting the IND exclusion would be the correct thing to do for a public policy perspective. And we also continue to work on the legislative end of it, working with Congressman, working with legislators like Congressman Murphy who has a Bill out there that would eliminate the IND exclusion. So we're working on a number of fronts. I think, that lifting the IND exclusion would be a game changer. I think the continued modifications to the parity law and the parity rules are helpful, but the sort of end goal would be the lifting of the IND exclusion.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: One more. You mentioned good raw based performance across most of your markets. But I guess, is there anywhere you see upside maybe on a relative basis some markets underperforming on the upside? And I think you got hospital leasing works in Vegas. Can yo
componenttext: One more. You mentioned good raw based performance across most of your markets. But I guess, is there anywhere you see upside maybe on a relative basis some markets underperforming on the upside? And I think you got hospital leasing works in Vegas. Can you give us any comment there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, look, I think what you're seeing and we talked about this for years. And I think during the several years of the recession beginning in 2009 for us as a company I think as an industry and extending well through 2013, we had sort of multiyear p
componenttext: Sure. Well, look, I think what you're seeing and we talked about this for years. And I think during the several years of the recession beginning in 2009 for us as a company I think as an industry and extending well through 2013, we had sort of multiyear pressure from the recession, from uncompensated care, et cetera, which put a burden on our volumes. Our volumes were rather muted during that period. And our uncompensated care level just grew throughout that period. And then beginning in 2014, with the benefits of the Affordable Care Act providing insurance to millions of people who didn't have it before, as well as the improving economy, allowing people to go back to work and get reinsured, all that has been helpful in our market. I think because the decline was a multiyear decline, we always anticipated that the recovery would be a multiyear recovery. And we're certainly seeing that, where I would suggest either the second or the third year of the recovery in Las Vegas and the second year of recovery in a number of our other markets. So while -- I'm not sure that we feel like we can sustain these Q1 levels of growth. I think we're comfortable that again the course of the recovery that's taking place is something that should last for a number of years.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Whit Mayo from Robert Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Whit Mayo from Robert Baird.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I know this exercise can be a little dangerous and you can cut it a few different ways. But looking back historically, you've earned roughly 30% of your.
componenttext: I know this exercise can be a little dangerous and you can cut it a few different ways. But looking back historically, you've earned roughly 30% of your.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] Please.
componenttext: [indiscernible] Please.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you hear me? Looking back historically, you guys have earned 30% of acute care EBITDA in the first quarter and on some modest site performance for the rest of the year. I think I can easily get near the high end of the range. Is it may be fair to thin
componenttext: Can you hear me? Looking back historically, you guys have earned 30% of acute care EBITDA in the first quarter and on some modest site performance for the rest of the year. I think I can easily get near the high end of the range. Is it may be fair to think about given the outperformance in the first quarter that you could be tracking closer to the high end and maybe to the midpoint at this time?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, I think although you describe it as dangerous, if you do the math, I think unless there's a real change in the operating landscape or unanticipated hurdles in either of the core businesses, we should be comfortably moving towards the high en
componenttext: Sure. I mean, I think although you describe it as dangerous, if you do the math, I think unless there's a real change in the operating landscape or unanticipated hurdles in either of the core businesses, we should be comfortably moving towards the high end of our existing range. I think again for all the reasons that we cited before, we just felt it was not terribly prudent to tinker with the range. And we'll take kind of a closer look and a more measured look at it at the end of the second quarter. But certainly, I think if you do the math, it's not at all unreasonable to make the observation that we are headed for the higher end of the range.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it seems appropriate. And maybe, just on cost trends for a second. Is there anything new that you're paying attention to in either segment right now? Any increase in registry cost that you're seeing in the acute care portfolio? And you leveraged suppl
componenttext: No, it seems appropriate. And maybe, just on cost trends for a second. Is there anything new that you're paying attention to in either segment right now? Any increase in registry cost that you're seeing in the acute care portfolio? And you leveraged supplies maybe a little bit more given the strength of the surgical performance in the quarter? And specialty pharma has gotten a lot of attention lately. I'm trying to wrap my head around the cost trends and what you're seeing and what initiatives you have under way?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, I think again, as a company and as an industry, we really did a significant amount of belt-tightening and kind of real structural reviews of our cost structure during those years of the recession when our revenues were really challenged. And I
componenttext: Yes. Look, I think again, as a company and as an industry, we really did a significant amount of belt-tightening and kind of real structural reviews of our cost structure during those years of the recession when our revenues were really challenged. And I think that left us in a very good position beginning in 2014 when the trends -- the revenue trends reversed themselves and revenue growth began anew earnestly. And as a consequence, we've seen these pretty robust expansion of margins, particularly on the acute side of the business. I think from a cost perspective, you cited the things that we're certainly concerned about. As volumes grow, there is pressure on wages. We see that in higher over time and higher use of temporary nurses. We see it to some degree in pressures, in terms of placing doctors. We've seen quite a bit of pressure frankly on the behavioral side and finding adequate number of psychiatrists in all of our facilities and that's put some pressure on use of physicians and that sort of thing. But as I think we step back and look at it, I don't know that there's anything on sort of the cost landscape that we would describe our think about as a huge discrete drag. Rather, it's always the challenge that as the business grows, you want to just make sure that you remain efficient. And I think our operators have been doing that for the last 1.5 [ph] year or so and have been doing a very good job of that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I might sneak just one quick one and look for an update on Cignet and just the updated performance of that asset.
componenttext: I might sneak just one quick one and look for an update on Cignet and just the updated performance of that asset.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. The behavioral company that we bought in the U.K. at the end of September was running at a very healthy occupancy levels, probably close to 80% when we bought them. We didn't really believe there was a huge amount of upside opportunity in the existi
componenttext: Sure. The behavioral company that we bought in the U.K. at the end of September was running at a very healthy occupancy levels, probably close to 80% when we bought them. We didn't really believe there was a huge amount of upside opportunity in the existing business. But we're happy to say that even on the core business, occupancy rates have risen in the 6 months we've owned them and are getting close to 90%. And that obviously is generating better than expected results for that business. And at the same time, we announced a small acquisition in our first 6 months of ownership, where we started a development project in our first 6 months of ownership and we continue to look at a whole series of other opportunities, both sort of large and small. So where we couldn't frankly be more pleased with that platform in the 6 months that we've owned it than we are.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Joshua Raskin of Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Joshua Raskin of Barclays.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question just on what we're seeing in terms of providers and health plan collaborations and whether that means just sort of capitation or even planned sponsor or sponsored, provider sponsored health plans. Just curious what your perspective if you g
componenttext: First question just on what we're seeing in terms of providers and health plan collaborations and whether that means just sort of capitation or even planned sponsor or sponsored, provider sponsored health plans. Just curious what your perspective if you guys have any pilots going on in any year? I'm thinking of the 24 acute care hospitals, what your thoughts are on the future of that?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Josh, we certainly share the view that over the long-term, the reimbursement or payment landscape in acute care will change from a fee-for-service, the traditional fee-for-service reimbursement to some sort of fee-for-value reimbursement that will include
componenttext: Josh, we certainly share the view that over the long-term, the reimbursement or payment landscape in acute care will change from a fee-for-service, the traditional fee-for-service reimbursement to some sort of fee-for-value reimbursement that will include things like bundled payments or accountable care organizations and ultimately gets to the end of the continuum, which is side of the capitation model and the risk, sort of pure risk model that I think you're referencing. I think we believe that, that process is definitely an evolutionary process. It is one that will take multiple years. Honestly, in the vast majority of our reimbursement remains fee-for-service reimbursement, although in some cases like in Medicare, there are quality components and elements of that, but it's still largely remains fee-for-service reimbursement. What we're doing are a number of things, both in terms of our relationship with our physicians and really trying to integrate with our physicians, particularly on the information technology side, to prepare for that move through kind of a more of a risk shifting environment with bundled payment and capitation, et cetera. We've talked, I think at some length, over the last few [ph] quarters over some other initiatives running the purchase in the middle of last year of health insurance company in Nevada to better prepare us again for that sort of risk-taking to allow us in certain selected markets and with certain selected products to go out there and have a provider sponsor product in certain of our markets. So we're trying to move at just the right pace in our markets. Not trying to get ahead of the curve, but also absolutely ensuring that we are nowhere behind the curve in terms of these changes that we know are coming in certainly the acute care space.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So is that pace being driven more by the payers and you're sort of a acting through are trying to accommodate those changes as opposed that the UHS driven? I'm just trying to think do you think ultimately, this is good or bad?
componenttext: So is that pace being driven more by the payers and you're sort of a acting through are trying to accommodate those changes as opposed that the UHS driven? I'm just trying to think do you think ultimately, this is good or bad?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know that we would have a value judgment about it. I think what we would say that it is inevitable. I think that payers and I think public policymakers have determined that the real -- ultimately they relate to control costs in the health care spa
componenttext: I don't know that we would have a value judgment about it. I think what we would say that it is inevitable. I think that payers and I think public policymakers have determined that the real -- ultimately they relate to control costs in the health care space is by a shift of risk from the consumer and the employer and the payer to -- excuse me, from the employer and the payer to the consumer and the provider. And so I think we're going there. It's not necessarily I think on the service a good or bad thing. I think it's a good thing if you can react nimbly and flexibly to the changes. And I think we're prepared to do that. So you can be the one to have and put together a large network in our markets and deliver high-quality low-cost care, efficient care in the markets, then I think it will be a good thing and I think we believe we're well positioned to do that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Shifting profits, one last one for me. Just on the behavioral health hospitals, think about the M&A pipeline, we haven't seen outside of activity domestically so U.K. Any updates our thoughts on maybe just on the commentary around lack of buybacks in the
componenttext: Shifting profits, one last one for me. Just on the behavioral health hospitals, think about the M&A pipeline, we haven't seen outside of activity domestically so U.K. Any updates our thoughts on maybe just on the commentary around lack of buybacks in the first quarter? How should we think about the site hospital, M&A pipeline?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look I think the behavior business is characterize at the moment by a lot of strong results. Certainly, our results are reflective of the underlying strength in this business. So as a result, I think most of the larger -- and we're far and away the l
componenttext: Yes. Look I think the behavior business is characterize at the moment by a lot of strong results. Certainly, our results are reflective of the underlying strength in this business. So as a result, I think most of the larger -- and we're far and away the largest, but most of the larger consolidated providers are right now in growth mode as opposed to in a sale mode or in a divestiture mode. So we're competing for assets with a number of other providers. I do think there still are a lot of other providers out there to be acquired. I also think we have talked a number of times about the opportunity for 50% of beds or so, half the day of admissions in the behavior business that are currently service did in the acute care hospitals, so that's behavioral that's within acute care hospitals. Some of the growth for instance of beds that I mentioned in the my opening remarks, are beds at acute care hospitals, nonaffiliated acute care hospitals that we have opened in connection with newly sort of formed partnerships with acute care hospitals and we still think that a significant opportunity in the future. Now to be fair, those opportunities are relatively bite-size. We will get 30 beds at a time, or 50 or 70 beds at that time. We're not going to get thousands of thousands of beds at a single stroke. But the ultimate opportunity I think is enormous, and I think that's far and away the largest provider of freestanding behavioral services in the country. I think we're very well positioned to take advantage of that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the opportunity in the U.K. broadly is sort of a twofold opportunity. One is that the overall demand for private psychiatric beds is going to continue to grow as the National Health Service continues to trend towards outsourcing more of
componenttext: Well, I think that the opportunity in the U.K. broadly is sort of a twofold opportunity. One is that the overall demand for private psychiatric beds is going to continue to grow as the National Health Service continues to trend towards outsourcing more of that business and deciding that they're going to spend their capital on investments other than behavioral investments. And I think we have a lot of the new incremental capital to be invested in the behavior industry through the private sector. At the same time, the market, much like it is here in the U.S. remains fragmented. And as a consequence, there are M&A opportunities. And we're pursuing those. And also due on the same things we're doing in the U.S., which I think you alluded to in your question where we're learning as I said in response to a previous question at very high occupancy rates that we're looking to add invest in our facilities here in the U.S. We're looking at greenfield, de novo projects and we'll continue to do all those things.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015

componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Chris Rigg with Susquehanna Financial.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to keep going with the M&A here for another minute. I know you guys of talked about in the past the potential -- the appetite for sort of larger nonprofit deals. And I guess I'd love to get your view. We're seeing very strong results from th
componenttext: I just wanted to keep going with the M&A here for another minute. I know you guys of talked about in the past the potential -- the appetite for sort of larger nonprofit deals. And I guess I'd love to get your view. We're seeing very strong results from the publicly traded change. Are the results you're seeing from you guys is sort of an illusion to what's going on amongst the sort of nonpublic guys? Or do you think the dynamic is actually changed materially because of the ACA and that's a setback to sort of near-term, larger nonprofit deals?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, Chris, I'm not sure that I'm the foremost expert on the subject. But I think if you look the not-for-profit financial data that is out there in any sort of consolidated way, I think probably the best data comes from the rating agencies. And I thin
componenttext: I mean, Chris, I'm not sure that I'm the foremost expert on the subject. But I think if you look the not-for-profit financial data that is out there in any sort of consolidated way, I think probably the best data comes from the rating agencies. And I think that their data suggests that the not-for-profit results, financial results, have not improved at this a bit over the last year, 1.5 year as the for profit results have. And so I think you'll still find a number of not-for-profit acute hospitals that find themselves financially challenged in a variety of ways. I think also, going back to Josh Raskin's question, I think a lot of not-for-profit hospitals look at the landscape of changing reimbursement and the challenges that presents, and the need to be in a large network and find that they may not be able to check all the boxes. And I think they're looking for either partners or they're looking for some sort of sale arrangement that allows them to be sort of be better positioned to move forward in the future. So we're talking with a number of not-for-profit about those sorts of opportunities. I think those sorts of opportunities are going to be there in the next few [ph] years. It's difficult to predict how and what rathe they will develop. All we can do is respond to them as they develop. But we're certainly ready to do so. We certainly have the financial flexibility to do so.

componenttext: Steve, I think you said that a little bit about last Vegas and I apologize if I missed any more color. But as you're looking at the various strong geographies of the business, Medicaid expanding states, non-Medicaid expanding states, and then Vegas which is I don't know you said is in a third year of economic recovery, Texas which has had a recovery. But is this going to a bit of a state of layoff and so on? How is the payer mix to the extent of your visibility differing from one core markets versus another?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the trends have been directionally the same over the last 1.5 year and that we certainly have seen a decline in uninsured patients and an increase in insured patients, mostly in Medicaid and commercial exchange patients. Those, the percentages and
componenttext: I think the trends have been directionally the same over the last 1.5 year and that we certainly have seen a decline in uninsured patients and an increase in insured patients, mostly in Medicaid and commercial exchange patients. Those, the percentages and the magnitude of that change differs a little bit from market-to-market. And it's a little challenging as I've suggested at the outset of the call, to kind of discretely identify to what degree those changes, those payer mix changes are being driven by the ACA and to what degree they're being driven by economic improvement or other factors. But I think our view is, as I said in an earlier response, that those trends, the ACA implementation, will continue this year and probably for at least one more year. And I think the economic improvement will likely continue. And then there are individual market efforts, which I think are also driving some of this improvement, and I think have been very successful. And I think in our minds, those results will be sustainable as well.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015

componenttext: Do you have any real-time visibility into the Texas just on recognizing your exposure to the oil heavy economy that's been limited than your peers about, working Americans in Texas that might use more care for surgeries because of layoffs, is any of that visible at all in the first quarter?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's worth noting that while we are in a number of markets in Texas, we're really not in any markets that are heavily dependent on the oil and gas industry. And I don't think we're therefore, directly impacted by any of the softness in that sector
componenttext: I think it's worth noting that while we are in a number of markets in Texas, we're really not in any markets that are heavily dependent on the oil and gas industry. And I don't think we're therefore, directly impacted by any of the softness in that sector of the economy. To be fair, while we continue to watch it closely, I don't think we're seeing pressure on either volumes or payer mix currently in our markets in Texas. Frankly, I think one of our broader concerns is that if there really is a squeeze on the Texas economy and it gets impacted at the state budget level, we are a big Medicaid provider in Texas, both in terms of traditional Medicaid reimbursement as well as some of the special programs like the share and UBL. That's the sort of thing we keep a close eye on. But to be fair, we're not we've seen impact from softer Texas economy in our markets as of this moment.

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Kelly, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Universal Health Services First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Filton, you may begin your conference.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the first quarter ended March 31, 2015. During the conference call, Alan and I will be using words such a
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the first quarter ended March 31, 2015. 
During the conference call, Alan and I will be using words such as believes, expects, anticipates, estimates and similar words that represent forecasts, projections and forward-looking statements.  For anyone not familiar with the risks and uncertainties inherent in these forward-looking statements, I recommend the careful reading of the section on risk factors and forward-looking statements and risk factors in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014. 
We would like to highlight just a couple of developments and business trends before opening the call up to questions.
As discussed in our press release last night, the company recorded -- reported net income attributable to UHS per diluted share of $1.73 for the quarter. After adjusting for the depreciation and amortization expense associated with the implementation of electronic health records applications at our acute care hospitals, our adjusted net income attributable to UHS per diluted share was $1.78 for the quarter ended March 31, 2015. 
On a same-facility basis in our acute care division, revenues increased 12.2% during the first quarter of 2015. The increase resulted primarily from a 5.7% increase in adjusted admissions and a 6.1% increase in revenue per adjusted admission. On a same-facility basis, operating margins for our acute care hospitals increased to 21.6% during the first quarter of 2015 from 19.2% during the first quarter of 2014.
On a same-facility basis, revenues in our behavioral health division increased 6.3% during the first quarter of 2015. Adjusted admissions to our behavioral health facilities owned for more than a year increased 6.0%, and adjusted patient days increased 2.6% over the prior year first quarter. Revenue per adjusted patient day rose 3.7% during the first quarter of 2015 over the comparable prior year quarter. On a same-facility basis, operating margins for our behavioral health division increased to 28.6% during the quarter ended March 31, 2015, as compared to 27.7% during the comparable prior year period.
Our cash provided by operating activities increased 39% to approximately $271 million during the first quarter of 2015 as compared to $195 million in the first quarter of 2014. 
Our accounts receivable days outstanding remained at 56 days during comparable first quarters of 2015 and 2014.
Our ratio of debt to total capitalization decreased to 44.6% at March 31, 2015, as compared to 48.6% at March 31, 2014.
During the first quarter of 2015, we spent $89 million on capital expenditures. During the quarter, we completed construction and opened 54 new beds in our acute care division and 148 new behavioral health beds at some of our busiest behavioral facilities. 
Alan and I will be pleased to answer your questions at this time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
