headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess the market oftentimes has a hard time getting your numbers right on a quarter-to-quarter basis. How would you characterize this quarter versus your internal expectations? It seemed like a pretty strong quarter on our side.
componenttext: I guess the market oftentimes has a hard time getting your numbers right on a quarter-to-quarter basis. How would you characterize this quarter versus your internal expectations? It seemed like a pretty strong quarter on our side.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Kevin. We certainly would share that view that this was a strong quarter. I would note that our internal expectations for the quarter were somewhat higher than the Street's, maybe by $0.07 or $0.08. So we didn't have quite as much of an internal bea
componenttext: Sure, Kevin. We certainly would share that view that this was a strong quarter. I would note that our internal expectations for the quarter were somewhat higher than the Street's, maybe by $0.07 or $0.08. So we didn't have quite as much of an internal beat, but still a very nice beat in the quarter. But it's also part of the reason why we chose not to revise our guidance at this point.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. If there's anything that you could point to that kind of -- versus your internal budget where numbers came in a little bit stronger?
componenttext: Okay. If there's anything that you could point to that kind of -- versus your internal budget where numbers came in a little bit stronger?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: My guess is, directionally, our experience was much like the Street expectations and models in that, clearly, the biggest excess over budget or expectations was in the acute division. The 12-plus percent revenue growth, same-store revenue growth, in the a
componenttext: My guess is, directionally, our experience was much like the Street expectations and models in that, clearly, the biggest excess over budget or expectations was in the acute division. The 12-plus percent revenue growth, same-store revenue growth, in the acute division was well in excess of the 7% to 8% that we talked about having guided to in our 2015 guidance. So that was clearly the biggest element of the beat.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I know that you guys usually don't update numbers with Q1, but any thoughts about how reform is coming in versus your expectations, and I'll jump off.
componenttext: Okay. And then I know that you guys usually don't update numbers with Q1, but any thoughts about how reform is coming in versus your expectations, and I'll jump off.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Look, I think we've made the point throughout 2014 that, I think, the science, if you will, of identifying the discrete impact of reform was difficult in 2014. I think as we move into the second year of reform implementation, it becomes even sort of
componenttext: Sure. Look, I think we've made the point throughout 2014 that, I think, the science, if you will, of identifying the discrete impact of reform was difficult in 2014. I think as we move into the second year of reform implementation, it becomes even sort of more blurry from our perspective. I think that we estimated that about 6% to 7% of our acute care EBITDA would come from reform patients, either Medicaid expansion patients or commercial exchange patients, and I think we still believe that, that's a best guess number and I think we ran at that rate in Q1. But again, I will sort of caveat that, I think, we believe it is becoming more and more difficult to precisely identify that impact and I think it will become even more difficult as time passes.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to know if you could update us on the percentage of the business that may be related to the economic environment improving and maybe how we should think about those trends for the rest of the year in 2015. And also if you could give us more co
componenttext: Just wanted to know if you could update us on the percentage of the business that may be related to the economic environment improving and maybe how we should think about those trends for the rest of the year in 2015. And also if you could give us more color on maybe your larger markets and what's happening in Texas, Florida and Vegas?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paula. I think what we did -- what we had said in 2014 was we attributed something like 35% to 40% of our acute care improvement to ACA-related impact, a comparable amount in those 35% to 40% to just the economic improvement in our markets and then
componenttext: Sure, Paula. I think what we did -- what we had said in 2014 was we attributed something like 35% to 40% of our acute care improvement to ACA-related impact, a comparable amount in those 35% to 40% to just the economic improvement in our markets and then the remaining 15% to 20% to kind of discrete market share improvements, et cetera, in our individual markets. Again, it strikes me that those percentages are probably still reasonably accurate in 2015 in terms of sort of geographically how the quarter looked. We had a very, very strong quarter in our Las Vegas market. Volumes were very strong in the Las Vegas market. We continued to see a full quarter's worth of benefit of the Medicaid expansion in Nevada, which is a Medicaid expansion state obviously, and so just real strong results in the Las Vegas market in Q1. Additionally, a very nice swing between years in our Temecula facility. I'll remind people that our Temecula was a start-up in the first quarter of 2014, so it is ramping up quite nicely. And while I think a lot of that ramp is reflected in our guidance, it does provide a real nice tailwind year-to-year. So those are the 2 markets I would highlight. Obviously, I think when you post a solid and as robust a quarter as we did, you're going to have strong results pretty much through the portfolio and we did, but at least I'd highlight those 2 markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And do you think that some of this strength is sustainable throughout the year? I mean, you talked about the 7% to 8% increase. We had a 12%, so would that mean that just given the difficult compares that we might see some softness sort of as we go throug
componenttext: And do you think that some of this strength is sustainable throughout the year? I mean, you talked about the 7% to 8% increase. We had a 12%, so would that mean that just given the difficult compares that we might see some softness sort of as we go through? Or it's just too soon to tell?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think part of the reason why we made no change to guidance is that, I think, after one quarter, we think it's generally premature to make changes to the outlook. We certainly feel like the core strength that both business segments demonstrated in
componenttext: Well, I think part of the reason why we made no change to guidance is that, I think, after one quarter, we think it's generally premature to make changes to the outlook. We certainly feel like the core strength that both business segments demonstrated in Q1 is largely sustainable. I mean, that 12-plus percent same-store revenue growth in the acute division, particularly as the year progresses and the comparisons become more difficult and the volume comparisons, in particular, become more difficult, I think it will be difficult to sustain. But I think the core directional trends that are very strong in the 2 businesses we certainly believe should be sustainable.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I just wanted to know what do you attribute the strength in the revenue or the pricing for adjusted admit to? Is there anything in particular that you can call out for us that happened during the quarter in terms of pricing or payer mix s
componenttext: Okay, great. And I just wanted to know what do you attribute the strength in the revenue or the pricing for adjusted admit to? Is there anything in particular that you can call out for us that happened during the quarter in terms of pricing or payer mix shift?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's a continuation of some of the trends that we called out in the fourth quarter. We talked about it in Q4 very strong surgical volume strength. We saw those same trends in Q1. I highlighted in Q4 the fact that, I think, for the first time,
componenttext: Yes, I think it's a continuation of some of the trends that we called out in the fourth quarter. We talked about it in Q4 very strong surgical volume strength. We saw those same trends in Q1. I highlighted in Q4 the fact that, I think, for the first time, at least in recent memory, our inpatient surgical growth rate was higher than our outpatient and we saw that same dynamic continue into Q1. So that's certainly driving a lot of the sort of acuity element of the revenue improvement. And then secondly, we just have that continued payer mix improvement. We anticipated that 2015 would benefit from a full year of that enrollment that we saw occur sort of incrementally throughout 2014 and I think Q1 was a reflection of that, and again, particularly in places like Las Vegas, which had huge Medicaid expansion growth in '14. And you're seeing that play out in a full quarter in the first quarter 2015.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of A.J. Rice with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of A.J. Rice with UBS.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, obviously, you had good cash flow quarter as well as operating quarter, but you didn't do too much in the buyback mode. Is that indicative of you're seeing an uptick in deal activity? Or any thoughts about the buyback going forward.
componenttext: First, obviously, you had good cash flow quarter as well as operating quarter, but you didn't do too much in the buyback mode. Is that indicative of you're seeing an uptick in deal activity? Or any thoughts about the buyback going forward.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the first quarter is a little different for us and have been for most in the sense that we spent most of the first quarter in a quiet period, so most of the buyback during the first quarter is done, in our case, under a 10b-5 preplanned repurchase that
componenttext: So the first quarter is a little different for us and have been for most in the sense that we spent most of the first quarter in a quiet period, so most of the buyback during the first quarter is done, in our case, under a 10b-5 preplanned repurchase that we established some price parameters around and sometimes we miss those estimates, so -- some. So I think I wouldn't read the relatively modest repurchases in Q1 to be terribly meaningful in any regard. I'll repeat what we've said in the last few quarters since the buyback authorization in Q2 of 2014 was approved by the board, and that is we anticipate we're going to generate a significant amount of free cash. We're not really anxious to see our leverage levels go any lower than they were when we established the share buyback. And while we continue to explore opportunities in the M&A space in both of the business segments, I think we feel comfortable we have the room to do most sized deals as well as share repurchase as well as continuing CapEx at the current levels. So we're very comfortable that we can accomplish all those things and still maintain what in our minds is a comfortable leverage level.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And might also just ask you because we get asked a lot about it. A couple of weeks ago, you filed another 8-K indicating some additional request for information in the behavioral business. Broadly, I'll just throw out on the table, is there anything
componenttext: Okay. And might also just ask you because we get asked a lot about it. A couple of weeks ago, you filed another 8-K indicating some additional request for information in the behavioral business. Broadly, I'll just throw out on the table, is there anything that can be said about what's happening behind the scenes there? And then I would also throw it out in terms of the operating performance. Looking at the behavioral business from a high level, it doesn't look like those inquiries are having any impact, at least in aggregate, on the business. Is that your assessment of it? Or anything we should be aware of?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the investigation has been ongoing now for a little over 2 years, A.J. We take it very seriously. We've cooperated fully with the government and have responded to all their requests and continue to respond to any new and incremental request that they m
componenttext: So the investigation has been ongoing now for a little over 2 years, A.J. We take it very seriously. We've cooperated fully with the government and have responded to all their requests and continue to respond to any new and incremental request that they make. But I think your observation is a fair one in the sense that we also continue to operate our business consistent with what we believe are the highest standards and we'll continue to do so. I think, unfortunately, those who follow the industry know that these investigations can be a long process and it certainly has been long already, but I also don't believe it's necessarily in its end stages. So it may go on for awhile, and while it does, we'll continue to take it seriously and comply with the government and cooperate with the government. But at the same time, we're going to continue to run the business, which we feel delivers high-quality care throughout the portfolio.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just maybe I'll slip in a last technical question. The California provider fee, I think you were not accruing previously the managed care proportion. Did you accrue anything this quarter? And what might that be if it ever comes to fruition
componenttext: Okay. And then just maybe I'll slip in a last technical question. The California provider fee, I think you were not accruing previously the managed care proportion. Did you accrue anything this quarter? And what might that be if it ever comes to fruition for you?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we did not recognize any incremental California UPL revenue in the quarter. And I think if it were to be approved, it's probably another, in my recollection, A.J., is another set of $5 million, $6 million. It's not a huge number.
componenttext: So we did not recognize any incremental California UPL revenue in the quarter. And I think if it were to be approved, it's probably another, in my recollection, A.J., is another set of $5 million, $6 million. It's not a huge number.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Ralph Giacobbe with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Ralph Giacobbe with Credit Suisse.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to jump to the behavioral side. Do you think there was any help from Mental Health Parity in the quarter? Any way to sort of discern that? And then I know we talk about this ever quarter, but any more visibility or optimism around sort of the
componenttext: Just wanted to jump to the behavioral side. Do you think there was any help from Mental Health Parity in the quarter? Any way to sort of discern that? And then I know we talk about this ever quarter, but any more visibility or optimism around sort of the length-of-stay challenges?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ralph. So I think on the length-of-stay issue, we continue to see length-of-stay decline, although I'll repeat a comment that I made in the fourth quarter and I think it continued into Q1, and that is that at least some of that length-of-stay declin
componenttext: Sure, Ralph. So I think on the length-of-stay issue, we continue to see length-of-stay decline, although I'll repeat a comment that I made in the fourth quarter and I think it continued into Q1, and that is that at least some of that length-of-stay decline, at least in the last few quarters, is self-imposed or self-manufactured in the sense that we continue to convert residential beds and residential services to acute beds and acute services. And when we do that, we are, by definition, lowering our length of stay because acute services length of stay is markedly lower than the residential length of stay is. So at least some element of the length-of-stay decline is intentional, and quite frankly, I think in our minds a positive development in that we're replacing higher revenue beds with lower revenue beds and I think that's partly what you see in the strong revenue growth, that same-store revenue growth of 6 plus-percent, which is clearly at the high end of our own expectations. As far as being able to identify the effect from Parity, I think we always believe that would be difficult to do. And I think we still believe that almost -- well, not impossible to do and that's because when we see a patient who has valid and legitimate insurance, we really don't sort of know the history of that insurance, to what degree benefit plan design has changed, et cetera. I think the insurance companies or the government might have better insight into that. What we are very focused on as a company, I think, and as an industry is in making sure that the Parity rules and regulations, including some of the newer ones and some of the clarifications are being properly enforced because I think we believe that there still are plans and that there still is executions of the plans that are not compliant and therefore that there is sort of upside to us if we can ensure that compliance is met throughout the country.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Then where are you, I guess, in the process of converting beds? Is there a time line for us to think about in terms of where you are at this point? Or is this just ongoing?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Then where are you, I guess, in the process of converting beds? Is there a time line for us to think about in terms of where you are at this point? Or is this just ongoing?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't know that it's sort of a finite sort of process, Ralph, where we have X number of beds that we want to convert. I think it's an issue of we're always looking at the best and highest use of all of our beds. And to the degree that beds become s
componenttext: Yes, I don't know that it's sort of a finite sort of process, Ralph, where we have X number of beds that we want to convert. I think it's an issue of we're always looking at the best and highest use of all of our beds. And to the degree that beds become sort of underperforming because rates go down or length of stay is under great pressure, whatever it may be, and if the demand is there for another better performing service, we're willing to convert those beds. So I don't know that we would sort of put it in the context of we're done with 50% of our conversions. I think, for us, it's just sort of an ongoing process and will remain so.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then one more if I can. Just SWB came in a lot better. Is it anything more than just leveraging the top line? Or are there specific initiatives there that helped? And I guess, more importantly, on a go-forward basis, can you help us
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then one more if I can. Just SWB came in a lot better. Is it anything more than just leveraging the top line? Or are there specific initiatives there that helped? And I guess, more importantly, on a go-forward basis, can you help us in terms of what a fair range on thinking about that line item as a percentage of revenue, particularly considering your commentary around maybe being tough to sustain the level of top line growth that we've seen in the quarter?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, look, salaries and wages are obviously the single biggest expense item in both of our divisions and get a lot of attention from the operators. But the nature of the business is such that when you have the really sort of strong revenue growth
componenttext: Yes, I mean, look, salaries and wages are obviously the single biggest expense item in both of our divisions and get a lot of attention from the operators. But the nature of the business is such that when you have the really sort of strong revenue growth that we had in Q1, you are likely to see a significant amount of operating leverage. You did see that particularly in the acute division in Q1. If that revenue run rate does start to sort of modestly regress, as I suggested before that it might from the 12-plus percent we ran in Q1, it'd be a little bit challenging to generate quite as much leverage as we did. But our operators are very focused on controlling those salary numbers and delivering an efficient and high-quality product, so I think they'll continue to remain focused that way.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Frank Morgan with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Frank Morgan with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess hopping back to that discussion on Parity. I know CMS just recently put out a proposal about extending Mental Health Parity to managed Medicaid and CHIP. And I'm just curious how much of an impact that might have? And do you think this may be a st
componenttext: I guess hopping back to that discussion on Parity. I know CMS just recently put out a proposal about extending Mental Health Parity to managed Medicaid and CHIP. And I'm just curious how much of an impact that might have? And do you think this may be a step in the direction, at least, toward striking down the IMD exclusion?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so, look, Frank, I think you get to the point that -- and I think as most of the people listening know, that the IMD exclusion precludes freestanding behavioral facilities from treating or from being paid, at least, for adult Medicaid patients and th
componenttext: Yes, so, look, Frank, I think you get to the point that -- and I think as most of the people listening know, that the IMD exclusion precludes freestanding behavioral facilities from treating or from being paid, at least, for adult Medicaid patients and that's a big hurdle from our perspective. The recent Parity clarifications that you mentioned I think are helpful for the nonadult population, the Medicaid population that's under age 21. And I think what it says is that managed care -- or Medicaid managed care organizations and other like organizations have to comply with Parity as to our case, that under 21 population. So I think it's helpful not in a sort of a game-changing way, but it's definitely helpful around the edges, if you will. We are hopeful and continue to work as an industry for a more rational sort of approach to the IMD exclusion and that means I think we continue to lobby CMS and cooperate with their data-gathering activities to try and demonstrate that lifting the IMD exclusion would be the correct thing to do from a public policy perspective. And we also continue to work on the legislative end of it, working with Congressman like -- working with legislators like Congressman Murphy who has a bill out there that would eliminate the IMD exclusion. So we're working on a number of fronts. I think that lifting the IMD exclusion would be a game changer. I think the continued modifications to the Parity law and the Parity rules are helpful, but the sort of end goal would be the lifting of the IMD exclusion.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. One more. In terms -- you mentioned good broad-based performance across most of your markets. But I guess, is there anywhere that you see really still has upside maybe on a relevant basis some markets that are underperforming, but still have upside?
componenttext: Okay. One more. In terms -- you mentioned good broad-based performance across most of your markets. But I guess, is there anywhere that you see really still has upside maybe on a relevant basis some markets that are underperforming, but still have upside? And then also I think you've got a new hospital, at least in the works, in Vegas. Could you give us comment there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, look, I think what you're seeing and we talked about this for years and I think during the several years of the recession beginning in 2009 for us as a company, I think, as an industry and extending well through 2013, we had this sort of multi
componenttext: Sure. Well, look, I think what you're seeing and we talked about this for years and I think during the several years of the recession beginning in 2009 for us as a company, I think, as an industry and extending well through 2013, we had this sort of multiyear pressure from the recession, from uncompensated care, et cetera, which put a burden on our volumes. Our volumes were rather muted during that period. And our uncompensated care level just grew throughout that period. And then beginning in 2014, with the benefits of the Affordable Care Act providing insurance to millions of people who didn't have it before as well as the improving economy allowing people to go back to work and get reinsured, all that's been helpful in our markets. I think because the decline was a multiyear decline, we always anticipated that the recovery would be a multiyear recovery and we're certainly seeing that. We're, I would suggest, either the second or the third year of a recovery in Las Vegas and the second year of recovery in a number of our other markets. So while -- I'm not sure that we feel like we can sustain these Q1 levels of growth. I think we're comfortable that, again, the course sort of recovery that's taking place is something that should last for a number of years.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Whit Mayo with Robert Baird.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015

componenttext: I know this exercise can be a little dangerous and you can cut it a few different ways. But looking back historically, you've earned roughly 30% of your...

componenttext: Speak up, please.

componenttextpreview: Can you hear me?
componenttext: Can you hear me?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015

componenttext: Yes, go ahead, Whit.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just was saying looking back historically, you guys have earned 30% of acute care EBITDA in the first quarter on some modest site performance for the rest of the year. I mean, think I can easily get right near the high end of the range. Is it fair to mayb
componenttext: Just was saying looking back historically, you guys have earned 30% of acute care EBITDA in the first quarter on some modest site performance for the rest of the year. I mean, think I can easily get right near the high end of the range. Is it fair to maybe think about given the outperformance in the first quarter that you could be tracking closer to the high end and maybe the midpoint at this time?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, I think although you describe it as dangerous, Whit, it would be -- if you do the math, I think unless there's a real change in the operating landscape or unanticipated hurdles in either of the core businesses, we should be comfortably movin
componenttext: Sure. I mean, I think although you describe it as dangerous, Whit, it would be -- if you do the math, I think unless there's a real change in the operating landscape or unanticipated hurdles in either of the core businesses, we should be comfortably moving towards the high end of our existing range. I think, again, just for all the reasons that we cited before, we just felt it was not terribly prudent to tinker with the range, either the high end or the low end at this point and we'll take kind of a closer look and a more measured look at it at the end of the second quarter. But certainly, I think if you do the math, it's not at all unreasonable to make the observation that we are headed for the higher end of the range.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it seems appropriate. And maybe just on cost trends for a second. Is there anything new that you're paying attention to in either segment right now? Any increase in registry costs with the volume that you're seeing come through the acute care portfoli
componenttext: No, it seems appropriate. And maybe just on cost trends for a second. Is there anything new that you're paying attention to in either segment right now? Any increase in registry costs with the volume that you're seeing come through the acute care portfolio. And you've leveraged supplies maybe a little bit more than I would have thought given the strength in the surgical performance in the quarter. And specialty pharma has gotten a lot of attention lately. So I guess I'm just trying to wrap my head around the cost trends and what you're seeing and what initiatives you have under way.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, I think, again, as a company and as an industry, we really did a significant amount of belt-tightening and kind of real structural reviews of our cost structure during those years of the recession when our revenues were really challenged. And I
componenttext: Yes. Look, I think, again, as a company and as an industry, we really did a significant amount of belt-tightening and kind of real structural reviews of our cost structure during those years of the recession when our revenues were really challenged. And I think that left us in a very good position beginning in 2014 when the trends -- the revenue trends reversed themselves and revenue growth began anew earnestly. And as a consequence, we've seen this pretty robust expansion of margins, particularly on the acute side of the business. I think, from a cost perspective, you cited the things that we're certainly concerned about. As volumes grow, there is pressure on wages. We see that higher over time and higher use of temporary nurses. We see it, to some degree, in pressures in terms of placing doctors. We've seen quite a bit of pressure, frankly, on the behavioral side in finding an adequate number of psychiatrists in all of our facilities and that's put some pressure on use of locums, physicians and that sort of thing. But as I think we step back and look at it, I don't know that there's anything on sort of the cost landscape that we would describe or think about as a huge discrete drag. Rather, it's always the challenge that as the business grows, you want to just make sure that you remain efficient. And I think our operators have been doing that for the last 1.5 years or so, have been doing a very good job of that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I might sneak just one quick one in and just looking for an update on Cygnet and just the updated performance of that asset.
componenttext: Okay. I might sneak just one quick one in and just looking for an update on Cygnet and just the updated performance of that asset.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, The behavioral company that we bought in the U.K. at the end of September was running at very healthy occupancy levels, probably close to 80% when we bought them. We didn't really believe there was a huge amount of upside opportunity in the ex
componenttext: Sure. Well, The behavioral company that we bought in the U.K. at the end of September was running at very healthy occupancy levels, probably close to 80% when we bought them. We didn't really believe there was a huge amount of upside opportunity in the existing business. But we're happy to say that even on the core business, occupancy rates have risen in the 6 months we've owned them and are getting close to 90% and that obviously is generating better-than-expected results for that business. And at the same time, we announced a small acquisition in our first 6 months of ownership where we've started a development project in our first 6 months of ownership and we continue to look at a whole series of other opportunities, both sort of large and small. So we couldn't frankly be more pleased with that platform in the 6 months that we've owned it than we are.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Joshua Raskin with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Joshua Raskin with Barclays.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question, just on what we're seeing in terms of just on providers and health plan collaborations and whether that means just sort of capitation or even all the way down to planned sponsor or provider-sponsored health plans. And I'm just curious what
componenttext: First question, just on what we're seeing in terms of just on providers and health plan collaborations and whether that means just sort of capitation or even all the way down to planned sponsor or provider-sponsored health plans. And I'm just curious what your perspectives, if you guys have any pilots going on in any year? I'm thinking more the 24 acute care hospitals, what your thoughts are on the future of that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Josh, we certainly share the view that over the long term, the reimbursement or payment landscape in acute care will change from a fee for service, the traditional fee-for-service reimbursement to some sort of fee-for-value reimbursement that will include
componenttext: Josh, we certainly share the view that over the long term, the reimbursement or payment landscape in acute care will change from a fee for service, the traditional fee-for-service reimbursement to some sort of fee-for-value reimbursement that will include things like bundled payments or accountable care organizations and ultimately gets to the end of the continuum, which is sort of the capitation model and the risk -- the sort of pure risk model that I think you're referencing. I think we believe that, that process is definitely an evolutionary process. It is one that will take multiple years. Honestly, the vast majority of our reimbursement remains fee-for-service reimbursement, although in some cases like in Medicare, there are quality components and elements of that, but it still largely remains fee-for-service reimbursement. What we're doing are a number of things, both in terms of our relationship with our physicians and really trying to integrate with our physicians, particularly on the information technology side, to prepare for that move to kind of more of a risk shifting environment with bundled payment and capitation, et cetera. We've talked, I think, at some length over the last few quarters about some of the initiatives surrounding the purchase in the middle of last year of a health insurance company in Nevada to better prepare us again for that sort of risk taking to allow us in certain selected markets and with certain selected products to go out there and have a provider-sponsored product in certain of our markets. So we're trying to move at just the right pace in our markets, not trying to get ahead of the curve, but also absolutely ensuring that we are nowhere behind the curve in terms of these changes that we know are coming in, certainly, at least the acute care space.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Steve, is that pace being driven more by the payers then and you're sort of reacting to or trying to accommodate those changes as opposed to just being UHS driven? I'm just trying to think do you think ultimately this is good or bad?
componenttext: So Steve, is that pace being driven more by the payers then and you're sort of reacting to or trying to accommodate those changes as opposed to just being UHS driven? I'm just trying to think do you think ultimately this is good or bad?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know that we would have a value judgment about it. I mean I think that the -- I think what we would say is it's inevitable. I think that payers and I think public policymakers have determined that the real -- ultimately, they real way to control c
componenttext: I don't know that we would have a value judgment about it. I mean I think that the -- I think what we would say is it's inevitable. I think that payers and I think public policymakers have determined that the real -- ultimately, they real way to control costs in the health care space is by a shift of risk from the consumer and the employer and the payer to -- excuse me, from the employer and the payer to the consumer and the provider. And so I think we're going there. And it's not necessarily, I think, on the surface a good or a bad thing. I think it's a good thing if you can react nimbly and flexibly to the changes and I think we're prepared to do that. So if you can be the one to have and put together a large network in our markets and deliver high-quality, low-cost care, efficient care in the markets, then I think it will be a good thing and I think we believe we're well positioned to do that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just shifting topics, one last one for me. Just on the behavioral health hospitals, just a thing about the M&A pipeline. We haven't seen a ton of activity X -- I'm thinking more domestically, so forgetting about the U.K. But just any update
componenttext: Okay. And then just shifting topics, one last one for me. Just on the behavioral health hospitals, just a thing about the M&A pipeline. We haven't seen a ton of activity X -- I'm thinking more domestically, so forgetting about the U.K. But just any updates on thoughts and maybe just supposing the commentary around lack of buybacks in the first quarter, how we should think about the psych hospital M&A pipeline?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, I think, that the behavioral business is characterized at the moment by a lot of strong results. Certainly, our results are reflective of the underlying strength in this business. So as a result, I think most of the larger -- and we're far and
componenttext: Yes. Look, I think, that the behavioral business is characterized at the moment by a lot of strong results. Certainly, our results are reflective of the underlying strength in this business. So as a result, I think most of the larger -- and we're far and away the largest, but most of the larger consolidated providers are right now in growth mode as opposed to in a sale mode or in a divestiture mode. So we're competing for assets with a number of other providers. I do think there still are a lot of other providers out there to be acquired. Also, we have talked to a number of times about the opportunity for the 50% of beds or so or half of the days or admissions in the behavioral business that are currently serviced within acute care hospitals. So that's behavioral beds within acute care hospitals. Some of the growth, for instance, of beds that I mentioned in my opening remarks are beds at acute care hospitals, nonaffiliated acute care hospitals, that we have opened in connection with newly sort of formed partnerships with acute care hospitals and we still think that's a significant opportunity in the future. Now to be fair, those opportunities are relatively bite-sized. We will get 30 beds at a time or 50 or 70 beds at a time. We're not going to get thousands and thousands of beds at a single stroke. But the ultimate opportunity, I think, is enormous and as by far and away the largest provider of freestanding behavioral services in the country, I think we're very well positioned to take advantage of that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Darren Lehrich with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Darren Lehrich with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Dana Nentin on for Darren. Just to follow up on an earlier question in the behavioral segment, I guess, particularly in the U.K. Can you just provide some more color on bed additions and development there? And how you might be working with NHS on get
componenttext: It's Dana Nentin on for Darren. Just to follow up on an earlier question in the behavioral segment, I guess, particularly in the U.K. Can you just provide some more color on bed additions and development there? And how you might be working with NHS on getting approvals and finding opportunities to expand beds there.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the opportunity in the U.K. broadly is sort of a twofold opportunity and one is that the overall demand for private psychiatric beds is going to continue to grow as the National Health Service continues to trend towards outsourcing more
componenttext: Well, I think that the opportunity in the U.K. broadly is sort of a twofold opportunity and one is that the overall demand for private psychiatric beds is going to continue to grow as the National Health Service continues to trend towards outsourcing more of that business and deciding that they're going to spend their capital on investments other than behavioral investments and I think leave a lot of the new incremental capital to be invested in the behavior industry to the private sector. At the same time, the market, much like it is here in the U.S., remains fragmented, and as a consequence, there are M&A opportunities and we're pursuing those and also doing all the same things that we're doing in the U.S., which, I think, you alluded to in your question where we're running, as I said, in response to a previous question at very high occupancy rates, that we're looking at adding beds to our facilities as we are here in the U.S. We're looking at building greenfield de novo projects and we'll continue to do all those things.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Chris Rigg with Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Chris Rigg with Susquehanna Financial.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to keep going with the M&A theme here for another minute. I know you guys have talked about in the past the potential for -- an appetite for sort of larger nonprofit deals and I guess I'd love to get your view. We're seeing very strong resul
componenttext: I just wanted to keep going with the M&A theme here for another minute. I know you guys have talked about in the past the potential for -- an appetite for sort of larger nonprofit deals and I guess I'd love to get your view. We're seeing very strong results from the publicly traded chains. Are the results we're seeing from you guys sort of an illusion to what's going on amongst the sort of nonpublic guys? Or do you think that the dynamic has actually changed materially because of the ACA and that's a setback to sort of nearer-term, larger nonprofit deals?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, Chris, I'm not sure that I'm the foremost expert on the subject. But I think if you look the not-for-profit financial data that is out there in any sort of consolidated way, I think that probably the best data comes from the rating agencies and I
componenttext: I mean, Chris, I'm not sure that I'm the foremost expert on the subject. But I think if you look the not-for-profit financial data that is out there in any sort of consolidated way, I think that probably the best data comes from the rating agencies and I think that their data suggest that the not-for-profit results, financial results, have not improved at the same rate over the last year or 1.5 years as the for-profit results have. And so I think you'll still find a number of not-for-profit acute hospitals that find themselves financially challenged in a variety of ways. I think also, going back to Josh Raskin's question, I think a lot of not-for-profit hospitals look at the landscape of changing reimbursement and the challenges that presents and the need to be in a large network and find that they may not be able to check all the boxes. And I think they're looking for either partners or they're looking for some sort of sale arrangement that allows them to be -- to sort of be better positioned to move forward in the future. So we're talking with a number of not-for-profits about those sorts of opportunities. I think those sorts of opportunities are going to be there in the next few years. It's difficult to predict how and at what rate they'll develop and all we can do is respond to them as they develop, but we're certainly ready to do so and we certainly have the financial flexibility to do so.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We have a question in queue from the line of Ana Gupte with Leerink Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I think you said a little bit about last Vegas and I apologize if I've missed any more color, but as you're looking at the various strong geographies, particularly in the acute care business, Medicaid expanding states, non-Medicaid expanding states
componenttext: Steve, I think you said a little bit about last Vegas and I apologize if I've missed any more color, but as you're looking at the various strong geographies, particularly in the acute care business, Medicaid expanding states, non-Medicaid expanding states and then Vegas, which is kind of as you said in the third year of economic recovery; Texas, which has had a recovery, but is going to a bit of a state of layoffs and so on, how is the payer mix to the extent you have visibility differing from one core markets versus another?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean I think the trends have been directionally the same over the last 1.5 years and that is we certainly have seen a decline in uninsured patients and an increase in insured patients, mostly in Medicaid and commercial exchange patients. Those -- the pe
componenttext: I mean I think the trends have been directionally the same over the last 1.5 years and that is we certainly have seen a decline in uninsured patients and an increase in insured patients, mostly in Medicaid and commercial exchange patients. Those -- the percentages and then the magnitude of that change differs a little bit from market to market. And it's a little challenging, as I suggested at the outset of the call, to kind of discretely identify to what degree those changes, those payer mix changes, are being driven by the ACA and to what degree they're being driven by economic improvement or other factors. But I think our view is, as I said to it in an earlier response, that those trends, the ACA implementation will continue this year and probably for at least one more year and I think the economic improvement will likely continue. And then there are individual market efforts, which I think are also driving some of this improvement and I think have been very successful. And I think in our minds, will also -- those results will be sustainable as well.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And do you have any real-time visibility into Texas just on recognizing your exposure to the oil-heavy economy as a bit more limited than your peers about working Americans in Texas that might want to use more care or do more surgeries or whatever because
componenttext: And do you have any real-time visibility into Texas just on recognizing your exposure to the oil-heavy economy as a bit more limited than your peers about working Americans in Texas that might want to use more care or do more surgeries or whatever because they're fearful of layoffs. Is any of that visible at all in the first quarter?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's worth noting that while we are in a number of markets in Texas, we're really not in any markets that are heavily dependent on the oil and gas industry and I don't think we're therefore directly impacted by any of the softness in that se
componenttext: Well, I think it's worth noting that while we are in a number of markets in Texas, we're really not in any markets that are heavily dependent on the oil and gas industry and I don't think we're therefore directly impacted by any of the softness in that sector of the economy. To be fair, while we continue to watch it closely, I don't think we're seeing pressure on your volumes or payer mix currently in our markets in Texas. Frankly, I think one of our broader concerns is that if there really is a squeeze on the Texas economy and it gets sort of felt and impacted at the state budget level, we are a big Medicaid provider in Texas, both in terms of traditional Medicaid reimbursement as well as some of the special programs like Disproportionate Share and UPL. That's the sort of thing that we keep a close eye on. But to be fair, we're not really seeing any impact from a softer Texas economy in our markets as of this moment.

componenttext: One final one. On the other OpEx that showed some deterioration, is that kind of a trend in spike and might get better?

componenttext: I think it probably is more impacted by the dynamic that I was talking about before, which is the continued shift of beds from residential to acute. headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Kelly, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Universal Health Services First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Filton, you m
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Kelly, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Universal Health Services First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Filton, you may begin your conference.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the first quarter ended March 31, 2015. During the conference call, Alan and I will be using words such a
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the first quarter ended March 31, 2015. 
During the conference call, Alan and I will be using words such as believes, expects, anticipates, estimates and similar words that represent forecasts, projections and forward-looking statements.  For anyone not familiar with the risks and uncertainties inherent in these forward-looking statements, I recommend the careful reading of the section on risk factors and forward-looking statements and risk factors in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014. 
We would like to highlight just a couple of developments and business trends before opening the call up to questions.
As discussed in our press release last night, the company recorded -- reported net income attributable to UHS per diluted share of $1.73 for the quarter. After adjusting for the depreciation and amortization expense associated with the implementation of electronic health records applications at our acute care hospitals, our adjusted net income attributable to UHS per diluted share was $1.78 for the quarter ended March 31, 2015. 
On a same-facility basis in our acute care division, revenues increased 12.2% during the first quarter of 2015. The increase resulted primarily from a 5.7% increase in adjusted admissions and a 6.1% increase in revenue per adjusted admission. On a same-facility basis, operating margins for our acute care hospitals increased to 21.6% during the first quarter of 2015 from 19.2% during the first quarter of 2014.
On a same-facility basis, revenues in our behavioral health division increased 6.3% during the first quarter of 2015. Adjusted admissions to our behavioral health facilities owned for more than a year increased 6.0%, and adjusted patient days increased 2.6% over the prior year first quarter. Revenue per adjusted patient day rose 3.7% during the first quarter of 2015 over the comparable prior year quarter. On a same-facility basis, operating margins for our behavioral health division increased to 28.6% during the quarter ended March 31, 2015, as compared to 27.7% during the comparable prior year period.
Our cash provided by operating activities increased 39% to approximately $271 million during the first quarter of 2015 as compared to $195 million in the first quarter of 2014. 
Our accounts receivable days outstanding remained at 56 days during comparable first quarters of 2015 and 2014.
Our ratio of debt to total capitalization decreased to 44.6% at March 31, 2015, as compared to 48.6% at March 31, 2014.
During the first quarter of 2015, we spent $89 million on capital expenditures. During the quarter, we completed construction and opened 54 new beds in our acute care division and 148 new behavioral health beds at some of our busiest behavioral facilities. 
Alan and I will be pleased to answer your questions at this time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess the market oftentimes has a hard time getting your numbers right on a quarter-to-quarter basis. How would you characterize this quarter versus your internal expectations? It seemed like a pretty strong quarter on our side.
componenttext: I guess the market oftentimes has a hard time getting your numbers right on a quarter-to-quarter basis. How would you characterize this quarter versus your internal expectations? It seemed like a pretty strong quarter on our side.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Kevin. We certainly would share the view that this was a strong quarter. I would note that our internal expectations for the quarter were somewhat higher than the Street's, maybe by $0.07 or $0.08. So we didn't have quite as much of an internal beat
componenttext: Sure, Kevin. We certainly would share the view that this was a strong quarter. I would note that our internal expectations for the quarter were somewhat higher than the Street's, maybe by $0.07 or $0.08. So we didn't have quite as much of an internal beat, but still a very nice beat in the quarter. But it's also part of the reason why we chose not to revise our guidance at this point.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. If there's anything that you could point to that kind of -- versus your internal budget where numbers came in a little bit stronger?
componenttext: Okay. If there's anything that you could point to that kind of -- versus your internal budget where numbers came in a little bit stronger?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: My guess is, directionally, our experience was much like the Street's expectations and models in that, clearly, the biggest excess over budget or expectations was in the acute division. The 12-plus percent revenue growth, same-store revenue growth, in the
componenttext: My guess is, directionally, our experience was much like the Street's expectations and models in that, clearly, the biggest excess over budget or expectations was in the acute division. The 12-plus percent revenue growth, same-store revenue growth, in the acute division was well in excess of the 7% to 8% that we talked about having guided to in our 2015 guidance. So that was clearly the biggest element of the beat.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I know that you guys usually don't update numbers with Q1, but any thoughts about how reform is coming in versus your expectations, and I'll jump off.
componenttext: Okay. And then I know that you guys usually don't update numbers with Q1, but any thoughts about how reform is coming in versus your expectations, and I'll jump off.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Look, I think we've made the point throughout 2014 that, I think, the science, if you will, of identifying the discrete impact of reform was difficult in 2014. I think as we move into the second year of reform implementation, it becomes even sort of
componenttext: Sure. Look, I think we've made the point throughout 2014 that, I think, the science, if you will, of identifying the discrete impact of reform was difficult in 2014. I think as we move into the second year of reform implementation, it becomes even sort of more blurry from our perspective. I think that we estimated that about 6% to 7% of our acute care EBITDA would come from reform patients, either Medicaid expansion patients or commercial exchange patients, and I think we still believe that, that's a best guess number and I think we ran at that rate in Q1. But again, I will sort of caveat that, I think, we believe it is becoming more and more difficult to precisely identify that impact and I think it will become even more difficult as time passes.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to know if you could update us on the percentage of the business that may be related to the economic environment improving and maybe how we should think about those trends for the rest of the year in 2015. And also if you could give us more co
componenttext: Just wanted to know if you could update us on the percentage of the business that may be related to the economic environment improving and maybe how we should think about those trends for the rest of the year in 2015. And also if you could give us more color on maybe your larger markets and what's happening in Texas, Florida and Vegas?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paula. I think what we did -- what we had said in 2014 was we attributed something like 35% to 40% of our acute care improvement to ACA-related impact, a comparable amount, another 35% to 40%, to just the economic improvement in our markets and then
componenttext: Sure, Paula. I think what we did -- what we had said in 2014 was we attributed something like 35% to 40% of our acute care improvement to ACA-related impact, a comparable amount, another 35% to 40%, to just the economic improvement in our markets and then the remaining 15% to 20% to kind of discrete market share improvements, et cetera, in our individual markets. Again, it strikes me that those percentages are probably still reasonably accurate in 2015 in terms of sort of geographically how the quarter looked. We had a very, very strong quarter in our Las Vegas market. Volumes were very strong in the Las Vegas market. We continued to see a full quarter's worth of benefit of the Medicaid expansion in Nevada, which is a Medicaid expansion state obviously, and so just real strong results in the Las Vegas market in Q1. Additionally, a very nice swing between years in our Temecula facility. I'll remind people that our Temecula was a start-up in the first quarter of 2014, so it is ramping up quite nicely. And while I think a lot of that ramp is reflected in our guidance, it does provide a real nice tailwind year-to-year. So those are the 2 markets I would highlight. Obviously, I think when you post as solid and as robust a quarter as we did, you're going to have strong results pretty much through the portfolio and we did, but at least I'd highlight those 2 markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And do you think that some of this strength is sustainable throughout the year? I mean, you talked about the 7% to 8% increase. We had a 12%, so would that mean that, just given the difficult compares, that we might see some softness sort of as we go thro
componenttext: And do you think that some of this strength is sustainable throughout the year? I mean, you talked about the 7% to 8% increase. We had a 12%, so would that mean that, just given the difficult compares, that we might see some softness sort of as we go through? Or it's just too soon to tell?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think part of the reason why we made no change to guidance is that, I think, after one quarter, we think it's generally premature to make changes to the outlook. We certainly feel like the core strength that both business segments demonstrated in
componenttext: Well, I think part of the reason why we made no change to guidance is that, I think, after one quarter, we think it's generally premature to make changes to the outlook. We certainly feel like the core strength that both business segments demonstrated in Q1 is largely sustainable. I mean, that 12-plus percent same-store revenue growth in the acute division, particularly as the year progresses and the comparisons become more difficult and the volume comparisons, in particular, become more difficult, I think will be difficult to sustain. But I think the core directional trends that are very strong in the 2 businesses, we certainly believe should be sustainable.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I just wanted to know what do you attribute the strength in the revenue or the pricing per adjusted admit to? Is there anything in particular that you can call out for us that happened during the quarter in terms of pricing or payer mix s
componenttext: Okay, great. And I just wanted to know what do you attribute the strength in the revenue or the pricing per adjusted admit to? Is there anything in particular that you can call out for us that happened during the quarter in terms of pricing or payer mix shift?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's a continuation of some of the trends that we called out in the Fourth Quarter. We talked about it in Q4 very strong surgical volume strength. We saw those same trends in Q1. I highlighted in Q4 the fact that, I think, for the first time,
componenttext: Yes, I think it's a continuation of some of the trends that we called out in the Fourth Quarter. We talked about it in Q4 very strong surgical volume strength. We saw those same trends in Q1. I highlighted in Q4 the fact that, I think, for the first time, at least in recent memory, our inpatient surgical growth rate was higher than our outpatient and we saw that same dynamic continue into Q1. So that's certainly driving a lot of the, sort of, acuity element of the revenue improvement. And then secondly, we just have that continued payer mix improvement. We anticipated that 2015 would benefit from a full year of that enrollment that we saw occur, sort of, incrementally throughout 2014 and I think Q1 was a reflection of that, and again, particularly in places like Las Vegas, which had huge Medicaid expansion growth in '14. And you're seeing that play out in a full quarter in the First Quarter of 2015.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015

componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of A.J. Rice with UBS.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, obviously, you had good cash flow quarter as well as operating quarter, but you didn't do too much in the buyback mode. Is that indicative of you're seeing an uptick in deal activity? Or any thoughts about the buyback going forward.
componenttext: First, obviously, you had good cash flow quarter as well as operating quarter, but you didn't do too much in the buyback mode. Is that indicative of you're seeing an uptick in deal activity? Or any thoughts about the buyback going forward.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the first quarter is a little different for us and, I think, for most in the sense that we spent most of the first quarter in a quiet period, so most of the buyback during the first quarter is done, in our case, under a 10b-5 preplanned repurchase that
componenttext: So the first quarter is a little different for us and, I think, for most in the sense that we spent most of the first quarter in a quiet period, so most of the buyback during the first quarter is done, in our case, under a 10b-5 preplanned repurchase that we established some price parameters around, and sometimes we miss those estimates, so -- some. So I think I wouldn't read the relatively modest repurchases in Q1 to be terribly meaningful in any regard. I'll repeat what we've said in the last few quarters since the buyback authorization in Q2 of 2014 was approved by the board, and that is we anticipate we're going to generate a significant amount of free cash. We're not really anxious to see our leverage levels go any lower than they were when we established the share buyback. And while we continue to explore opportunities in the M&A space in both of the business segments, I think we feel comfortable we have the room to do most size deals as well as share repurchase as well as continuing CapEx at the current levels. So we're very comfortable that we can accomplish all those things and still maintain what, in our minds, is a comfortable leverage level.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And might also just ask you, because we get asked a lot about it. A couple of weeks ago, you filed another 8-K indicating some additional request for information in the behavioral business. Broadly, I'll just throw out on the table, is there anythin
componenttext: Okay. And might also just ask you, because we get asked a lot about it. A couple of weeks ago, you filed another 8-K indicating some additional request for information in the behavioral business. Broadly, I'll just throw out on the table, is there anything that can be said about what's happening behind the scenes there? And then I would also throw it out in terms of the operating performance. Looking at the behavioral business from a high level, it doesn't look like those inquiries are having any impact, at least in aggregate, on the business. Is that your assessment of it? Or anything we should be aware of?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the investigation has been ongoing now for a little over 2 years, A.J. We take it very seriously. We've cooperated fully with the government and have responded to all their requests and continue to respond to any new and incremental requests that they
componenttext: So the investigation has been ongoing now for a little over 2 years, A.J. We take it very seriously. We've cooperated fully with the government and have responded to all their requests and continue to respond to any new and incremental requests that they make. But I think your observation is a fair one in the sense that we also continue to operate our business consistent with what we believe are the highest standards and we'll continue to do so. I think, unfortunately, those who follow the industry know that these investigations can be a long process; this certainly has been long already, but I also don't believe it's necessarily in its end stages. So it may go on for awhile, and while it does, we'll continue to take it seriously and comply with the government and cooperate with the government. But at the same time, we're going to continue to run the business, which we feel delivers high-quality care throughout the portfolio.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just maybe I'll slip in a last technical question. The California provider fee, I think you were not accruing, previously, the managed care proportion. Did you accrue anything this quarter? And what might that be if it ever comes to fruitio
componenttext: Okay. And then just maybe I'll slip in a last technical question. The California provider fee, I think you were not accruing, previously, the managed care proportion. Did you accrue anything this quarter? And what might that be if it ever comes to fruition for you?
