headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Michael Hoffman for Sarah. Just kind of following up on Matt's question. Same facility acute care adjusted admissions growth grew by 5.7%, the same growth in both 1Q and 2Q. And in 1Q you mentioned those numbers especially difficult to sustain moving to t
componenttext: Michael Hoffman for Sarah. Just kind of following up on Matt's question. Same facility acute care adjusted admissions growth grew by 5.7%, the same growth in both 1Q and 2Q. And in 1Q you mentioned those numbers especially difficult to sustain moving to the year. So how should we be looking at this for the back half of the year?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, and I wish we had perfect insight into that dynamic. You're absolutely right. So we've run 5.7% adjusted admission growth for the first half of the year. That is really significant improvement over what we've been running. But I think if you even lo
componenttext: Look, and I wish we had perfect insight into that dynamic. You're absolutely right. So we've run 5.7% adjusted admission growth for the first half of the year. That is really significant improvement over what we've been running. But I think if you even look at it in a broader context and look at it back over multiple years and a decade or 2, I mean, that's at the high end of our business that has run at best days. So I think to some degree, we have the view is going to be sustain that level of growth. We obviously will work hard to do so and are focused on doing it. But I think to be realistic about it and I think the way that we crafted our by guidance for the balance of the year, we presume that, that growth slows some. And I was speaking with somebody last night and made the point that look, if we think acute same-store revenue growth is 3% or 3.5% in the back half of the year, if you would ask us about a year ago or I think ask just about anybody observing the acute care business, would've been pleased that sort of growth. I think we're looking for that volume growth to moderate some in the back half of the year. Although we will certainly work hard to maintain what we've experienced in the first half.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Also debt-to-EBITDA this quarter was lower sequentially. And you guys have mentioned previously that you wouldn't let that leverage continue on any lower from levels. Taking that into account M&A activity slower year-to-date versus peers, how do you see t
componenttext: Also debt-to-EBITDA this quarter was lower sequentially. And you guys have mentioned previously that you wouldn't let that leverage continue on any lower from levels. Taking that into account M&A activity slower year-to-date versus peers, how do you see the pipeline compared to last year, smaller or just as big?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's always hard to judge, but I do think that we have a sense that there is sort of an increased level of activity. We seem to be reviewing a number of deals or potential deals in both business segments. It's always hard to predict what might mat
componenttext: I think it's always hard to judge, but I do think that we have a sense that there is sort of an increased level of activity. We seem to be reviewing a number of deals or potential deals in both business segments. It's always hard to predict what might materialize or not materialize. But certainly, I think we've been up the mind that it looks to us like there may be more opportunities in the next 12 months than there've been in some time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just one last question. On the behavior front, increased length of stay sequentially. Is your conversion of residential beds to acute beds completed? And could that be the driver of the increase? Or do you believe this is more related to stabilizing t
componenttext: And just one last question. On the behavior front, increased length of stay sequentially. Is your conversion of residential beds to acute beds completed? And could that be the driver of the increase? Or do you believe this is more related to stabilizing trend of length of stay that's trying to pick up?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think you have to be careful that what you're looking at. If you look at length of stay on a same-store basis, it's still down 3.5% or so from last year. If you look at it on a total divisional basis, it's up, but I think that's largely because
componenttext: Yes. So I think you have to be careful that what you're looking at. If you look at length of stay on a same-store basis, it's still down 3.5% or so from last year. If you look at it on a total divisional basis, it's up, but I think that's largely because it includes the U.K. facilities, which clearly have a longer length of stay. So I would sort of echo many of the statements that we made in Q1, which is we still see length of stay declining some, although we also believe that some of that decline is kind of self-imposed or self-initiated as we convert more beds from residential to acute. So -- which I think is reflected in the fact that even though we have lower length of stay and lower patient days, we have a higher revenue per day. The 4-plus-percent revenue per day growth is I think among the best that we've seen in some time, and again, I think is reflective of our efforts to convert from residential to acute beds.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of AJ Rice with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of AJ Rice with UBS.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe first I'll just ask you to comment a little bit on the geographies, obviously with a strong results you're probably seeing strength across the board. But is there anything to call out of the geographies, in particular maybe in addition to Vegas and
componenttext: Maybe first I'll just ask you to comment a little bit on the geographies, obviously with a strong results you're probably seeing strength across the board. But is there anything to call out of the geographies, in particular maybe in addition to Vegas and Texas you always talk about, anything on the new facilities that are coming online that you had in the last year or so?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, AJ. I think your comment is well taken in the sense that I think when you have almost 6% same-store adjusted admission growth and over 8% same-store revenue growth in the acute division, you're basically, I think I have to assume and I think will be
componenttext: Sure, AJ. I think your comment is well taken in the sense that I think when you have almost 6% same-store adjusted admission growth and over 8% same-store revenue growth in the acute division, you're basically, I think I have to assume and I think will be correct to assume, that there's pretty strong performance across the portfolio. It would be difficult if there were to post those kind of numbers. On the other hand, what we did in Q1 was we called out the performance of the Vegas market and Riverside County market in California. Those 2 markets, again, I would say outperformed the divisional averages in Q2. And that includes sort of to your question that Temecula facility, which has been open for about 1.5 years, maybe a little longer at this point. But I think what's really impressive about that Riverside County market is not only Temecula doing a little bit better than it did last year, probably not a surprises it's ramping up, but our other hospitals in that market are also doing better, so that's a really strong market in addition to the Vegas market, which continues to outperform and I think that's also within our expectations to the sense that through several years of the recession, we talked about the drag from the Vegas market was for us. We were so used to it being an outperforming market that the difficulties and the high unemployment of that market was a real struggle for us. But as the market has improved and as unemployment has dropped in the Las Vegas market from like 6.5% from the high 15% at the height of the recession, I think our business has in turn improved both volume-wise and payer mix wise and so we see that. The flip side is the Texas market was a little bit slower. I can, I think that's a relative term, it's the low. As positive volume growth, but in terms of OR, or different geographies, it's probably performing under the average whereas Vegas and California were performing over the average.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just switching gears for a follow-up on this site business side. Since the first quarter, there's been this proposed rule at CMS mainly the Medicaid managed care, but it does incorporate some language around partially alleviating the IMD i
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just switching gears for a follow-up on this site business side. Since the first quarter, there's been this proposed rule at CMS mainly the Medicaid managed care, but it does incorporate some language around partially alleviating the IMD inclusion that's impacted your site business. Can you give us a little flavor of what the impact of that would be if it goes ahead and gets implemented? And any thoughts on timing on when we might see that actually happen?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well as you suggest, that was issued, I believe, at the beginning -- sort of early June, if I'm remembering correctly. And as a consequence, CMS can't issue a finalized rule until early August and then that's sort of the earliest they can do, if the
componenttext: Sure. Well as you suggest, that was issued, I believe, at the beginning -- sort of early June, if I'm remembering correctly. And as a consequence, CMS can't issue a finalized rule until early August and then that's sort of the earliest they can do, if they can certainly do it after that. What the rule will do and I think it was pressed for quite frankly by the managed Medicaid companies, is it would allow those companies to contract with whoever they chose based on certain conditions, but they would be able to contract for adult Medicaid patients regardless of the IMD exclusion rule. So we certainly believe that if that rule is finalized in anything close to the form that it was proposed and depending on when it is effective, we will certainly get a benefit from that. Difficult for us to quantify what that benefit is because we've never had those patients really before. So it's mostly guesstimate work at this point. But we're certainly looking forward to the final rule being issued and starting to contract with those managed Medicaid companies for their adult Medicaid patients. We view that as a nice potential tailwind for where this business. So we're anxiously awaiting for the issuance of this rule.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Josh Raskin with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Josh Raskin with Barclays.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: The first question, just on the expense side of things, overall seeing good control there. I'm just curious, are you seeing anything in terms of wages in your market and any markets specifically? Any pressures that are on wage growth?
componenttext: The first question, just on the expense side of things, overall seeing good control there. I'm just curious, are you seeing anything in terms of wages in your market and any markets specifically? Any pressures that are on wage growth?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, I think it's always a competitive market, Josh. And I don't think that's really changed. But I think if you look at it, one of the reasons why acute care margins are up is that when revenue increases and when volume increases the way that it does, t
componenttext: Look, I think it's always a competitive market, Josh. And I don't think that's really changed. But I think if you look at it, one of the reasons why acute care margins are up is that when revenue increases and when volume increases the way that it does, there are -- there is just the nature of the hospital operating model is there is 4 efficient providers, there's usually a fair amount of operating leverage to be exercised and I think our operators should get credit for doing so. So yes, I mean clearly, as a percentage of revenue, our salaries are down and we're exercising some of that leverage even though I do believe that there is a fair amount of wage pressure in some of our markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. But it sounded like you don't think that's changed, that wage pressure, nothing you would call out relative to last year?
componenttext: Okay. But it sounded like you don't think that's changed, that wage pressure, nothing you would call out relative to last year?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think there's been significant developments. No.
componenttext: No, I don't think there's been significant developments. No.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the site side of the business, have you guys talked about ancillary lines services beyond just the operation of the actual site facility?
componenttext: On the site side of the business, have you guys talked about ancillary lines services beyond just the operation of the actual site facility?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'm not exactly sure what that implies. I mean, again, we do offer a wide array of behavioral services. We tend to talk about them in terms of acute and residential, but we're one of the largest provider of specialty behavioral services, and have been
componenttext: So I'm not exactly sure what that implies. I mean, again, we do offer a wide array of behavioral services. We tend to talk about them in terms of acute and residential, but we're one of the largest provider of specialty behavioral services, and have been for a long time specializing in things like eating disorders and sexual trauma and all kinds of other specialties. And so we continue to do that. And I think we'll continue to do so. I know that addiction treatment is kind of a hot topic in the industry. But we've been -- we probably have a 8 or 9 facilities that are dedicated to CD and addiction treatment. We also have, for a long time now, had a real emphasis on supporting behavioral disorders within the military. We have what we call our Patriot Support program, and that is a program that is fairly widespread throughout the division. So in terms of service lines, I think we touch on most of them and continue to look for ways to expand them. Autism is another one that we've clearly emphasized more in the last few years. In terms of other behavioral-related services, we have outpatient services in a number of our markets, not really what else you might be alluding to. But we're always open to ways as the largest behavioral inpatient provider in the country, always looking for ways to enhance and kind of make that position more robust. So I think we're open to just about everything.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I was thinking outpatient [indiscernible], but that's very helpful.
componenttext: Yes, I was thinking outpatient [indiscernible], but that's very helpful.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Rigg with Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Rigg with Susquehanna Financial.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I know at this point you're kind of saying it was exercise to kind of isolate the ACA driven strength. But at the same time, I guess people are still trying to get a sense on how much that could be helping you out in the industry. Is it possible to sort o
componenttext: I know at this point you're kind of saying it was exercise to kind of isolate the ACA driven strength. But at the same time, I guess people are still trying to get a sense on how much that could be helping you out in the industry. Is it possible to sort of when you think about the pockets of volume strength commercial, Medicare, Medicaid, where the relative outperformance was in those buckets where you saw the most pronounced improvement year-to-year volume trends?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, and I suspect my answer will still be on satisfaction for you Chris, in the sense that I think what we've be said for a while is we assume that the growth in our Medicaid patient base utilization is related at least in large part to Medicaid
componenttext: Yes. I mean, and I suspect my answer will still be on satisfaction for you Chris, in the sense that I think what we've be said for a while is we assume that the growth in our Medicaid patient base utilization is related at least in large part to Medicaid expansion. We see it quite clearly, most dramatically in those states, Nevada, California, the District of Columbia, that have participated in Medicaid expansion. Although as others have noted, we've seen Medicaid utilization increases in our nonexpansion states as well. I guess the most people refer to that as the woodwork effect. And we certainly have seen that as well. Some of the commercial growth clearly comes from expansion patients. That's the trickiest part for us. It has not always been easy for us to identify exactly who is a commercial-exchange patient and who is just a regular commercial patient. So that's where I think wv always felt was the greatest level of imprecision. And then as I said in the last couple of quarters, we've clearly seen an increase in our Medicare utilization, which is difficult for us, quite frankly, to attribute either to the ACA impact or quite frankly to economic improvement only because historically, our Medicare utilization has been relatively insensitive to that, those sort of factors. But that's kind of where we've seen our payer mix go.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one big picture question. I guess with King Burwell behind us, there is a theory that, that sort of a -- that's a catalyst for additional states to opt into Medicaid -- into Medicaid expansion sooner rather than later. I guess, can you give
componenttext: Okay. And then one big picture question. I guess with King Burwell behind us, there is a theory that, that sort of a -- that's a catalyst for additional states to opt into Medicaid -- into Medicaid expansion sooner rather than later. I guess, can you give us your take as to whether that really is a game changer and that you will see states move to expand Medicaid over the near-term versus just keep delaying it?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, honestly, Chris, I wish I could predict this accurately. I mean in our case, you're really talking about a couple of states that make the difference. For us, the 2 states that have not chosen to participate that I think would make a significant di
componenttext: I mean, honestly, Chris, I wish I could predict this accurately. I mean in our case, you're really talking about a couple of states that make the difference. For us, the 2 states that have not chosen to participate that I think would make a significant difference in our acute care operations would be Florida and Texas. I think all sorts of people have speculated on the likelihood on those states might or might not choose to do so in the future. I don't know whether this Supreme Court ruling really makes that more likely are not. I don't think we have a view that in either of those dates that Medicaid expansion is going to take place imminently. So we continue to work for it along with the state hospital associations and others in those states. But I wouldn't make a prediction as to how likely that is.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is actually Joanna Gajuk filling in for Kevin today. Thanks for taking the question. So I just want to come back a little bit to the question earlier about the capital deployment. And I guess you talked about interest in other, I guess, areas in site
componenttext: This is actually Joanna Gajuk filling in for Kevin today. Thanks for taking the question. So I just want to come back a little bit to the question earlier about the capital deployment. And I guess you talked about interest in other, I guess, areas in site. But is there anything on the acute care side terms of the deals that you might be considering, or maybe outside of acute -- any sort of outpatient sites you're also looking to add? Any color around the capital deployment here, or whether maybe you're focused on increasing your CapEx?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Joanna, just to be clear about what I said, I was clear about saying that we have seen an increased number of opportunities in both the business segments, both acute and behavioral. And I think it's in both cases sort of across the continuum, meaning i
componenttext: So Joanna, just to be clear about what I said, I was clear about saying that we have seen an increased number of opportunities in both the business segments, both acute and behavioral. And I think it's in both cases sort of across the continuum, meaning it's hospitals. It may be outpatient facilities. It may be physician-type practices. And we're exploring all those items. I think the landscape of health care is such that it's changing and that payers and employers are looking for more comprehensive and coordinated continuum of care and looking for sort of the ability to go to 1 or 2 providers who can really kind of sort of provide that. So we're very focused on that in both of the divisions. And I think that it creates, I think, a universe of opportunities that is broader than what we necessarily have been used to for the last few years. So we'll say now again, as I also said before, I think it's difficult to predict to how this is going to sort out and what will really become actionable and what won't. But I think we're very focused on what those opportunities might be, again in both business segments.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. And then on the -- more on the policy side here. Can you comment about the proposed mandatory replacement demonstration or the bundle that came out? How do we feel it could impact the industry and your business in particular? And also maybe rec
componenttext: All right. And then on the -- more on the policy side here. Can you comment about the proposed mandatory replacement demonstration or the bundle that came out? How do we feel it could impact the industry and your business in particular? And also maybe recently on the, I guess, the set of hospital payment reforms that came out from the House Ways and Means Committee. Any color you can give us will be helpful.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Joanna, I'm not going to sort of comment on this really specific development in part because I don't know that we got a full opportunity to review them. But I'm going to just sort of reiterate a little bit and maybe expand on the comment I made before. We
componenttext: Joanna, I'm not going to sort of comment on this really specific development in part because I don't know that we got a full opportunity to review them. But I'm going to just sort of reiterate a little bit and maybe expand on the comment I made before. We certainly have of view that the reimbursement mechanisms that have been sort of historic ones for the industry are changing. They're changing, I think, incrementally. And I think that change will continue to be incremental. But we are doing great many things to prepare for that to prepare for things like accepting bundled payment and accepting capitated payments in some very limited instances, et cetera, because I think we do think that's at least part of the future of the industry. And so we're very focused on that. Now exactly what that form is going to take, to what degree the government is going to initiate that, or the initiation will come from the private sector, hard for us to predict that the moment. But I will tell you and there's probably not enough time in the context of this call to discuss it meaningfully. But we've got a number of initiatives underway to make sure that we are absolutely prepared for that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gurda with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gurda with KeyBanc.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I just heard on the news that the doctor's hospital of Renaissance have filed to expand or double the size of the number of the beds, but they have to get approval from the CMS. Do you have any sense for how likely that is?
componenttext: Steve, I just heard on the news that the doctor's hospital of Renaissance have filed to expand or double the size of the number of the beds, but they have to get approval from the CMS. Do you have any sense for how likely that is?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: We don't. As you might imagine, there are others in the market, I think, who are sort of questioning the appropriateness of that. And so CMS will have to weigh, I think a number of different factors as they think about that. But we -- for those who follow
componenttext: We don't. As you might imagine, there are others in the market, I think, who are sort of questioning the appropriateness of that. And so CMS will have to weigh, I think a number of different factors as they think about that. But we -- for those who followed us for a long time, know that the physician-owned hospital in the McAllen market is a formidable competitor of ours. When they first opened, we had a fairly significant diminution in our earnings in that market. We regained a lot of that over the years and done a number of things to strengthen our position in the market, including a number of physician-integration strategies, a number of physical strategies, physical improvements. And again, I think we feel like we're well positioned in the market, regardless of what the physician hospital ultimately is able to do.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I'm not sure if you're going to want to comment on this or not, but I'd be interested in hearing maybe an update in your relationship of working with M care?
componenttext: Okay. And I'm not sure if you're going to want to comment on this or not, but I'd be interested in hearing maybe an update in your relationship of working with M care?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean M care is the emergency room provider and probably the majority of our acute care hospitals, and they provide some other physician contract service -- services in some of our hospitals as well. As with any sort of Contract Service vendor, we w
componenttext: Yes, I mean M care is the emergency room provider and probably the majority of our acute care hospitals, and they provide some other physician contract service -- services in some of our hospitals as well. As with any sort of Contract Service vendor, we work closely with them to try and provide services that are both satisfactory to our patients and to our other physicians, as well as from our perspective, cost-efficient. And look, I think M care is a good solid company. We'll continue to work with them. But as always, we will continue to explore all the alternatives to increase patient satisfaction and increase our cost efficiency at the same time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Next question will come from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to focus on the U.K. for a second. Just wondering how that business is progressing in the behavioral side? Are you happy with it? And maybe how much of that business is contributing to our overall behavior revenue, and what are some of the g
componenttext: I just wanted to focus on the U.K. for a second. Just wondering how that business is progressing in the behavioral side? Are you happy with it? And maybe how much of that business is contributing to our overall behavior revenue, and what are some of the growth plans there for the next 12 months?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So, Paula, I think that we talked a little bit in Q1, and I'll largely repeat those comments in the sense that when we bought Cygnet in the U.K. in the late in third quarter of '14, they were already operating what we considered to be high occupancy
componenttext: Yes. So, Paula, I think that we talked a little bit in Q1, and I'll largely repeat those comments in the sense that when we bought Cygnet in the U.K. in the late in third quarter of '14, they were already operating what we considered to be high occupancy levels, probably around 80%, maybe the low 80s. We've been extremely pleased because I think they're now operating at close to 90%. And so while we didn't think there was a tremendous opportunity for improvement, based on our short period of ownership, that's already experienced some fairly significant incremental improvement that has been very beneficial. I would say at the end of the day, we acquired a company that had roughly $170 million $180 million of revenues, and $40 million of EBITDA, something like that. So it's not a terribly material part of our behavioral business or consolidated results at the moment, but we also viewed it as a platform for growth. We've already, in the short time we've owned them, announced small acquisition and a number of bed expansion opportunities, both kind of de novo facilities as well as incremental bed expansions in existing facilities. So I think it is turning out to be everything that we expected it would be and maybe more. And the hope is that it continues to be a platform for growth in the future and that we will continue to expand both the existing facilities as well as find other opportunities to acquire streams of EBITDA in that market.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow-up to that, 90% occupancy, certainly high. I know you mentioned de novos and bed expansions, that should help sort of fill in some of that demand. But wondering on the acquisition front, are there some larger players still in that mar
componenttext: And just as a follow-up to that, 90% occupancy, certainly high. I know you mentioned de novos and bed expansions, that should help sort of fill in some of that demand. But wondering on the acquisition front, are there some larger players still in that market that you could think about acquiring? And what are some of your thoughts there, I guess, in terms of how big do you want to actually take this business?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean the challenge when asked anywhere, whether it's in the U.K. or the U.S. about acquiring other consolidated players is unfortunately, that decision is up to those other players. There are other consolidated players in the U.K. And we certainly
componenttext: Yes, I mean the challenge when asked anywhere, whether it's in the U.K. or the U.S. about acquiring other consolidated players is unfortunately, that decision is up to those other players. There are other consolidated players in the U.K. And we certainly are doing our best to stay in touch of with those players to the degree that any of those players decide that they are looking to pursue some other strategy, whether it's an exit strategy or a joint venture strategy, or some sort of partnership to develop new facilities, we'd be interested in all those opportunities. So the difficulty of sort of pegging kind of the likelihood of that is, again, this is largely dependent on what somebody else wants to do or chooses to do. So for the most part, although we try to stay on top of it, we have to be reactive to that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the color there. Just one last one maybe for me. Certainly a very strong first half. You raised guidance and it seems that the second half, you're still taking a little bit more of a prudent approach. I was just wondering what type of metrics d
componenttext: Thanks for the color there. Just one last one maybe for me. Certainly a very strong first half. You raised guidance and it seems that the second half, you're still taking a little bit more of a prudent approach. I was just wondering what type of metrics do we need to see on the revenue side to maybe get the high mark in that EPS guidance?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I would say that to get to the high end of the EPS guidance, Paula, we'd have to sustain most of the metrics that you've seen in the first quarter, including the volume growth, which I think is probably the most aggressive piece that I mentioned before
componenttext: So I would say that to get to the high end of the EPS guidance, Paula, we'd have to sustain most of the metrics that you've seen in the first quarter, including the volume growth, which I think is probably the most aggressive piece that I mentioned before. I think realistically, we've assumed that there will be some tempering of that volume growth. And I would suggest that the midpoint of our guidance sort of is what's sort of suggest that there is at least a bit of tempering of that sort of growth. I think the high end is would be more of a continuation of all the trends we've seen in the first half.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ana Gupte with Leerink Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ana Gupte with Leerink Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to again tease out sort of the elements of what were the drivers of the guidance range and some of this might be repetition or at least a follow up of what others have already asked. In February, you are pretty conservative of the pull-through
componenttext: So I wanted to again tease out sort of the elements of what were the drivers of the guidance range and some of this might be repetition or at least a follow up of what others have already asked. In February, you are pretty conservative of the pull-through to EBITDA was weaker and weaker than expected. Firstly, on the new raised guidance this time, is this because the exchange enrollment that you have factored in was lower than what eventually manifested itself? Or are you more confident at this point, the midpoint of the year, on the economic recovery as a driver of the volumes?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean again, Ana, a little bit of your question is sort of based on this idea of what's driving the improvement. And not to be repetitive, but I think we struggled ourselves with exactly what is driving the improvement. I would say again, what makes us c
componenttext: I mean again, Ana, a little bit of your question is sort of based on this idea of what's driving the improvement. And not to be repetitive, but I think we struggled ourselves with exactly what is driving the improvement. I would say again, what makes us confident about raising guidance after the first half of the year is simply the acute care performance, which clearly was an outperformance in the first half, it's really based on the strong revenue growth. And I think that strong revenue growth is particularly driven by this 5.7% increase in adjusted admissions, which honestly is well above what we were guiding to and what we were budgeting for when the year began. And as I sort of suggested to my answer to Paula, I think that's the sort of trickiest variable from our perspective as we think about the back half of the year. We certainly believe that acute care demand will continue. It will be strong whether it would be quite as strong as the 5.7% again I'm going to make the point is really at the high end of our historical trends, not just us as a company, but as an industry. Whether that can continue, I'm not and again, we've tempered a little bit in our guidance. But I think that's what's really driving the confidence here is that the strong, very consistent performance in the first half of the year, and especially in Q2 when I think the comparisons were far more difficult.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then on the Medicaid utilization that you alluded to that's accelerating, I know the payer mix is not that clear at all times. But any color on whether this is from the Medicaid side of it versus the government Medicare itself? And any color on the ty
componenttext: And then on the Medicaid utilization that you alluded to that's accelerating, I know the payer mix is not that clear at all times. But any color on whether this is from the Medicaid side of it versus the government Medicare itself? And any color on the types of acuity and the types of procedures and services that are interesting in Medicare?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we always look at our Medicare and Medicaid blocks of business in total and we look at them as both the managed portion and the traditional portion, in part because they certainly owe a continuing shift of patients from the traditional Medicaid a
componenttext: Sure. So we always look at our Medicare and Medicaid blocks of business in total and we look at them as both the managed portion and the traditional portion, in part because they certainly owe a continuing shift of patients from the traditional Medicaid and Medicare programs to the managed Medicare and Medicaid programs. So if I were to answer the question directly like that, I would say no. Clearly, the increase in Medicare utilization is coming from an increase in Medicare advantage patients. But I don't know that, that's all that meaningful because clearly, there are just more Medicare Advantage patients today than there were a year ago or 2 years ago, whatever. But overall, we're seeing a more total Medicare and total Medicaid patient that to me is the more meaningful dynamic. In terms of who those patients are and what's driving them, as we review our service lines, as we review our surgical alliance, et cetera, we see strength really across the board, orthopedics, cardiology, oncology, and all the service lines that are traditional sort of Medicare intensive service lines. So I wouldn't point to a particular procedure or diagnosis, et cetera that's really driving this strength. I think it's pretty much across the board.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the Texas economy and the Medicaid concern that you had in February and it seems like the oil and gas, and I know you're not fully levered to those geographies, but just broadly speaking, the lay-off haven't abated. if anything they're accelerating. Ar
componenttext: On the Texas economy and the Medicaid concern that you had in February and it seems like the oil and gas, and I know you're not fully levered to those geographies, but just broadly speaking, the lay-off haven't abated. if anything they're accelerating. Are you comfortable at this point that there will not be any Medicaid funding pressures, or might we see that further down the line?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the answer is a little bit of both. I think that we think there's no immediate threat to our reimbursement funding in the state of Texas. I think that as always over the long-term you look out more uncertainty there might be. We have seen in
componenttext: Yes, I think the answer is a little bit of both. I think that we think there's no immediate threat to our reimbursement funding in the state of Texas. I think that as always over the long-term you look out more uncertainty there might be. We have seen in an earlier question or in response to an earlier question, I said that our Texas markets have performed a little bit more modestly than some of our other markets, like Vegas and California. So I don't know if that's the economic impact of a slightly slowing economy. Honestly, Texas is a big state and we're only in a handful of markets in this state. So I don't know whether our performance of our experience is necessary reflective of what's going on more broadly. But for us at least Texas has slowed a little bit. Again, and we the point earlier that's a relative term our Texas markets are ahead of last year and both volume wise and earnings wise, but not quite as much ahead as some of those other markets like California and Vegas.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: And a finaly one if I may. On the consolidation our announced in managed care, out of the 2 deals, the 2 mega deals, would you see both as potentially impacting the pricing dynamic? One is more of a complementary rather than an overlapping commercial-only
componenttext: And a finaly one if I may. On the consolidation our announced in managed care, out of the 2 deals, the 2 mega deals, would you see both as potentially impacting the pricing dynamic? One is more of a complementary rather than an overlapping commercial-only story, the other one is commercial. Any thoughts on that and what might be the strategic response from the hospital industry?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's difficult to respond. I think first of all I think the industry, the provider industry, broadly will, I think, raise questions about the lack of competitiveness or the diminishing in competitiveness that these transactions might drive. And I think on
componenttext: It's difficult to respond. I think first of all I think the industry, the provider industry, broadly will, I think, raise questions about the lack of competitiveness or the diminishing in competitiveness that these transactions might drive. And I think one of the things in the industry will point out is that it may not necessarily be or the most appropriate way to look at this may not simply be on the service line business, that I think when an insurer in a market gets increased commercialized and increased Medicare lives at the same time that increases their market power in the market, even though there might be 2 different service lines. So I think the industry as a whole will make those points as the government reviews these transactions. And I certainly am not smart enough to know how that's going to play out. I think for us, individually, we tend to look at these things very much in a market-by-market basis. We have spent and have focused a lot of our internal efforts over the last decade or 2 at enhancing and increasing our market positions in all of our markets, both acute and behavioral care. Not that we necessarily had a view that this is there with insurance industry would sort out, but we had a view that, look, we would need as much market power as possible to deal with payers of every stripe, government or private payers. So I think in general we're fairly comfortable with the market positions and market share percentages that we have in most of our markets. So in a very specific UHS sense, I don't know that we have any grave concerns about this payear consolidation dynamic. But I think as a provider, generally, we think that the payer consolidation will provide some limits and some restrictions on consumer choice and consumer cost, et cetera.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Lieberman with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Lieberman with Wells Fargo.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

componenttext: I think mostly have been taken. You were waiting for some California provider fees I think at the last quarter. Any update on those?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so those were approved and we did record them in the quarter, Gary. It's a relatively small number for us, probably $3 million or $4 million in the quarter. And for us, it was really just an acceleration of an item that we sort of guided to or assume
componenttext: Yes, so those were approved and we did record them in the quarter, Gary. It's a relatively small number for us, probably $3 million or $4 million in the quarter. And for us, it was really just an acceleration of an item that we sort of guided to or assumed would occur in the second half of the year. So it doesn't really affect our sort of full year guidance or full year expectations.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

componenttext: Got it. And then, Allen, maybe I'd be interested on your thoughts on the current deal [indiscernible] as President.

componenttext: Well, we have a very exciting 17th candidate. You heard about that I'm sure. There will be a debate on August 6, we'll see. And it's too early to really say much of anything. So we'll see.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dana Nentin of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dana Nentin of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I know you touched on this briefly, but is there any color you can provide on how surgical trends performed in the quarter, maybe inpatient versus outpatient?
componenttext: I know you touched on this briefly, but is there any color you can provide on how surgical trends performed in the quarter, maybe inpatient versus outpatient?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Dana. I mean we made the point -- I think we made it actually in the last 2 quarters, that the most interesting development from a surgical trend perspective is that inpatient surgical -- inpatient surgeries are growing faster than outpatient, reall
componenttext: Sure, Dana. I mean we made the point -- I think we made it actually in the last 2 quarters, that the most interesting development from a surgical trend perspective is that inpatient surgical -- inpatient surgeries are growing faster than outpatient, really for the first time in a very long time. And honestly that trend continued into Q2 as well. So that to me is the most interesting trend. And the only other thing I'd emphasize or point out is what I said to Ana is as we look at those surgical procedures, there's not a particular service or diagnosis that's really driving the growth. It tends to be fairly widespread, both geographically and service-line wise.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Whit Mayo with Robert Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Whit Mayo with Robert Baird.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I know you don't give quarterly guidance. But generally, you tend to earn about 21%, maybe 23% of your full year acute care EBITDA within the third quarter. And I think sometimes we forget about the seasonal earnings progression. Just any reason as
componenttext: Steve, I know you don't give quarterly guidance. But generally, you tend to earn about 21%, maybe 23% of your full year acute care EBITDA within the third quarter. And I think sometimes we forget about the seasonal earnings progression. Just any reason as you look at your internal budgets, that might be materially different this time around?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

componenttext: No, I think historical trend third quarter being the softest quarter for the hospital industry in general and certainly for us, I don't think we would see any reason why that wouldn't hold up in 2015 as well.

componenttext: No, we tend to the street sometimes seems to get a little ahead of you sometimes in the third quarter. Can you just comment on employment strategy. This hasn't really been a focus, I think, internally UHS is perhaps, others and that's perhaps a cultural dynamic in some of your markets. But where do you think you are in the industry within that particular cycle?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I always think -- I mean, to a couple of things. I don't think UHS sort of emphasizes it as we talk about the business as much as some of our peers. But it doesn't mean that we have not employed physicians. I think we view physician employment the way we
componenttext: I always think -- I mean, to a couple of things. I don't think UHS sort of emphasizes it as we talk about the business as much as some of our peers. But it doesn't mean that we have not employed physicians. I think we view physician employment the way we view a lot of our market strategies and market development and business development strategies in that they're very market-specific. So there are some markets in which we have a significant amount of physician employment. McAllen is one, Texoma is another. There are other markets like Las Vegas where in general the market has not seen a lot of physician employment for a variety of reasons. So we'll see. I mean we continue to do what we think is the most appropriate competitive thing in every market. We definitely have a view that physician integration is going to be more and more important as time goes on. And we certainly are doing what we can in that regard, in some cases employing physicians, in many cases, working with physicians to integrate our information technologies. We think that's a very important strategy. We'll continue to do that. But we'll also continue to be judicious about it because at the end of the day we think that most hospitals lose money on owned-physician practices. And obviously, that's an end results that if we can avoid, we prefer to avoid.

componenttext: So Jen, when we bought Signet, I think we have a view that as we model that acquisition, that rates from the NHS, which 95 plus-percent of our patients are NHS patients, would be relatively kind of flat to maybe up 1% for the foreseeable future on an annual basis. I don't think any of our current experience in our 9 months of ownership or so, has really made us think any differently about that. So I think our actual performance has kind of fit into that. And as we continue to think about the next few years, we still think that's the right way of thinking about the business. And so any growth from that business is much more likely to come from volume growth than it is from rate growth.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Regina, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Universal Health Services Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the conference over to Steve Filton. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Regina. Good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services' results for the second quarter ended June 30, 2015.During this conference call, Alan and I will be using words s
componenttext:
Thank you, Regina. Good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services' results for the second quarter ended June 30, 2015.
During this conference call, Alan and I will be using words such as believes, expects, anticipates, estimates and similar words that represent forecasts, projections and forward-looking statements. For anyone not familiar with the risks and uncertainties inherent in those forward-looking statements, I recommend a careful reading of the section on Risk Factors and Forward-looking Statements and Risk Factors in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014, and our Form 10-Q for the quarter ended March 31, 2015.
We would like to highlight just a couple of developments and business trends before opening the call up to questions.
As discussed in our press release last night, the company recorded net income attributable to UHS per diluted share of $1.80 for the quarter. After adjusting each quarter's reported results for the incentive income and expenses recorded in connection with the implementation of electronic health record applications at our acute care hospitals, as disclosed on the supplemental schedule included with last night's earnings release, adjusted net income attributable to UHS increased approximately 20% to $186.6 million or $1.85 per diluted share during the second quarter of 2015 as compared to $155.6 million or $1.55 per diluted share during the second quarter of last year.
On a same-facility basis in our acute division, revenues during the second quarter of 2015 increased 8.4% over last year's comparable quarter. The increase resulted primarily from a 5.7% increase in adjusted admissions to our hospitals owned for more than a year and a 3.2% increase in revenue per adjusted admission. On a same-facility basis, operating margins for our acute care hospitals increased to 19.8% during the second quarter of 2015 from 18.7% during the second quarter of 2014.
On a same-facility basis, net revenues in our behavioral health division increased 5.1% during the second quarter of 2015 as compared to the second quarter of 2014. During this year's second quarter as compared to last year, adjusted admissions to our behavioral health facilities owned for more than a year increased to 4.2% and adjusted patient days increased 0.6%. Revenue per adjusted patient day rose 4.1% during the second quarter of 2015 over the comparable prior year quarter.
Operating margins for our behavioral health hospitals owned for more than a year were 28.5% and 28.4% during the quarters ended June 30, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
For the 6 months ended June 30, 2015, our cash provided by operating activities increased approximately 16% to $532 million over the $458 million generated during the comparable 6-month period of 2014. Our accounts receivable days outstanding increased slightly to 54 days during the second quarter of 2015 as compared to 53 days during the second quarter of 2014.
At June 30, 2015, our ratio of debt to total capitalization decreased to 42.8% as compared to 47.0% at June 30, 2014. We spent $81 million on capital expenditures during the second quarter of 2015 and $171 million during the first six months of 2015.
Based upon the operating trends and financial results experienced during the first 6 months of 2015, we are increasing our estimated range of adjusted net income attributable to UHS for the year ended December 31, 2015, to $6.75 to $7.15 per diluted share. This revised guidance, which excludes the expected electronic health records impact for the year, represents an increase of approximately 9% to 10% from the previously provided range of $6.15 to $6.55 per diluted share. This guidance range, which is subject to certain conditions including those set forth in last night's earnings release, also excludes the impact of future items, if applicable, that are nonrecurring or nonoperational in nature including items such as, but not limited to: gains on sales of assets and businesses; cost related to extinguishment of debt; reserves for settlements; legal judgments and law suits; impairments of long-lived assets; impact of share repurchases; and other material amounts that may be reflected in our financial statements that relate to prior periods.
We would be pleased to answer your questions at this time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I wanted to just ask if you could comment on the factors impacting pricing on the acute care side and what your outlook is on that front for the second half of the year.
componenttext: Okay. I wanted to just ask if you could comment on the factors impacting pricing on the acute care side and what your outlook is on that front for the second half of the year.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Matt. So the 3-plus percent increase in revenue per adjusted admission was somewhat lower than we ran in the first quarter but still very much within our expectations. I think it continues to be driven mostly by an improved payer mix, less uninsured
componenttext: Sure, Matt. So the 3-plus percent increase in revenue per adjusted admission was somewhat lower than we ran in the first quarter but still very much within our expectations. I think it continues to be driven mostly by an improved payer mix, less uninsured patients. Clearly, our total uncompensated care declined for the quarter as it has for the last 6 quarters now, but we also, I think, in the second quarter had a pretty difficult comparison with the second quarter of last year. So we're -- again, we're pleased with that 3-plus percent revenue per unit growth. A lot of it being driven by increased government business, Medicaid -- more Medicaid patients as a result of the continued Medicaid expansion in those states that are participating and also increased Medicare utilization, which we reported as well in the first quarter of last year. Not sure I have a terribly insightful explanation for that, but I know that some of the managed care companies have reported a similar dynamic, but we definitely saw increased Medicare utilization in the quarter as well. So all of those factors, I think, contributed to the acute care revenue per unit growth.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Wouldn't the -- I'm sorry, I'm missing something here. But wouldn't the -- I mean, the higher Medicaid volumes displacing sort of charity care, uninsured, that makes sense on how that's going to positively impact the revenue per unit. But on the Medicare
componenttext: Wouldn't the -- I'm sorry, I'm missing something here. But wouldn't the -- I mean, the higher Medicaid volumes displacing sort of charity care, uninsured, that makes sense on how that's going to positively impact the revenue per unit. But on the Medicare side, is that just sort of the same mix even though, obviously, Medicare isn't expressly offsetting uninsured? I mean, Medicare is lower certainly in commercial when you think about the pricing mix.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you made the right point, and I probably should have been clear, Matt. So yes, I think to the degree that we've got increased insured business, whether it's government or commercial, versus uninsured business, clearly, that's driving the over
componenttext: Yes. I think you made the right point, and I probably should have been clear, Matt. So yes, I think to the degree that we've got increased insured business, whether it's government or commercial, versus uninsured business, clearly, that's driving the overall revenue per unit up. To the degree that we've got more Medicare and slightly less commercial, that tempers in some. Yes, that's correct.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. Sorry, I just wanted to make sure I wasn't missing something. And one last, in terms of the incremental volume improvement -- and you made the comments on Medicare, which is interesting. But do you still generally see that being 2/3 core econo
componenttext: Okay. Okay. Sorry, I just wanted to make sure I wasn't missing something. And one last, in terms of the incremental volume improvement -- and you made the comments on Medicare, which is interesting. But do you still generally see that being 2/3 core economy and 1/3 ACA?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Matt, we talked about this, I think, in Q1. And I think from our perspective, as each quarter passes, we sort of view the exercise of trying to parse out where volume growth is being generated, whether it's ACA-related or economy-related, becomes more and
componenttext: Matt, we talked about this, I think, in Q1. And I think from our perspective, as each quarter passes, we sort of view the exercise of trying to parse out where volume growth is being generated, whether it's ACA-related or economy-related, becomes more and more difficult. And honestly, from our perspective, sort of less and less meaningful. So I think in this quarter, we effectively sort of stopped doing that analysis and really are much more interested in things like geographies and service lines and payer mix and that sort of thing and really have focused a lot less on trying to sort of parse out exactly what's ACA-related.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. So this is Michael Ha for Sarah. Just kind of following up on Matt's question. Same-facility acute care adjusted admissions growth grew by 5.7%, the same growth in both 1Q and 2Q. And in 1Q, you mentioned those numbers, especially volume comps
componenttext: All right. So this is Michael Ha for Sarah. Just kind of following up on Matt's question. Same-facility acute care adjusted admissions growth grew by 5.7%, the same growth in both 1Q and 2Q. And in 1Q, you mentioned those numbers, especially volume comps were difficult to sustain moving through the year. So how should we be looking at this for the back half of the year?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look -- and I wish that we have perfect insight into that dynamic. You're absolutely right. So we've run 5.7% adjusted admission growth for the first half of the year. That is a really significant improvement over what we've been running. But I think if y
componenttext: Look -- and I wish that we have perfect insight into that dynamic. You're absolutely right. So we've run 5.7% adjusted admission growth for the first half of the year. That is a really significant improvement over what we've been running. But I think if you even look at it in the broader context and look at it back over multiple years and a decade or 2, I mean, that's at the high end of our business that is run at in its sort of best days. So I think to some degree, we have the view that it's going to be difficult to sustain that level of growth. We obviously will work hard to do so and are focused on doing it. But I think to be realistic about it and I think in the way that we crafted our by guidance for the balance of the year, we presume that, that growth slows some. And I was speaking with somebody last night and made the point that -- look, if we think acute care same-store revenue growth is 3% or 3.5% in the back half of the year, if you would ask us that a year ago or I think ask just about anybody observing the acute care business, they would have been pleased with that sort of growth. So I think we're looking for that volume growth to moderate some in the back half of the year, although we will certainly work hard to maintain what we've experienced in the first half.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Also, debt to EBITDA this quarter was lower sequentially. And you guys have mentioned previously that you wouldn't let that leverage continue any lower from current levels. Taking that into account and seeing that your M&A activity has been slower year-to
componenttext: Also, debt to EBITDA this quarter was lower sequentially. And you guys have mentioned previously that you wouldn't let that leverage continue any lower from current levels. Taking that into account and seeing that your M&A activity has been slower year-to-date versus peers, how do you see the pipeline compared to last year? Smaller or just as big?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's always hard to judge, but I do think that we have a sense that there is sort of an increased level of activity. We seem to be reviewing a number of deals or potential deals in both business segments. It's always hard to predict what might mat
componenttext: I think it's always hard to judge, but I do think that we have a sense that there is sort of an increased level of activity. We seem to be reviewing a number of deals or potential deals in both business segments. It's always hard to predict what might materialize or not materialize, but certainly. I think we've been up the mind that it looks to us like there may be more opportunities in the next 12 months than there have been in some time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Great. And just one last question. On the behavioral front, you saw an increase in length of stay sequentially. Is your conversion of residential beds to acute beds completed? And could that be the driver of the increase? Or do you believe this is
componenttext: Great. Great. And just one last question. On the behavioral front, you saw an increase in length of stay sequentially. Is your conversion of residential beds to acute beds completed? And could that be the driver of the increase? Or do you believe this is more related to a stabilizing trend of length of stay that's starting to pick up?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think you have to be careful of what you look at. If you look at length of stay on a same-store basis, it's still down 3.5% or so from last year. If you look at it on a total divisional basis, it's up, but I think that's largely because it inclu
componenttext: Yes. So I think you have to be careful of what you look at. If you look at length of stay on a same-store basis, it's still down 3.5% or so from last year. If you look at it on a total divisional basis, it's up, but I think that's largely because it includes the U.K. facilities, which clearly have a longer length of stay. So I would sort of echo many of the statements that we made in Q1, which is we still see length of stay declining some, although we also believe that some of that decline is kind of self-imposed or self-initiated as we convert more beds from residential to acute. So -- and which I think is reflected in the fact that even though we have lower length of stay and lower patient days, we have a higher revenue per day. The 4-plus percent revenue per day growth is, I think, among the best that we've seen in some time and again, I think, is reflective of our efforts to convert from residential to acute beds.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of A.J. Rice with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of A.J. Rice with UBS.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe first, I'll just ask you to comment a little bit on the geographies. Obviously, with the strong results, you're probably seeing strength across the board. But is there anything to call out on geographies in particular? And maybe in addition to Vegas
componenttext: Maybe first, I'll just ask you to comment a little bit on the geographies. Obviously, with the strong results, you're probably seeing strength across the board. But is there anything to call out on geographies in particular? And maybe in addition to Vegas and Texas, which you always talk about, anything on the new facilities and how they're coming online that you've analyzed that you had in the last year or so?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, A.J. So I think your comment is well taken in the sense that I think when you have almost 6% same-store adjusted admission growth and over 8% same-store revenue growth in the acute division, you're basically -- I think I have to assume, and I think
componenttext: Sure, A.J. So I think your comment is well taken in the sense that I think when you have almost 6% same-store adjusted admission growth and over 8% same-store revenue growth in the acute division, you're basically -- I think I have to assume, and I think it will be correct to assume that there's pretty strong performance across the portfolio. It'd be difficult if there weren't to post those kind of numbers. On the other hand, what we did in Q1 was we called out the performance of the Vegas market and the Riverside County market in California. Those 2 markets again, I would say, outperformed the divisional averages in Q2. And that includes sort of, to your question, that Temecula facility which has been open for about 1.5 years, maybe a little longer at this point. But I think what's really impressive about that Riverside County market is not only Temecula is doing quite a bit better than it did last year, probably not a surprise, and so we're just ramping up, but our other hospitals in that market are also doing better. So that's a really strong market in addition to the Vegas market, which continues to outperform. And I think that's also within our expectations in the sense that through several years of the recession, we talked about what a drag the Vegas market was for us. It was -- we were so used to it being an outperforming market that the difficulties and the high unemployment in that market were a real struggle for us. But as the market has improved and as unemployment has dropped in the Las Vegas market to like 6.5% from the high 15% at the height of the recession, I think our business has in turn improved both volume-wise and payer mix-wise, and so we see that. The flip side is, I think, the Texas market was a little bit slower. Again, I think that's a relative term. It's still up. It still has positive volume growth. But in terms of our different geographies, it's probably performing under the average, whereas Vegas and California are performing over the average.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just switching gears for a follow-up on this site business side. Since the first quarter, there's been this proposed rule out of CMS mainly related to Medicaid managed care, but it does incorporate some language around at least partially a
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just switching gears for a follow-up on this site business side. Since the first quarter, there's been this proposed rule out of CMS mainly related to Medicaid managed care, but it does incorporate some language around at least partially alleviating the IMD inclusion that's impacted your site business. So can you give us a little flavor for what the impact of that would be if it goes ahead and gets implemented? And any thoughts on timing on when we might see that actually happen?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, as you suggest, I mean, that rule was issued, I believe, at the beginning -- sort of early June, if I'm remembering correctly. And as a consequence, CMS can't issue a finalized rule until early August and has -- that's sort of the earliest the
componenttext: Sure. Well, as you suggest, I mean, that rule was issued, I believe, at the beginning -- sort of early June, if I'm remembering correctly. And as a consequence, CMS can't issue a finalized rule until early August and has -- that's sort of the earliest they could do it. They can certainly do it after that. What the rule would do, and I think it was pressed for, quite frankly, by the managed Medicaid companies, is it would allow those companies to contract with whoever they chose based on certain conditions, but they would be able to contract for adult Medicaid patients regardless of the IMD exclusion rule. So we certainly believe that if that rule is finalized in anything close to the form that it was proposed, and depending on when it is effective, we will certainly get a benefit from that. Difficult for us to quantify what that benefit is because we've never had those patients really before. So it's mostly guesstimate work at this point, but we're certainly looking forward to the final rule being issued and starting to contract with those managed Medicaid companies for their adult Medicaid patients. We view that as a nice potential tailwind for this business. So we're anxiously awaiting the issuance of the rule.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
