headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. So this is Michael Ha for Sarah. Just kind of following up on Matt's question. Same-facility acute care adjusted admissions growth grew by 5.7%, the same growth in both 1Q and 2Q. And in 1Q, you mentioned those numbers, especially volume comps
componenttext: All right. So this is Michael Ha for Sarah. Just kind of following up on Matt's question. Same-facility acute care adjusted admissions growth grew by 5.7%, the same growth in both 1Q and 2Q. And in 1Q, you mentioned those numbers, especially volume comps were difficult to sustain moving through the year. So how should we be looking at this for the back half of the year?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look -- and I wish that we had perfect insight into that dynamic. You're absolutely right. So we've run 5.7% adjusted admission growth for the first half of the year. That is a really significant improvement over what we've been running. But I think if yo
componenttext: Look -- and I wish that we had perfect insight into that dynamic. You're absolutely right. So we've run 5.7% adjusted admission growth for the first half of the year. That is a really significant improvement over what we've been running. But I think if you even look at it in the broader context and look at it back over multiple years and a decade or 2, I mean, that's at the high end of our business that is run at in its sort of best days. So I think to some degree, we have the view that it's going to be difficult to sustain that level of growth. We obviously will work hard to do so and are focused on doing it. But I think to be realistic about it and I think in the way that we crafted our by guidance for the balance of the year, we presume that, that growth slows some. And I was speaking with somebody last night and made the point that -- look, if we think acute care same-store revenue growth is 3% or 3.5% in the back half of the year, if you would ask us that a year ago or I think ask just about anybody observing the acute care business, they would have been pleased with that sort of growth. So I think we're looking for that volume growth to moderate some in the back half of the year, although we will certainly work hard to maintain what we've experienced in the first half.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Also, debt to EBITDA this quarter was lower sequentially. And you guys have mentioned previously that you wouldn't let that leverage continue any lower from current levels. Taking that into account and seeing that your M&A activity has been slower year-to
componenttext: Also, debt to EBITDA this quarter was lower sequentially. And you guys have mentioned previously that you wouldn't let that leverage continue any lower from current levels. Taking that into account and seeing that your M&A activity has been slower year-to-date versus peers, how do you see the pipeline compared to last year? Smaller or just as big?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's always hard to judge, but I do think that we have a sense that there is sort of an increased level of activity. We seem to be reviewing a number of deals or potential deals in both business segments. It's always hard to predict what might mat
componenttext: I think it's always hard to judge, but I do think that we have a sense that there is sort of an increased level of activity. We seem to be reviewing a number of deals or potential deals in both business segments. It's always hard to predict what might materialize or not materialize, but certainly. I think we've been of the mind that it looks to us like there may be more opportunities in the next 12 months than there have been in some time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Great. And just one last question. On the behavioral front, you saw an increase in length of stay sequentially. Is your conversion of residential beds to acute beds completed? And could that be the driver of the increase? Or do you believe this is
componenttext: Great. Great. And just one last question. On the behavioral front, you saw an increase in length of stay sequentially. Is your conversion of residential beds to acute beds completed? And could that be the driver of the increase? Or do you believe this is more related to a stabilizing trend of length of stay that's starting to pick up?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think you have to be careful of what you look at. If you look at length of stay on a same-store basis, it's still down 3.5% or so from last year. If you look at it on a total divisional basis, it's up, but I think that's largely because it inclu
componenttext: Yes. So I think you have to be careful of what you look at. If you look at length of stay on a same-store basis, it's still down 3.5% or so from last year. If you look at it on a total divisional basis, it's up, but I think that's largely because it includes the U.K. facilities, which clearly have a longer length of stay. So I would sort of echo many of the statements that we made in Q1, which is we still see length of stay declining some, although we also believe that some of that decline is kind of self-imposed or self-initiated as we convert more beds from residential to acute. So -- and which I think is reflected in the fact that even though we have lower length of stay and lower patient days, we have a higher revenue per day. The 4-plus percent revenue per day growth is, I think, among the best that we've seen in some time and again, I think, is reflective of our efforts to convert from residential to acute beds.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of A.J. Rice with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of A.J. Rice with UBS.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe first, I'll just ask you to comment a little bit on the geographies. Obviously, with the strong results, you're probably seeing strength across the board. But is there anything to call out on geographies in particular? And maybe in addition to Vegas
componenttext: Maybe first, I'll just ask you to comment a little bit on the geographies. Obviously, with the strong results, you're probably seeing strength across the board. But is there anything to call out on geographies in particular? And maybe in addition to Vegas and Texas, which you always talk about, anything on the new facilities and how they're coming online that you've analyzed that you had in the last year or so?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, A.J. So I think your comment is well taken in the sense that I think when you have almost 6% same-store adjusted admission growth and over 8% same-store revenue growth in the acute division, you're basically -- I think have to assume, and I think it
componenttext: Sure, A.J. So I think your comment is well taken in the sense that I think when you have almost 6% same-store adjusted admission growth and over 8% same-store revenue growth in the acute division, you're basically -- I think have to assume, and I think it will be correct to assume that there's pretty strong performance across the portfolio. It'd be difficult if there weren't to post those kind of numbers. On the other hand, what we did in Q1 was we called out the performance of the Vegas market and the Riverside County market in California. Those 2 markets again, I would say, outperformed the divisional averages in Q2. And that includes sort of, to your question, the Temecula facility which has been open for about 1.5 years, maybe a little longer at this point. But I think what's really impressive about that Riverside County market is not only Temecula is doing quite a bit better than it did last year, probably not a surprise, and so we're just ramping up, but our other hospitals in that market are also doing better. So that's a really strong market in addition to the Vegas market, which continues to outperform. And I think that's also within our expectations in the sense that through several years of the recession, we talked about what a drag the Vegas market was for us. It was -- we were so used to it being an outperforming market that the difficulties and the high unemployment in that market were a real struggle for us. But as the market has improved and as unemployment has dropped in the Las Vegas market to like 6.5% from the high of 15% at the height of the recession, I think our business has in turn improved both volume-wise and payer mix-wise, and so we see that. The flip side is, I think, the Texas market was a little bit slower. Again, I think that's a relative term. It's still up. It still has positive volume growth. But in terms of our different geographies, it's probably performing under the average, whereas Vegas and California are performing over the average.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just switching gears for a follow-up on this site business side. Since the first quarter, there's been this proposed rule out of CMS mainly related to Medicaid managed care, but it does incorporate some language around at least partially a
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just switching gears for a follow-up on this site business side. Since the first quarter, there's been this proposed rule out of CMS mainly related to Medicaid managed care, but it does incorporate some language around at least partially alleviating the IMD exclusion that's impacted your psych business. So can you give us a little flavor for what the impact of that would be if it goes ahead and gets implemented? And any thoughts on timing on when we might see that actually happen?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, as you suggest, I mean, that rule was issued, I believe, at the beginning -- sort of early June, if I'm remembering correctly. And as a consequence, CMS can't issue a finalized rule until early August and has -- that's sort of the earliest the
componenttext: Sure. Well, as you suggest, I mean, that rule was issued, I believe, at the beginning -- sort of early June, if I'm remembering correctly. And as a consequence, CMS can't issue a finalized rule until early August and has -- that's sort of the earliest they could do it. They can certainly do it after that. What the rule would do, and I think it was pressed for, quite frankly, by the managed Medicaid companies, is it would allow those companies to contract with whoever they chose based on certain conditions, but they would be able to contract for adult Medicaid patients regardless of the IMD exclusion rule. So we certainly believe that if that rule is finalized in anything close to the form that it was proposed, and depending on when it is effective, we will certainly get a benefit from that. Difficult for us to quantify what that benefit is because we've never had those patients really before. So it's mostly guesstimate work at this point, but we're certainly looking forward to the final rule being issued and starting to contract with those managed Medicaid companies for their adult Medicaid patients. We view that as a nice potential tailwind for this business. So we're anxiously awaiting the issuance of the rule.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Josh Raskin with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Josh Raskin with Barclays.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: The first question, just on the expense side of things. Overall, seeing good control there. I'm just curious, are you seeing anything in terms of wages in your markets -- in any markets specifically? Any pressures, et cetera, on wage growth?
componenttext: The first question, just on the expense side of things. Overall, seeing good control there. I'm just curious, are you seeing anything in terms of wages in your markets -- in any markets specifically? Any pressures, et cetera, on wage growth?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, I think it's always a competitive market, Josh, and I don't think that's really changed. But I think if you look at it, one of the reasons why acute care margins are up is that when revenue increases and when volume increases the way that it does, t
componenttext: Look, I think it's always a competitive market, Josh, and I don't think that's really changed. But I think if you look at it, one of the reasons why acute care margins are up is that when revenue increases and when volume increases the way that it does, there is just the nature of the hospital operating model is there is, for efficient providers, there is usually a fair amount of operating leverage to be exercised. And I think our operators deserve credit for doing so. So yes, I mean, clearly, as a percentage of revenue, our salaries are down, and we're exercising some of that leverage, even though I do believe that there is a fair amount of wage pressure in some of our markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And -- but it sounded like you don't think that's changed, that wage pressure, nothing you would call out relative to, say, last year?
componenttext: Okay. And -- but it sounded like you don't think that's changed, that wage pressure, nothing you would call out relative to, say, last year?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think there's been significant developments. No.
componenttext: No, I don't think there's been significant developments. No.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the psych side of the business, have you guys thought about other lines, the ancillary sort of services beyond just the operation of the actual psych facility?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the psych side of the business, have you guys thought about other lines, the ancillary sort of services beyond just the operation of the actual psych facility?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'm not exactly sure what that implies. I mean, again, we do offer a wide array of behavioral services. We tend to talk about them in terms of acute and residential, but we're one of the largest provider of specialty behavioral services and have been f
componenttext: So I'm not exactly sure what that implies. I mean, again, we do offer a wide array of behavioral services. We tend to talk about them in terms of acute and residential, but we're one of the largest provider of specialty behavioral services and have been for a long time, specializing in things like eating disorders and sexual trauma and all kinds of other specialties. And so we continue to do that, and I think we'll continue to do so. I know that addiction treatment is kind of a hot topic in the industry, but we've been -- we probably have 8 or 9 facilities that have -- are dedicated to CD and addiction treatment. We also have, for a long time now, had a real emphasis on supporting behavioral disorders within the military. We have what we call our Patriot Support Program, and that is a program that is fairly widespread throughout the division. So in terms of service lines, I think we touch on most of them and continue to look for ways to expand them. Autism is another one that we have clearly emphasized more in the last few years. In terms of other behavioral-related services, we have outpatient services in a number of our markets. Not really sure what else you might be alluding to, but we're always open to ways, as the largest behavioral inpatient provider in the country, always looking for ways to enhance and kind of make that position more robust. So I think we're open to just about everything.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Rigg with Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Rigg with Susquehanna Financial.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I know at this point, you're kind of saying it's a fruitless exercise to try to isolate ACA-driven strength. But at the same time, I guess, people are still trying to get a sense for how much that could be helping you out in the industry. So is it possibl
componenttext: I know at this point, you're kind of saying it's a fruitless exercise to try to isolate ACA-driven strength. But at the same time, I guess, people are still trying to get a sense for how much that could be helping you out in the industry. So is it possible to sort of -- when you think about the pockets of volume strength in commercial, Medicare, Medicaid, where the relative outperformance was in those buckets where you saw the most pronounced improvement year-to-year volume trends?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean -- and I suspect my answer will still be unsatisfactory for you, Chris, in the sense that -- I think what we have said for a while is that look, we assume that the growth in our Medicaid patient base and utilization is related at least, in lar
componenttext: Yes. I mean -- and I suspect my answer will still be unsatisfactory for you, Chris, in the sense that -- I think what we have said for a while is that look, we assume that the growth in our Medicaid patient base and utilization is related at least, in large part, to Medicaid expansion. We see it quite clearly most dramatically in those states, Nevada, California, the District of Columbia, that have participated in Medicaid expansion. Although as others have noted, we have seen Medicaid utilization increases in our nonexpansion states as well. I guess, most people refer to that as the woodwork effect, and we certainly have seen that as well. Some of the commercial growth clearly comes from expansion patients. That's the trickiest part for us. It has not always been easy for us to identify exactly who is a commercial exchange patient and who is just a regular commercial patient. So that's where I think we have always felt was the greatest level of imprecision. And then as I said in the last couple of quarters, we have clearly seen an increase in our Medicare utilization, which is difficult for us, quite frankly, to attribute either to the ACA impact or, quite frankly, to economic improvement only because historically, our Medicare utilization has been relatively insensitive to that -- those sort of factors. But that's kind of where we have seen our payer mix go.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one big picture question. I guess, with King, Burwell behind us, there is a theory that, that's sort of a -- that's going to -- that's a catalyst for additional states to opt into Medicaid. Hello?
componenttext: Okay. And then one big picture question. I guess, with King, Burwell behind us, there is a theory that, that's sort of a -- that's going to -- that's a catalyst for additional states to opt into Medicaid. Hello?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Chris.
componenttext: Go ahead, Chris.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Oh, all right. That's a catalyst for states to opt into Medicaid expansion sooner rather than later. I guess, can you give us your take as to whether that really is a game changer and that you will see states move to expand Medicaid over the near term ver
componenttext: Oh, all right. That's a catalyst for states to opt into Medicaid expansion sooner rather than later. I guess, can you give us your take as to whether that really is a game changer and that you will see states move to expand Medicaid over the near term versus just keep delaying it?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, honestly, Chris, I wish I could predict this very accurately. I mean, in our case, I think you're really talking about a couple of states that really make the difference. For us, the 2 states that have not chosen to participate in Medicaid ex
componenttext: Yes. I mean, honestly, Chris, I wish I could predict this very accurately. I mean, in our case, I think you're really talking about a couple of states that really make the difference. For us, the 2 states that have not chosen to participate in Medicaid expansion that I think would make a significant difference in our acute care operations would be Florida and Texas. I think all sorts of people have speculated on the likelihood that those states might or might not choose to do so in the future. I don't know whether the Supreme Court ruling really makes that more likely or not. I don't think we just have a view that in either of those states that Medicaid expansion is going to take place imminently. So we continue to work for it along with the state hospital associations and others in those states, but I wouldn't make a prediction as to how likely that is.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is actually Joanna Gajuk filling in for Kevin today. So I just want to come back a little bit to the question earlier about the capital deployment. And I guess, you talked about interest in other, I guess, areas in psych. But is there anything on the
componenttext: This is actually Joanna Gajuk filling in for Kevin today. So I just want to come back a little bit to the question earlier about the capital deployment. And I guess, you talked about interest in other, I guess, areas in psych. But is there anything on the acute care side terms of the deals that you might be considering? Or maybe outside of acute, any sort of outpatient sites you're also looking to add? Or any color around the capital deployment here or whether maybe you will focus on increasing your CapEx spending?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Joanna, just to be clear about what I said, I was clear about saying that we have seen an increased number of opportunities in both the business segments, both acute and behavioral. And I think it's in both cases sort of across the continuum. Meaning,
componenttext: So Joanna, just to be clear about what I said, I was clear about saying that we have seen an increased number of opportunities in both the business segments, both acute and behavioral. And I think it's in both cases sort of across the continuum. Meaning, it's hospitals, it may be outpatient facilities, it may be physician-type practices. And we're exploring all those items. I think the landscape of health care is such that it's changing and that payers and employers are looking for more comprehensive and coordinated continuum of care and looking for sort of the ability to go to 1 or 2 providers who can really kind of sort of provide that. So we're very focused on that in both of the divisions, and I think that it creates, I think, a universe of opportunities that is broader than what we necessarily have been used to for the last few years. So we'll say now again, I -- as I also said before, I think it's always difficult to predict how this is going to sort out and what will really become actionable and what won't. But I think we're very focused on what those opportunities might be, again in both business segments.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. And then on the -- more on the policy side here. Can you comment about the proposed mandatory joint replacement demonstration? Or the bundle that came out, how do you feel it could impact the industry and your business in particular? And also m
componenttext: All right. And then on the -- more on the policy side here. Can you comment about the proposed mandatory joint replacement demonstration? Or the bundle that came out, how do you feel it could impact the industry and your business in particular? And also maybe recently, on the, I guess, the set of hospital payment reforms that came out from the House Ways and Means Committee. Just recently, I know it's -- just very early stages. But any color you can give us will be helpful.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Joanna, I'm not going to sort of comment on this really specific developments in part because I don't know that we've had a full opportunity to review them, but I'm going to just sort of reiterate a little bit and maybe expand on the comment I have made b
componenttext: Joanna, I'm not going to sort of comment on this really specific developments in part because I don't know that we've had a full opportunity to review them, but I'm going to just sort of reiterate a little bit and maybe expand on the comment I have made before. We certainly have a view that the reimbursement mechanisms that have been sort of the historic ones for the industry are changing. They're changing, I think, incrementally, and I think that change will continue to be incremental. But we are doing great many things to prepare for that, to prepare for things like accepting bundled payments and accepting capitated payments in some very limited instances, et cetera, because I think we do think that's at least part of the future of the industry. And so we're very focused on that. Now exactly what form that's going to take, to what degree the government is going to initiate that or the initiation will really come from the private sector, hard for us to predict at this moment, but I will tell you, and there's probably not enough time in the context of this call to discuss it meaningfully, but we've got a number of initiatives underway to make sure that we are absolutely prepared for that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gurda with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gurda with KeyBanc.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I just heard in the news that the Doctors Hospital of Renaissance had filed to expand or double the size of a number of the beds, but they have to get approval from CMS. Do you have any sense for how likely that is?
componenttext: Steve, I just heard in the news that the Doctors Hospital of Renaissance had filed to expand or double the size of a number of the beds, but they have to get approval from CMS. Do you have any sense for how likely that is?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: We don't. As you might imagine, there are others in the market, I think, who are sort of questioning the appropriateness of that. And so CMS will have to weigh, I think, a number of different factors as they think about that. But we've -- for those who ha
componenttext: We don't. As you might imagine, there are others in the market, I think, who are sort of questioning the appropriateness of that. And so CMS will have to weigh, I think, a number of different factors as they think about that. But we've -- for those who have followed us for a long time, know that the physician-owned hospital in the McAllen market is a formidable competitor of ours. When they first opened, we had a fairly significant diminution in our earnings in that market. We regained a lot of that over the years and done a number of things to strengthen our position in the market, including a number of physician integration strategies, a number of physical strategies, physical improvements. And again, I think we feel like we're well positioned in the market regardless of what the physician hospital ultimately is able to do.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'm not sure if you're going to want to comment on this or not, but I'd be interested in hearing maybe an update on your relationship of working with EmCare.
componenttext: Okay. I'm not sure if you're going to want to comment on this or not, but I'd be interested in hearing maybe an update on your relationship of working with EmCare.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, EmCare is the emergency room provider in probably the majority of our acute care hospitals, and they provide some other physician contract services in some of our hospitals as well. As with any sort of contract service vendor, we work closely
componenttext: Yes, I mean, EmCare is the emergency room provider in probably the majority of our acute care hospitals, and they provide some other physician contract services in some of our hospitals as well. As with any sort of contract service vendor, we work closely with them to try and provide services that are both satisfactory to our patients and to our other physicians as well as, from our perspective, cost-efficient. And look, I think EmCare is a good solid company. We'll continue to work with them. But as always, we will continue to explore all the alternatives to increase patient satisfaction and increase our cost efficiency at the same time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question will come from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Next question will come from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to focus on the U.K. for a second. Just wondering how that business is progressing in the behavioral side. Are you happy with it? And maybe how much of that business is contributing to your overall behavior revenue? And what are some of the
componenttext: I just wanted to focus on the U.K. for a second. Just wondering how that business is progressing in the behavioral side. Are you happy with it? And maybe how much of that business is contributing to your overall behavior revenue? And what are some of the growth plans there for the next 12 months?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Paula, I think that we -- so we talked a little bit in Q1, and I'll largely repeat those comments in the sense that when we bought Cygnet in the U.K. late in the third quarter of '14, they were already operating at what we considered to be high oc
componenttext: Yes. So Paula, I think that we -- so we talked a little bit in Q1, and I'll largely repeat those comments in the sense that when we bought Cygnet in the U.K. late in the third quarter of '14, they were already operating at what we considered to be high occupancy levels, probably around 80%, maybe the low 80s. We've been extremely pleased because I think they're now operating at close to 90%. And so while we didn't think there was a tremendous opportunity for improvement. Based on our short period of ownership, have already experienced some fairly significant incremental improvement that has been very beneficial. I will say that -- look, at the end of the day, we acquired a company that had a roughly $170 million, $180 million of revenues and $40 million of EBITDA, something like that. So it's not a terribly material part of our behavioral business or certainly of our consolidated results at the moment, but we also viewed it as a platform for growth. We have already, in the short time we've owned them, announced small acquisition and a number of bed expansion opportunities, both kind of de novo facilities as well as incremental bed expansions in existing facilities. So I think it is turning out to be everything that we expected it would be and maybe more. And the hope is that it continues to be a platform for growth in the future and that we will continue to expand both the existing facilities as well as find other opportunities to acquire streams of EBITDA in that market.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow-up to that. 90% occupancy is certainly high. And I know you mentioned de novos and bed expansions, so that should help sort of fill in some of that demand. But wondering on the acquisition front, are there some larger players still in
componenttext: And just as a follow-up to that. 90% occupancy is certainly high. And I know you mentioned de novos and bed expansions, so that should help sort of fill in some of that demand. But wondering on the acquisition front, are there some larger players still in that market that you could think about acquiring? And what are some of your thoughts there, I guess, in terms of how big you want to actually take this business?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, the challenge when asked anywhere, whether it's in the U.K. or in the U.S. about acquiring other consolidated players is -- -- unfortunately, that decision is largely up to those other players. There are other consolidated players in the U.K.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, the challenge when asked anywhere, whether it's in the U.K. or in the U.S. about acquiring other consolidated players is -- -- unfortunately, that decision is largely up to those other players. There are other consolidated players in the U.K., and we certainly are doing our best to stay in touch with those players. And to a degree that any of those players decide that they are looking to pursue some other strategy, whether it's an exit strategy or a joint venture strategy or some sort of partnership to develop new facilities, we'd be interested in all of those opportunities. So the difficulty of sort of pegging kind of a likelihood of that is, again, this is largely dependent on what somebody else wants to do or chooses to do. So for the most part, although we try to stay on top of it, we have to be reactive to that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Just one last one maybe for me. Certainly, a very strong first half. You raised guidance, and it seems like the second half, you're still taking a little bit more of a prudent approach. So just wondering, what type of metrics do we need to se
componenttext: Okay, great. Just one last one maybe for me. Certainly, a very strong first half. You raised guidance, and it seems like the second half, you're still taking a little bit more of a prudent approach. So just wondering, what type of metrics do we need to see on the revenue side to maybe hit the high mark in that EPS guidance?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I would say that to get to the high end of the EPS guidance, Paula, we'd have to sustain most of the metrics that you've seen in the first quarter, including the volume growth, which I think is probably the most aggressive piece of it, as I mentioned b
componenttext: So I would say that to get to the high end of the EPS guidance, Paula, we'd have to sustain most of the metrics that you've seen in the first quarter, including the volume growth, which I think is probably the most aggressive piece of it, as I mentioned before. I think realistically, we have assumed that there will be some tempering of that volume growth. And I would suggest that the midpoint of our guidance sort of is -- would sort of suggest that there is at least a bit of tempering of that sort of growth. I think the high end is -- would be more of a continuation of all the trends that we've seen in the first half.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ana Gupte with Leerink Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ana Gupte with Leerink Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to again tease out sort of the elements of what were the drivers of the guidance raise. And some of this might be a repetition or at least a follow-up of what others have already asked. But in February, you were pretty conservative. The pull-t
componenttext: So I wanted to again tease out sort of the elements of what were the drivers of the guidance raise. And some of this might be a repetition or at least a follow-up of what others have already asked. But in February, you were pretty conservative. The pull-through to EBITDA was weaker than the Street expected. So firstly, on the new raised guidance this time, is this because the exchange enrollment that you had factored in was lower than what eventually manifested itself? Or are you more confident at this point, at the midpoint of the year, on the economic recovery as the driver of the volume?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, again, Ana, a little bit of your question is sort of based on this idea of what's driving the improvement. And not to be repetitive, but I think we struggle ourselves with exactly what is driving the improvement. I would say again, what makes us c
componenttext: I mean, again, Ana, a little bit of your question is sort of based on this idea of what's driving the improvement. And not to be repetitive, but I think we struggle ourselves with exactly what is driving the improvement. I would say again, what makes us confident about raising guidance after the first half of the year is simply the acute care performance, which clearly was an outperformance in the first half, it's really based on the strong revenue growth. And I think that strong revenue growth is really driven by this 5.7% increase in adjusted admissions, which honestly, is well above what we were guiding to and what we were budgeting for when the year began. And as I sort of suggested in my answer to Paula, I think that's the sort of trickiest variable from our perspective as we think about the back half of the year. We certainly believe that our acute care demand will continue. It will be strong. Whether it will be quite as strong as the 5.7%, which again, I'm going to make the point, is really at the very high end of our historical trends, not just us as a company, but us as an industry. Whether that can continue, I'm not clear, and again, we've tempered a little bit in our guidance. But I think that's what's really driving the confidence here is that strong, very consistent performance in the first half of the year and especially in Q2 when I think the comparisons were far more difficult.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then on the Medicare utilization that you alluded to that's accelerating, I know the payer mix is not that clear at all times. But any color on whether this is from the Medicare Advantage side of it versus the government Medicare itself? And any color
componenttext: And then on the Medicare utilization that you alluded to that's accelerating, I know the payer mix is not that clear at all times. But any color on whether this is from the Medicare Advantage side of it versus the government Medicare itself? And any color on the types of the acuity and the types of procedures and services that are interesting in Medicare?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we always look at our Medicare and Medicaid blocks of business in total, and we look at them as both the managed portion and the traditional portion in part because there's certainly a continuing shift of patients from the traditional Medicaid an
componenttext: Sure. So we always look at our Medicare and Medicaid blocks of business in total, and we look at them as both the managed portion and the traditional portion in part because there's certainly a continuing shift of patients from the traditional Medicaid and Medicare programs to the managed Medicare and Medicaid programs. So if I were to answer the question directly like that, I would say no. Clearly, the increase in Medicare utilization is coming from an increase in Medicare Advantage patients. But I don't know that, that's all that meaningful because clearly, there are just more Medicare Advantage patients today than there were a year ago or 2 years ago, whatever. But the overall -- we're seeing more total Medicare and total Medicaid patients, that to me is the meaningful dynamic. In terms of who those patients are and what's driving them, as we review our service lines, as we review our surgical lines, et cetera, we see strength really across the board: orthopedics, cardiology, oncology, and all the service lines that are traditional sort of Medicare-intensive service lines. So I wouldn't point to a particular procedure or diagnosis, et cetera, that's really driving this strength, but I think it's pretty much across the board.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. On the Texas economy and the Medicaid concern that you had in February, it seems like the oil and gas -- and I know you are not fully levered to those geographies. But just broadly speaking, the layoffs haven't abated. If anything, th
componenttext: That's very helpful. On the Texas economy and the Medicaid concern that you had in February, it seems like the oil and gas -- and I know you are not fully levered to those geographies. But just broadly speaking, the layoffs haven't abated. If anything, they're accelerating. Are you comfortable at this point that there will not be any Medicaid funding pressures? Or might we see that further down the line?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think the answer is a little bit of both. I think -- we don't think there's any immediate threat to our reimbursement funding in the state of Texas. I think that's always -- over the long term, you look out, the more uncertainty there might be.
componenttext: Yes. So I think the answer is a little bit of both. I think -- we don't think there's any immediate threat to our reimbursement funding in the state of Texas. I think that's always -- over the long term, you look out, the more uncertainty there might be. We have seen -- in an earlier question or in response to an earlier question, I said that our Texas markets have performed a little bit more modestly than some of our other markets like Vegas and California. So I don't know if that's the economic impact of a slightly slowing economy. Honestly, Texas is a big state, and we're only in a handful of markets in this state. So I don't know whether our performance or our experience is necessarily reflective of what's going on more broadly. But for us at least, Texas has slowed a little bit. Again, I made a point earlier that's a relative term. Our Texas markets are ahead of last year both volume-wise and earnings-wise, but not quite as much ahead as some of those -- as some of our other markets like California and Vegas.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then one final one, if I may. On the consolidation that's now been announced in managed care, out of the 2 deals, the 2 mega deals, would you see both as potentially impacting the pricing dynamic? One is more of a complementary rather than an overlapp
componenttext: And then one final one, if I may. On the consolidation that's now been announced in managed care, out of the 2 deals, the 2 mega deals, would you see both as potentially impacting the pricing dynamic? One is more of a complementary rather than an overlapping commercial-only story; the other one is commercial. Any thoughts on that? And what might be the strategic response from the hospital industry?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, it's difficult to respond. I think first of all, I think the industry, the provider industry, broadly will, I think, raise questions about the lack of competitiveness or diminution in competitiveness that these transactions might drive. And I thin
componenttext: I mean, it's difficult to respond. I think first of all, I think the industry, the provider industry, broadly will, I think, raise questions about the lack of competitiveness or diminution in competitiveness that these transactions might drive. And I think one of the things the industry will point out is that it may not necessarily be -- the most appropriate way to look at this may not simply be on a service line business that, I think, when an insurer in a market gets increased commercial lives and increased Medicare lives at the same time, that increases their market power in the market, even though they might be 2 different service lines. So I think the industry as a whole will make those points as the government reviews these transactions. And I certainly am not smart enough to know how that's going to play out. I think for us, individually, we tend to look at these things very much on a market-by-market basis. We have spent and have focused a lot of our internal efforts over the last decade or 2 at enhancing and increasing our market positions in all of our markets, both acute and behavioral care. Not that we necessarily had a view that this is the way the insurance industry would sort out, but we had a view that -- look, we would need as much market power as possible to deal with payers of every stripe, both government and private payers. And so I think in general, we're fairly comfortable with the market positions and market share percentages that we have in most of our markets. So in a very specific UHS sense, I don't know that we have any grave concerns about this payer consolidation dynamic. But I think as a provider, generally, we think that payer consolidation will provide some limits and some restrictions on consumer choice and consumer cost, et cetera.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Dana. I mean, we made the point -- I think we've made it actually in the last 2 quarters -- that the most interesting development from a surgical trend perspective is that inpatient surgical -- inpatient surgeries are growing faster than outpatient
componenttext: Sure, Dana. I mean, we made the point -- I think we've made it actually in the last 2 quarters -- that the most interesting development from a surgical trend perspective is that inpatient surgical -- inpatient surgeries are growing faster than outpatient really for the first time in a very long time. And honestly, that trend continued into Q2 as well. So that to me is the most interesting trend. And then the only other thing I'd emphasize or point out is what I said to Ana that as we look at those surgical procedures, there's not a particular service line or a diagnosis that's really driving the growth. It tends to be fairly widespread, both geographically and service line-wise.

componenttext: Steve, I know you don't give quarterly guidance, but generally, you tend to earn about 21% to maybe 23% of your full year acute care EBITDA within the third quarter. And I think sometimes we forget about the seasonal earnings progression. Just any reason, as you look at your internal budgets, that, that would be materially different this time around?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

componenttext: No, I think the historical trend of the third quarter being the softest quarter for the hospital industry in general and certainly for us, I don't think we would see any reason why that wouldn't hold up in 2015 as well.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's -- the street sometimes seems to get a little ahead of you sometimes in the third quarter. So just appreciate that. And can you just comment on employment strategy? This hasn't really been a focus. I think, internally at UHS as perhaps others
componenttext: Okay. That's -- the street sometimes seems to get a little ahead of you sometimes in the third quarter. So just appreciate that. And can you just comment on employment strategy? This hasn't really been a focus. I think, internally at UHS as perhaps others, and that's perhaps a cultural dynamic in some of your markets. But where do you think you are and the industry is within that particular cycle?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I always think -- I mean, a couple of things. I mean, I don't think UHS sort of emphasizes it as we talk about the business as much as some of our peers, but it doesn't mean that we have not employed physicians. I think we view physician employment the wa
componenttext: I always think -- I mean, a couple of things. I mean, I don't think UHS sort of emphasizes it as we talk about the business as much as some of our peers, but it doesn't mean that we have not employed physicians. I think we view physician employment the way we view a lot of our market strategies and market development and business development strategies in that they are very market-specific. So there are some markets in which we have a significant amount of physician employment. McAllen is one. Texoma is another. There are other markets like Las Vegas where in general, the market has not seen a lot of physician employment for a variety of reasons. So we'll see. I mean, we continue to do what we think is the most appropriate competitive thing in every market. We definitely have a view that physician integration is going to be more and more important as time goes on, and we certainly are doing what we can in that regard. In some cases employing physicians; in many cases, working with physicians to integrate our information technologies. We think that's a very important strategy. We'll continue to do that, but we'll also continue to be judicious about it because at the end of the day, we think that most hospitals lose money on owned-physician practices. And obviously, that's an end result that if we can avoid, we'd prefer to avoid.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Jen, when we bought Cygnet, I think we had a view that as we modeled that acquisition, that rates from the NHS, which 95-plus percent of our patients are NHS patients, would be relatively kind of flat to maybe up 1% for the foreseeable future on an ann
componenttext: So Jen, when we bought Cygnet, I think we had a view that as we modeled that acquisition, that rates from the NHS, which 95-plus percent of our patients are NHS patients, would be relatively kind of flat to maybe up 1% for the foreseeable future on an annual basis. I don't think any of our current experience in our 9 months of ownership or so has really made us think any differently about that. So I think our actual performance has kind of fit into that. And I think as we continue to think about the next few years, we still think that's the right way of thinking about the business. And so any growth from that business is going to -- much more likely to come from volume growth than it is from rate growth.
