headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your  conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Filton, you may begin your conference.
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your  conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Filton, you may begin your conference.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the third quarter ended September 30, 2015. During this conference call, Alan and I will be using words such
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the third quarter ended September 30, 2015. 
During this conference call, Alan and I will be using words such as believes, expects, anticipates, estimates and similar words that represent forecasts, projections and forward-looking statements. 
For anyone not familiar with the risks and uncertainties inherent in these forward-looking statements, I recommend a careful reading of the section on Risk Factors and Forward-looking Statements and Risk Factors in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014, and our Form 10-Q for the quarter ended June 30, 2015.
We would like to highlight just a couple of developments and business trends before opening the call up to questions.
As discussed in our press release last night, the company reported net income attributable to UHS of $1.48 per diluted share for the third quarter of 2015. After adjusting each quarter's reported results for the incentive income and expenses recorded in connection with implementation of electronic health record applications at our acute care hospitals, as well as the other items attributable to last year's third quarter as disclosed on the supplemental schedule included with last night's earnings release, adjusted net income attributable to UHS increased approximately 13% to $155.3 million or $1.53 per diluted share during the third quarter of 2015 as compared to $137.5 million or $1.36 per diluted share during the third quarter of last year.
On a same-facility basis in our acute care division, revenues during the third quarter of 2015 increased 7.2% over last year's comparable quarter. The increase resulted primarily from a 5.1% increase in adjusted admissions to our hospitals owned for more than a year and a 3% increase in revenue per adjusted admission. 
On a same-facility basis, operating margins for our acute hospitals decreased to 15.4% during the third quarter of 2015 from 17.1% during the third quarter of 2014.
As expected, net revenue growth slowed in the third quarter from the unprecedented levels we have been experiencing in the first half of the year. Surgical volumes moderated a bit and uncompensated care volumes ticked up as well. At the same time, there was a measurable increase in nursing cost all contributing to the margin declines.
On a same-facility basis, net revenues on our behavioral health division increased 5% during the third quarter of 2015 as compared to the third quarter of 2014.
During this year's third quarter as compared to last year's, adjusted admissions and adjusted patient days to our behavioral health facilities owned for more than a year each increased 1.6%. 
Revenue per adjusted admission and adjusted patient day each rose 3.1% during the third quarter of 2015 over the comparable prior year quarter.
Operating margins for our behavioral health hospitals owned for more than a year were 27.5% and 27.6% during the quarters ended September 30, 2015 and 2014 respectively.
For the 9 months ended September 30, 2015, our net cash provided by operating activities increased approximately 16% [ph] to $796 million over the $690 million generated during the comparable 9-month period of 2014.
Our accounts receivable days outstanding decreased slightly to 55 days during the third quarter of 2015 as compared to 56 days during the third quarter of 2014.
At September 30, 2015, our ratio of debt to total capitalization decreased to 42.8% as compared to 48.9% at September 30, 2014.
We spent $99 million on capital expenditures during the third quarter of 2015 and $270 [ph] million during the first 9 months of 2015.
In connection with our previously announced $400 million stock repurchase program, we repurchased 543,380 shares at an aggregate cost of approximately $72 million during the third quarter of this year. Since inception of the program through September 30, 2015, we have repurchased approximately 1.4 million shares at an aggregate cost of approximately $166 million and had a remaining share repurchase authorization of approximately $234 million as of the end of the third quarter.
In August 2015 we acquired 4 behavioral health facilities with 305 beds located in the U.K. This acquisition increases our behavioral health presence in the U.K. to 21 facilities consisting of approximately 1,100 beds. 
In October 2015, we completed the acquisition of Foundations Recovery Network. Through this acquisition, we have added 4 inpatient facilities consisting of 322 beds as well as 8 outpatient centers. In addition, there are over 140 expansion beds in progress for Foundation as well.
Foundation is one of the premier names in addiction treatment is focused on treating adults with co-occurring addiction and mental health disorders through an evidenced-based integrated treatment model in residential and outpatient settings. 
Based upon the operating trends and financial results experienced during the first 9 months of 2015, we're revising our estimated range of adjusted net income attributable to UHS for the year ended December 31, 2015 to $6.75 to $7.05 per diluted share. This revised guidance, which excludes the expected electronic health records impact for the year maintains the lower end of the previously provided range of $6.75 to $7.15 per diluted share and decreases the upper end of the range by approximately 1%. 
Alan and I are pleased to answer your questions at this time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Matthew Borsch from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Matthew Borsch from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is [indiscernible] joining on for Matthew Borsch. I was wondering if you could touch a little bit more on both on the growth in the uninsured on the acute care side? I can see the provision grew faster than the uninsured charges as a whole. And I was
componenttext: This is [indiscernible] joining on for Matthew Borsch. I was wondering if you could touch a little bit more on both on the growth in the uninsured on the acute care side? I can see the provision grew faster than the uninsured charges as a whole. And I was just curious about that in terms of any difference in collection rates or why that would be the case.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we did see, as the data that you cited suggest a -- an increase in uncompensated care in the third quarter. While we saw throughout the portfolio, I think it was most evident in our Texas and specifically in our South Texas market. And I think ou
componenttext: Sure. So we did see, as the data that you cited suggest a -- an increase in uncompensated care in the third quarter. While we saw throughout the portfolio, I think it was most evident in our Texas and specifically in our South Texas market. And I think our estimate is  that increase in uncompensated care probably had an impact in maybe 50 basis point reduction in our acute care margins during the quarter.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to touch on acute care margin again and speaking with this conversation. So 50 basis -- excuse me, 50 basis points impact to the uncompensated care. Wonder if you can tell us how much of an impact to the temporary nursing costs were in the q
componenttext: I just wanted to touch on acute care margin again and speaking with this conversation. So 50 basis -- excuse me, 50 basis points impact to the uncompensated care. Wonder if you can tell us how much of an impact to the temporary nursing costs were in the quarter? And sort of what's going on there, is there higher competition, is it tightness? Do you think that's going to continue into the fourth quarter and into next year? Anymore color there.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paula. Just from an order of magnitude, I think the impact of the increase in temporary nurse cost was similar to the uncompensated care impact that is in the neighborhood of 50 basis points. Obviously, it is a trend that has been mentioned by a num
componenttext: Sure, Paula. Just from an order of magnitude, I think the impact of the increase in temporary nurse cost was similar to the uncompensated care impact that is in the neighborhood of 50 basis points. Obviously, it is a trend that has been mentioned by a number of our peers as well, which is not necessarily something we were aware of during the quarter. I think from our perspective, we continue to have and generate very substantial acute care demand as reflected in our growing admissions, very helpfully growing admissions. And as a result, that is contributing to a need for more employees, particularly nurses. And honestly, I think we're just not filling those positions as quickly and as efficiently and expeditiously as we would hope. To some degree, I think we probably underestimated the need for new nurses as demand has remained as strong as it has. As we look forward and project sort of solving this issue or solving the problem, I think we view it as definitely a fixable problem and one that we will address in the fourth quarter and begin to make progress in the fourth quarter and certainly begin to really solve the issue by the beginning of next year as we fill those vacant positions. The feedback that I get from our hospitals when we talk to them is that they can fill those positions. They're sort of redoubling their efforts to do so. So we're fairly confident that we'll address that issue in the near future.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And one more if I may. Just turning to behavioral quickly and the Foundations acquisition that you did. Can you update us may be on the thoughts on the expansion? I know you said 140 beds, I believe. When should we expect those to come online
componenttext: Okay, great. And one more if I may. Just turning to behavioral quickly and the Foundations acquisition that you did. Can you update us may be on the thoughts on the expansion? I know you said 140 beds, I believe. When should we expect those to come online? And are they across all of the 4 facilities? How fast do you expect the addiction piece of your behavioral business to grow? And maybe you can help us think about some of the future investments there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean in the grand scheme, the foundations acquisition is relatively small, but we think strategically important acquisition. Obviously, we're talking about 330 beds out of a total of 20,000. But I think we think that the foundation acquisition ver
componenttext: Sure. I mean in the grand scheme, the foundations acquisition is relatively small, but we think strategically important acquisition. Obviously, we're talking about 330 beds out of a total of 20,000. But I think we think that the foundation acquisition very nicely complements our existing addiction businesses. We probably have 8 or 9 dedicated addiction facilities in our portfolio today, as well as the fact that we offer addiction services in many of our other behavioral  facilities as well. And we think that the foundations model, as well as the foundations model in terms of patient treatment as well as their model for patient capture is one that we'll have relevance for us throughout our other addiction businesses. And quite frankly, in some of our other lines of business as well, things like eating disorders, et cetera. So 140 beds that are in the Q for Foundations are both additions to existing facilities as well as some de novo development. I think they're all likely to be completed within the 12-month cycle and we continue to look for other opportunities to expand that business as well as other elements of our behavioral business.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Chris Rigg from Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Chris Rigg from Susquehanna Financial.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Frank for Chris Rigg. Acute care volumes continue to be strong in the quarter. I'm just curious if there are any specific regions that are driving that growth that you can call out? And the revised guidance reflect a similar pace of volume growth
componenttext: This is Frank for Chris Rigg. Acute care volumes continue to be strong in the quarter. I'm just curious if there are any specific regions that are driving that growth that you can call out? And the revised guidance reflect a similar pace of volume growth in the fourth quarter?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Frank. So I think the acute care volume growth, we talked a little bit about this in general in the first half of the year saying that the strongest performing markets were Las Vegas, Nevada and Southern California. And as I mentioned before, I think
componenttext: Yes, Frank. So I think the acute care volume growth, we talked a little bit about this in general in the first half of the year saying that the strongest performing markets were Las Vegas, Nevada and Southern California. And as I mentioned before, I think our Texas markets and particularly South Texas markets have lagged a little bit over the last few quarters. And I think all those same trends were present in Q3 as well. In terms of the revised guidance and how that acute care growth fits into that, again we revised that guidance at the end of the second quarter. We talked about the fact that the first half of the year, acute care revenue growth of 10% was unlikely to be sustainable. It was sort of unprecedented in the history, not only of the company, but of the acute care industry. And we thought that revenues in the back half of the year and frankly going forward would likely moderate to levels more like 6.5%, 7%. And that's certainly what happened in Q3. And I think our revised guidance, taking off the very top end of the guidance, was simply an acknowledgment that those acute care revenues had moderated and would likely continue to do so in that I think we had said to get to the high end of that range, we have to sustain those 10% or so revenue growth levels. And I think the revision at the top end of the range was just an acknowledgment that, that was very unlikely.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks. And then it looks like share repurchases increased pretty meaningfully in the quarter even with the alpha transaction. Can you help us think about the pace repurchases going forward? And the fourth quarter given the Foundations acquisition?
componenttext: Okay, thanks. And then it looks like share repurchases increased pretty meaningfully in the quarter even with the alpha transaction. Can you help us think about the pace repurchases going forward? And the fourth quarter given the Foundations acquisition?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't necessarily think that either of the 2 recent acquisitions, Alpha in Q3 and Foundations in Q4 will materially affect the way we think about share repurchase. Obviously, we have the view that our share price has seen a dramatic decline in the
componenttext: Yes, I don't necessarily think that either of the 2 recent acquisitions, Alpha in Q3 and Foundations in Q4 will materially affect the way we think about share repurchase. Obviously, we have the view that our share price has seen a dramatic decline in the last month or 2 and is not necessarily from our perspective related to real fundamental changes in the business, in our business trends or in future prospects of the business. So I think we view the current share price as an attractive investment. And we'll continue to look at share repurchase in the same way that we have historically with other capital deployment opportunities, which we think also fits at this point in time. I think we're ready for the next question.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from Kevin Fischbeck from Bank of America.
componenttext: And your next question is from Kevin Fischbeck from Bank of America.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is actually Joanna Gajuk filling in for Kevin today. I want to go back to the discussion on margins in your segment. So first of all, in terms of the comments around temporary staffing, you suggested you feel that you might be able to refill these po
componenttext: This is actually Joanna Gajuk filling in for Kevin today. I want to go back to the discussion on margins in your segment. So first of all, in terms of the comments around temporary staffing, you suggested you feel that you might be able to refill these positions in Q4 in the beginning of next year. But does it feel like to you there might be something more systemic going on in the industry given that we're hearing clear point from other providers talking about similar issues? So any color you might have in terms of what you feel this is very flexible in the near-term or whether there's something systemic going on around in terms of the labor cost or the ability to staff nurses?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Joanna, the best I can offer is that given my tenure in the industry, I can remember some 10 years ago when we -- the industry was experiencing a really severe shortage of nurses and other clinical professionals. And I recall talking to our hospitals at t
componenttext: Joanna, the best I can offer is that given my tenure in the industry, I can remember some 10 years ago when we -- the industry was experiencing a really severe shortage of nurses and other clinical professionals. And I recall talking to our hospitals at that time and when we talk at that time about hiring and filling vacancies, the feedback you get from the hospitals was simply, they just couldn't do it. There just weren't nurses out there. Didn't matter what we were willing to pay. There was enormous pressure on wages. I will tell you that the current environment just doesn't have the same feel to it. Certainly, this issue of increased use of temporary nurses is not unique to us. Other companies have reported it as well. So it seems to be a bit more systemic issue. But it also, based on the feedback that we're getting from our hospitals, is one that remains fixable. I mean, they're hiring nurses. They're hiring nurses within our current wage scale etc. We do have an impression and a feeling that this really is an addressable issue and one that can be dealt with in relatively near-term.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks. And then I was also in the same topic in terms of the margin pressure out there. In the past, I believe you talked about ability in the acute care segment to show margin expansion if revenue was 3% [ph] I believe. But clearly it didn't happ
componenttext: Great, thanks. And then I was also in the same topic in terms of the margin pressure out there. In the past, I believe you talked about ability in the acute care segment to show margin expansion if revenue was 3% [ph] I believe. But clearly it didn't happen this quarter because margins were down 170 basis points year-over-year at a same-store basis. So you said 50 basis points from the temporary staffing and then another 50 from the uncompensated care costs. So what else was driving -- putting the margins to be under so much pressure given that the top line growth was so strong?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think it's worth pointing the comparison, the acute care comparison in context, we ran over 17% margins in the third quarter of 2014. And those margins and the EBITDA that the acute care business generated in the third quarter of 2014 was almost a
componenttext: Sure. I think it's worth pointing the comparison, the acute care comparison in context, we ran over 17% margins in the third quarter of 2014. And those margins and the EBITDA that the acute care business generated in the third quarter of 2014 was almost a doubling of what it had run in the previous year. And the 17% margin, I think, was probably the best margin we've ever run in the third quarter in that division. So the comparison was extremely difficult. And even though I think your point is a valid one and well taken, and that is that under normal circumstances, if we generate 7% growth, revenue growth in the acute division, we would expect to have margin expansion. And I believe that's what we will expect in the future. In the third quarter, there were a couple of extenuating circumstances which we have discussed already. But I think it's just that extenuating circumstances as opposed to sort of fundamental changes in the model. I think our general sense is that at these very healthy revenue levels and that's what I think we take away from the quarter as the most important message, we believe that in the future we will be able to generate the margin expansion that we've come to expect at those levels.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So then you suggest that you don't expect the -- I guess the volume growth to remain at the 5% range, I mean, without giving guidance for next year. But what kind of type of volume growth would you expect over the near-term or medium term, I guess of -- i
componenttext: So then you suggest that you don't expect the -- I guess the volume growth to remain at the 5% range, I mean, without giving guidance for next year. But what kind of type of volume growth would you expect over the near-term or medium term, I guess of -- in the acute care segment?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as you suggest, im not going to give 2016 guidance and we're not going to give it for another several [ph] months. But I will just sort of reiterate what we talked about it in the end of the second quarter of this year and that is that we thought th
componenttext: Well, as you suggest, im not going to give 2016 guidance and we're not going to give it for another several [ph] months. But I will just sort of reiterate what we talked about it in the end of the second quarter of this year and that is that we thought that acute care revenue growth would moderate from the 10% unprecedented levels that we were experiencing to something closer to 6.5%, 7%. That is in fact what happened. We're very comfortable at those levels. Not prepared to say whether those levels are going to be sustainable completely into 2016. But certainly sustainable through the end of the year. And we're very comfortable that over the long-term, we will generate margin expansion at those revenue growth levels.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from A.J. Rice with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question is from A.J. Rice with UBS.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of things may be. On the payer mix, you're laying down a little bit more. You have the details in the year-to-year change or some other key components of that? Or the percentages, how they changed?
componenttext: Just a couple of things may be. On the payer mix, you're laying down a little bit more. You have the details in the year-to-year change or some other key components of that? Or the percentages, how they changed?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: AJ, I think as we discussed in the first half of the year, we continue to see growth in both our Medicare and Medicaid utilization and that's total Medicare Medicaid meaning both traditional and managed. What was a little bit different in the third quarte
componenttext: AJ, I think as we discussed in the first half of the year, we continue to see growth in both our Medicare and Medicaid utilization and that's total Medicare Medicaid meaning both traditional and managed. What was a little bit different in the third quarter was we saw our commercial volume growth slow some. We had been since the beginning of the ACA implementation and the economic recovery seeing commercial volumes increasing in the high single and double-digit, low double-digit ranges. I think that commercial volume increase in the third quarter was only like 3% or 4%. Still good but a deceleration from where we've seen. And I think we saw an uptick in uncompensated volumes as well uninsured volumes. But they have been declining, quite frankly, for a number of period. And in the third quarter of this year, uninsured volumes were up, let's call it 6% or 7%.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And when you -- I know you said when you drill down, Texas was especially the, I would say the border community or something I guess where you saw some of that pressure. When you asked your operators what they see, is there anything to call out ther
componenttext: Okay. And when you -- I know you said when you drill down, Texas was especially the, I would say the border community or something I guess where you saw some of that pressure. When you asked your operators what they see, is there anything to call out there? I know you're asked questions all the time about energy patch. I wouldn't necessarily associate with those types of hospitals, but is there any issue there? Or anything more broadly are just natural ebb and flow you see sometimes in a quarter-to-quarter swing?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Honestly, AJ, it's hard to say. It's the best answer I can give you. You're right that the South Texas market, Mical [ph] and Norado [ph] are not markets that are heavily dependent on the oil and gas industry. They're not markets where there's sort of qua
componenttext: Honestly, AJ, it's hard to say. It's the best answer I can give you. You're right that the South Texas market, Mical [ph] and Norado [ph] are not markets that are heavily dependent on the oil and gas industry. They're not markets where there's sort of quarter economic metrics like employment seem to be deteriorating in any meaningful way. So the increase in uncompensated care is a bit of a head scratcher in those markets. And I think a lot of times, it's a mistake to draw broad conclusions from one quarter's worth of results in a particular market. So I think we'll wait and see and try and evaluate it as it goes forward. But no, I mean, it's not obvious to us what's driving that change.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly on the capital deployment. I mean, I understand the enthusiasm for your stock even in its pullback as it has on the buyback. Any commentary on what you're seeing on the acquisition front, either acute or psych, you've done 2 sma
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly on the capital deployment. I mean, I understand the enthusiasm for your stock even in its pullback as it has on the buyback. Any commentary on what you're seeing on the acquisition front, either acute or psych, you've done 2 small deals in the quarter. But it sounded early in the year, we actually thought there would be some things on the acute side, is there's some things out there or where do we stand?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So again in our second quarter call, we had expressed the view that we thought that the pipeline for potential opportunities was busier than it had been for some time. Subsequent to that, as you suggest, we did 2 behavioral deals totaling $500 million in
componenttext: So again in our second quarter call, we had expressed the view that we thought that the pipeline for potential opportunities was busier than it had been for some time. Subsequent to that, as you suggest, we did 2 behavioral deals totaling $500 million in total investment. We continued to look at other behavioral opportunities. We continued to look at the acute opportunities. We do -- I think we would continue to describe the pipeline, if you will, as more active than it's been in a while. And so as we always do, I think we kind of look at that landscape. We look at our ability or opportunity to purchase -- repurchase our own stock as well, and we sort of try and measure each of those opportunities against each other. And obviously, we have an exceptionally strong balance sheet with very low leverage levels which allows us to pursue multiple opportunities at once. And that's going to continue to be our plan.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: AJ, I'd also point out that in addition to the $500 million we've spent, we have -- we're very excited about hospital under construction in Las Vegas. We have built our own acute care hospital here. We're spending between $155 million and $185 million on
componenttext: AJ, I'd also point out that in addition to the $500 million we've spent, we have -- we're very excited about hospital under construction in Las Vegas. We have built our own acute care hospital here. We're spending between $155 million and $185 million on those hospitals. So we are making investments in the acute business. And as opportunities present themselves, we're ready to take advantage of them.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Okay, great. Yes, I guess I called a little [indiscernible] not so little, actually.

componenttext: I wasn't going to correct you, AJ.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Josh Raskin with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Josh Raskin with Barclays.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, I appreciate those comments around sort of what we saw on the last nursing shortage, I guess volumes sequentially are relatively similar. So what's causing that need for temporary labor? Has there been just more turn over? Are you not filling those
componenttext: Steve, I appreciate those comments around sort of what we saw on the last nursing shortage, I guess volumes sequentially are relatively similar. So what's causing that need for temporary labor? Has there been just more turn over? Are you not filling those roles? Any sense of where these nurses and clinicians are getting hired or are they going to nontraditional channels at this point? And then if you could also comment any decision compensation and recruitment issues within that labor, or is this really all just nursing

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me address the first one. I think if we're seeing any pressure on physician staffing, I think it tends to be on the behavioral side. We've mentioned this once or twice before. At least in some specific markets, it's been difficult for us to hire th
componenttext: So let me address the first one. I think if we're seeing any pressure on physician staffing, I think it tends to be on the behavioral side. We've mentioned this once or twice before. At least in some specific markets, it's been difficult for us to hire the appropriate number of psychiatrists. And that's been a bit of a drag both to the degree that we can -- we don't have sufficient numbers of psychiatrists. We see our volumes pressured a little bit. Behavioral admissions were a little bit soft in Q3. And I think as I look around the portfolio, there were a market or 2 where I would attribute some of that softness to a shortage of physicians. Also to the degree that we're using temporary physicians that pushes our operating expense up in the behavioral division and you'll see that in the Q a little bit. You see the specific pressure on our operating expenses in behavioral, again, around the margins at least. On the acute side, it's a good question exactly why this problem is sort of bubbling up at the moment, Josh. My sense is that to some degree, there has been a bit of a skepticism out in the field that the really strong volumes that we've been generating were going to continue. And I think there's always a bit of hesitancy to hire nurses when you're not sure if volume strength will continue. So I think that may have been. I think there may have been some unnecessary skepticism about the need for those nurses, but I think that's now become clear. Turn over has an increase for us. I know some of our peers have mentioned that. We're constantly trying to drive turn over rates down, and I'm not sure that we're terribly successful in driving them down. But I'd certainly think that they have been stable for us. And then finally, this idea that there is a lot of these alternate care providers, [indiscernible] providers etc. I think in our markets at least, the numbers of those source of providers and the amount of people they're hiring is relatively immaterial. So it doesn't seem to me to be the item that's really driving this.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's really helpful. And then just one quick follow-up. Are you seeing any delays on Medicaid enrollment? Are you seeing anything different on the state level in terms of their ability to process and enroll some of these previously uninsured indiv
componenttext: Okay. That's really helpful. And then just one quick follow-up. Are you seeing any delays on Medicaid enrollment? Are you seeing anything different on the state level in terms of their ability to process and enroll some of these previously uninsured individuals?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I know that was cited by one of our peers. I checked with our folks this morning because I have not heard that. And they sort of reiterated that it has not been an issue for us. So I don't think that's what's driving our uncompensated experience.
componenttext: Yes, I know that was cited by one of our peers. I checked with our folks this morning because I have not heard that. And they sort of reiterated that it has not been an issue for us. So I don't think that's what's driving our uncompensated experience.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Your next question is from Gary Lieberman from Wells Fargo.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I know you said you weren't entirely clear what was causing the slowdown in commercial volumes comparatively anyway. Is there any indication that you're seeing individuals that were previously covered by exchange plans coming off of those plans? Or do you
componenttext: I know you said you weren't entirely clear what was causing the slowdown in commercial volumes comparatively anyway. Is there any indication that you're seeing individuals that were previously covered by exchange plans coming off of those plans? Or do you think it's more seasonal weakness in the third quarter that comes back in the fourth quarter. What were your thoughts there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and again I know that one of our peers cited that as sort of a dynamic as well. And it's an intellectually kind of intuitively obvious argument. It seems logical that it could be happening. Other than a couple of anecdotal examples that we've been ab
componenttext: Yes, and again I know that one of our peers cited that as sort of a dynamic as well. And it's an intellectually kind of intuitively obvious argument. It seems logical that it could be happening. Other than a couple of anecdotal examples that we've been able to gather, we're really not able to generate sort of any measurable data that would suggest we're seeing that in sort of large volumes. We'll continue to watch that. Again, Gary, I'm going to repeat a comment I made a little bit ago. I think sometimes it can be a mistake to draw really broad conclusions about one quarter's worth of metrics. We try -- we're exploring and we certainly dive into these numbers when we see them. But none of these other explanations, at least for us, seem to be terribly obvious or explanations that we could really prove out.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then can you give as an update on the U.K. behavioral market, the acquisition environment? Any update on pricing or reimbursement issues there?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then can you give as an update on the U.K. behavioral market, the acquisition environment? Any update on pricing or reimbursement issues there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, the operational environment has been very good. We've said from the beginning in the Signet acquisition, just about a year old at this point, that Signet pretty much every single quarter and the third quarter was no exception has exceeded our expe
componenttext: I mean, the operational environment has been very good. We've said from the beginning in the Signet acquisition, just about a year old at this point, that Signet pretty much every single quarter and the third quarter was no exception has exceeded our expectations. Their volumes and occupancy rates are extremely high. They continue to pursue opportunities that include building new beds at existing hospitals, doing some de novo development, doing some small acquisition work and looking at acquisitions of various sizes. So we continue to be very positive about our entry into the U.K. behavioral market and are working very sort of pointedly with our local management there to continue to grow that platform.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Ana Gupte with Leerink partners.
componenttext: Your next question is from Ana Gupte with Leerink partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to come back to the uncompensated care issue, Steve, if any. You said it's in South Texas and it's probably not the slow Medicaid application processing. Have you had any kind of anecdotal data in your department or whatever whether these peop
componenttext: So I wanted to come back to the uncompensated care issue, Steve, if any. You said it's in South Texas and it's probably not the slow Medicaid application processing. Have you had any kind of anecdotal data in your department or whatever whether these people have been in exchanges and are now trying to get [indiscernible] just lost their jobs [indiscernible] enrollment Medicaid or exchanges or whatever, they're not insured right now. Just trying to get a sense despite of what you're seeing, how structural is this for the '16 [ph] because it meaningfully changes your forecast?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So a couple of things. I mean I just wanted to clarify a little bit. What I said was the increase in uncompensated care was most evident in the South Texas market, and that's true. But I don't want to leave the impression that it was completely limit
componenttext: Yes. So a couple of things. I mean I just wanted to clarify a little bit. What I said was the increase in uncompensated care was most evident in the South Texas market, and that's true. But I don't want to leave the impression that it was completely limited. We saw an uptick in uncompensated care in other markets as well. I mean, again, I think you're asking the question that Gary asked maybe a little bit differently. We're not able to attribute that increase to specifically to commercial exchange patients or subscribers, not being able to make their premium payments. We're not really able to subscribe or ascribe the increase in anything in particular. And I think that our sort of outlook on this is we'll wait and see. We'll try and gather more data as another month or 2 passes and do a better job of trying to figure out what's going on. I realized that there is a lot of pressure on folks all over to try and figure this out immediately. I will say this -- at the end of the day, even with the increase in bad debt and uncompensated care pressure, we generated 7.2% acute care revenue growth in the quarter. And if somebody had asked me a year ago whether I would take that, I would've taken that offer. And in an instant I'll take it again next quarter if presented to me. So I appreciate the fact that there's a lot of focus on this increase in uncompensated care. But I think sometimes, we're looking at the glass in the wrong way. I mean, this glass is half-full in my mind when acute care revenues are growing by 7.2% over the prior year.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, fair enough. Your volumes in growth was great in acute. And my apologies again if this was asked before on a different call. On Medicare in the second quarter as well, you talked about very strong volumes. How much is Medicare is contributing to your
componenttext: Yes, fair enough. Your volumes in growth was great in acute. And my apologies again if this was asked before on a different call. On Medicare in the second quarter as well, you talked about very strong volumes. How much is Medicare is contributing to your volume growth? [indiscernible] might be lacking or is there something structural we can carry forward in terms of the volume?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the strength in Medicare volumes is something that we've now seen probably for at least 3 quarters. And I think, as you suggest, probably an explanation for the strength in Medicare volumes is the idea that some of the weakness that we saw a year
componenttext: Yes, so the strength in Medicare volumes is something that we've now seen probably for at least 3 quarters. And I think, as you suggest, probably an explanation for the strength in Medicare volumes is the idea that some of the weakness that we saw a year ago as a result of this shift from inpatients to observation patients has anniversary-ed a bit. We continue to see observation patients being quoted with frequency, but I do think we're lapping some of that. And that makes sense only because all the other explanations that usually offer for increased volumes, the ACA impact or the economic impact, are generally not relevant to the Medicare population. So I think this idea that we're starting to sort of see some leveling off of some of this pressure on Medicare admissions that we have seen for a few years is a relevant explanation.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And any differences in the managed Medicare versus the traditional?
componenttext: And any differences in the managed Medicare versus the traditional?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think generally we find that when a population moves from traditional Medicare to managed, it's usually reflected in length of stay pressures rather than in actual admission rate pressures. So no, I don't think we're seeing a big change between the
componenttext: No. I think generally we find that when a population moves from traditional Medicare to managed, it's usually reflected in length of stay pressures rather than in actual admission rate pressures. So no, I don't think we're seeing a big change between the 2 populations.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: But in [indiscernible] the budget deal, any thoughts on that, assuming nobody else [indiscernible] and then I'll go back in queue.
componenttext: But in [indiscernible] the budget deal, any thoughts on that, assuming nobody else [indiscernible] and then I'll go back in queue.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, I think that there's still some clarification that we as an industry are looking for. But I think with the major change being to [ph] alternate site payments. And the idea that I think hospitals are not going to be able to use hospital rates f
componenttext: No, I mean, I think that there's still some clarification that we as an industry are looking for. But I think with the major change being to [ph] alternate site payments. And the idea that I think hospitals are not going to be able to use hospital rates for some alternate site payments, I think we may see a slowdown in the way hospitals in general, approach some of those off-campus strategies. I would say that this has not been a huge part of the UHS model. And obviously whatever we have as grandfathered anyway according to the deal as I understand it. So I don't view this as a real significant change to our operating outlook at the moment.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Your next question is from Rob Jiacobi from Sidoti.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Apologies if I'm a half little bit late. Did you give the exchange volume in the quarter, Steve, and how that is tracked in the last couple of quarters?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ralph, not specifically exchange volume. I talked a little bit about commercial volume in general. I think we, as a company, sort of said beginning -- at the beginning of this year, that we really were no longer trying to separate out discreetly the impac
componenttext: Ralph, not specifically exchange volume. I talked a little bit about commercial volume in general. I think we, as a company, sort of said beginning -- at the beginning of this year, that we really were no longer trying to separate out discreetly the impact of the ACA or exchanges et cetera, and really haven't done so all year and certainly not going to do so this quarter. But I do talk about the fact that commercial exchange volume growth slowed some in the third quarter. And not commercial exchange, just general growth slowed some in the third quarter.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then what about acuity mix in the quarter? Did you give that? Was that a favorable impact?
componenttext: And then what about acuity mix in the quarter? Did you give that? Was that a favorable impact?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I didn't give it. I mentioned in my prepared remarks that surgical volume slowed a little bit. One of the comments that I had made in the first two quarters of this year was that for the first time in a long time inpatient surgeries and the growth in inpa
componenttext: I didn't give it. I mentioned in my prepared remarks that surgical volume slowed a little bit. One of the comments that I had made in the first two quarters of this year was that for the first time in a long time inpatient surgeries and the growth in inpatient surgeries were outpacing the growth in outpatient surgeries. In the third quarter, we sort of returned back to where we had been the last few year's where outpatient surgeries are growing faster than inpatient, although both continue to grow at a decent pace. But that's, I think, an indication of a small decline in acuity and contribution a little bit to the slow down on overall revenue growth.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess on the behavioral side with the regs out, sort of the IMD exclusion. To the extent it does hold, do you see this as sort of an immediate benefit as we head into '16 [ph]? Or is there something you need to do in terms of outreach and
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess on the behavioral side with the regs out, sort of the IMD exclusion. To the extent it does hold, do you see this as sort of an immediate benefit as we head into '16 [ph]? Or is there something you need to do in terms of outreach and education that would suggest that any benefit would be kind of later in the year as opposed to early in the year?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's a couple of issues. I mean, one is the rule has yet to be published in final form. And we certainly don't know exactly when that's going to happen. I'm actually told that CMS has a number of sort of pending rules in their queue. And
componenttext: Well, I think there's a couple of issues. I mean, one is the rule has yet to be published in final form. And we certainly don't know exactly when that's going to happen. I'm actually told that CMS has a number of sort of pending rules in their queue. And I think there's some speculation they may not get to this one until early in '16. And we're not sure at that point when the effective day would be. So that's an issue right away. And we just don't know when the rule and the effective date is going to be. But when the rule is issued, there is some of that work to be done. These patients are being treated, for the most part, in existing acute care facilities today. And we have work to do to, I think, communicate with those acute care facilities and see if there is an opportunity. And this is really a market by market effort to cooperate with them. And see if those patients can be treated in sort of a more efficient way, mutually efficient way for both the acute care hospital and for us. We also have to work with the managed Medicaid companies to negotiate rates. I don't view that as a big hurdle, but something that has to be done. So there are a few steps that have to be taken once the rule does become effective. So at the moment, it's certainly impossible to predict what the impact on 2016 might be at this point.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just last one. I don't know if you have your stats with you, Steve, or not. Uninsured admissions relative to uninsured adjusted admissions. One sort of outpaced the other. Is there any way to put some context around whether the admissions h
componenttext: Okay. And then just last one. I don't know if you have your stats with you, Steve, or not. Uninsured admissions relative to uninsured adjusted admissions. One sort of outpaced the other. Is there any way to put some context around whether the admissions have grown sort of at a faster pace than the adjusted admission, specifically for the uninsured?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, uninsured admissions, I did say earlier, we're probably up 6% or 7% in the quarter. I don't really know what the adjusted admission number is for uninsureds. I would say that generally, the adjusted number for uninsured doesn't vary greatly f
componenttext: Yes. I mean, uninsured admissions, I did say earlier, we're probably up 6% or 7% in the quarter. I don't really know what the adjusted admission number is for uninsureds. I would say that generally, the adjusted number for uninsured doesn't vary greatly from the admission number just because we don't have the large component of outpatient revenue that we have for our regular admissions. It's basically EOR revenues is for the bulk of outpatient revenue that we have. There's usually not a huge difference.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Whit Mayo with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Whit Mayo with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, do you feel like the acute care business has just gotten to be much more seasonal over the years? For years you've been earning less in the third quarter, more in the fourth quarter. Anything just about physician behavior, vacation, employment, ben
componenttext: Steve, do you feel like the acute care business has just gotten to be much more seasonal over the years? For years you've been earning less in the third quarter, more in the fourth quarter. Anything just about physician behavior, vacation, employment, benefit? I just don't know why we should sit here and include that flat growth off of the year where your EBITDA expanded 85% is really a problem, especially with this volume. So I feel like a lot of this is an overreaction, but I don't know, I'm just kind of curious as you scan the landscape and see what's going on, everyone's missing for different reasons right now. I'm just curious if you have any sort of perspective on what you think is occurring.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks for the question, Whit. I think the traditional seasonality of the business has been distorted over the last couple of years with the implementation of ACA, with Medicaid expansion in some of our big states, with commercial enrollment, commer
componenttext: Well, thanks for the question, Whit. I think the traditional seasonality of the business has been distorted over the last couple of years with the implementation of ACA, with Medicaid expansion in some of our big states, with commercial enrollment, commercial exchange enrollment. With the dynamic in the fourth quarter, people exhausting co-pays and deductibles and having elective procedures done in the fourth quarter and that becoming more of an issue as co-pays and deductibles become a bigger part of the overall landscape. But I think the one sort of constant in all that is the third quarter has sort of traditionally been the weakest quarter. Honestly, when I saw our third quarter results a few weeks ago before anyone else had commented on theirs, I generally thought they were kind of a slightness that I attributed mostly to seasonality. I'm not actually sure having seen what people have said. I really feel like that's a wholly different. I mean, again, we're -- I'm back to the idea of feeling pretty good about a quarter in which we -- lots of our surgeons and physicians are on vacation. Lots of our patients are on vacation. Elective procedures are usually down pretty significantly in the quarter. And we still grew our revenue by over 7%. I'm still feeling pretty good about the fundamental performance of that acute division.
